41  
42 # The axes module contains all the wrappers to plotting functions.
43 # All the other methods should go in the _AxesBase class.
44  
45  
46 @_docstring.interpd
47 class Axes(_AxesBase):
48 """
49 An Axes object encapsulates all the elements of an individual (sub-)plot in
50 a figure.
51  
52 It contains most of the (sub-)plot elements: `~.axis.Axis`,
53 `~.axis.Tick`, `~.lines.Line2D`, `~.text.Text`, `~.patches.Polygon`, etc.,
54 and sets the coordinate system.
55  
56 Like all visible elements in a figure, Axes is an `.Artist` subclass.
57  
58 The `Axes` instance supports callbacks through a callbacks attribute which
59 is a `~.cbook.CallbackRegistry` instance. The events you can connect to
60 are 'xlim_changed' and 'ylim_changed' and the callback will be called with
61 func(*ax*) where *ax* is the `Axes` instance.
62  
63 .. note::
64  
65 As a user, you do not instantiate Axes directly, but use Axes creation
66 methods instead; e.g. from `.pyplot` or `.Figure`:
67 `~.pyplot.subplots`, `~.pyplot.subplot_mosaic` or `.Figure.add_axes`.
68  
69 Attributes
70 ----------
71 dataLim : `.Bbox`
72 The bounding box enclosing all data displayed in the Axes.
73 viewLim : `.Bbox`
74 The view limits in data coordinates.
75  
76 """
  • E266 Too many leading '#' for block comment
77 ### Labelling, legend and texts
78  
79 def get_title(self, loc="center"):
80 """
81 Get an Axes title.
82  
83 Get one of the three available Axes titles. The available titles
84 are positioned above the Axes in the center, flush with the left
85 edge, and flush with the right edge.
86  
87 Parameters
88 ----------
89 loc : {'center', 'left', 'right'}, str, default: 'center'
90 Which title to return.
91  
92 Returns
93 -------
94 str
95 The title text string.
96  
97 """
98 titles = {'left': self._left_title,
99 'center': self.title,
100 'right': self._right_title}
101 title = _api.check_getitem(titles, loc=loc.lower())
102 return title.get_text()
103  
104 def set_title(self, label, fontdict=None, loc=None, pad=None, *, y=None,
105 **kwargs):
106 """
107 Set a title for the Axes.
108  
109 Set one of the three available Axes titles. The available titles
110 are positioned above the Axes in the center, flush with the left
111 edge, and flush with the right edge.
112  
113 Parameters
114 ----------
115 label : str
116 Text to use for the title
117  
118 fontdict : dict
119  
120 .. admonition:: Discouraged
121  
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
122 The use of *fontdict* is discouraged. Parameters should be passed as
123 individual keyword arguments or using dictionary-unpacking
124 ``set_title(..., **fontdict)``.
125  
126 A dictionary controlling the appearance of the title text,
127 the default *fontdict* is::
128  
129 {'fontsize': rcParams['axes.titlesize'],
130 'fontweight': rcParams['axes.titleweight'],
131 'color': rcParams['axes.titlecolor'],
132 'verticalalignment': 'baseline',
133 'horizontalalignment': loc}
134  
135 loc : {'center', 'left', 'right'}, default: :rc:`axes.titlelocation`
136 Which title to set.
137  
138 y : float, default: :rc:`axes.titley`
139 Vertical Axes location for the title (1.0 is the top). If
140 None (the default) and :rc:`axes.titley` is also None, y is
141 determined automatically to avoid decorators on the Axes.
142  
143 pad : float, default: :rc:`axes.titlepad`
144 The offset of the title from the top of the Axes, in points.
145  
146 Returns
147 -------
148 `.Text`
149 The matplotlib text instance representing the title
150  
151 Other Parameters
152 ----------------
153 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.text.Text` properties
154 Other keyword arguments are text properties, see `.Text` for a list
155 of valid text properties.
156 """
157 if loc is None:
158 loc = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlelocation']
159  
160 if y is None:
161 y = mpl.rcParams['axes.titley']
162 if y is None:
163 y = 1.0
164 else:
165 self._autotitlepos = False
166 kwargs['y'] = y
167  
168 titles = {'left': self._left_title,
169 'center': self.title,
170 'right': self._right_title}
171 title = _api.check_getitem(titles, loc=loc.lower())
172 default = {
173 'fontsize': mpl.rcParams['axes.titlesize'],
174 'fontweight': mpl.rcParams['axes.titleweight'],
175 'verticalalignment': 'baseline',
176 'horizontalalignment': loc.lower()}
177 titlecolor = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlecolor']
178 if not cbook._str_lower_equal(titlecolor, 'auto'):
179 default["color"] = titlecolor
180 if pad is None:
181 pad = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlepad']
182 self._set_title_offset_trans(float(pad))
183 title.set_text(label)
184 title.update(default)
185 if fontdict is not None:
186 title.update(fontdict)
187 title._internal_update(kwargs)
188 return title
189  
190 def get_legend_handles_labels(self, legend_handler_map=None):
191 """
192 Return handles and labels for legend
193  
194 ``ax.legend()`` is equivalent to ::
195  
196 h, l = ax.get_legend_handles_labels()
197 ax.legend(h, l)
198 """
199 # pass through to legend.
200 handles, labels = mlegend._get_legend_handles_labels(
201 [self], legend_handler_map)
202 return handles, labels
203  
204 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
205 def legend(self, *args, **kwargs):
206 """
207 Place a legend on the Axes.
208  
209 Call signatures::
210  
211 legend()
212 legend(handles, labels)
213 legend(handles=handles)
214 legend(labels)
215  
216 The call signatures correspond to the following different ways to use
217 this method:
218  
219 **1. Automatic detection of elements to be shown in the legend**
220  
221 The elements to be added to the legend are automatically determined,
222 when you do not pass in any extra arguments.
223  
224 In this case, the labels are taken from the artist. You can specify
225 them either at artist creation or by calling the
226 :meth:`~.Artist.set_label` method on the artist::
227  
228 ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='Inline label')
229 ax.legend()
230  
231 or::
232  
233 line, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3])
234 line.set_label('Label via method')
235 ax.legend()
236  
237 .. note::
238 Specific artists can be excluded from the automatic legend element
239 selection by using a label starting with an underscore, "_".
240 A string starting with an underscore is the default label for all
241 artists, so calling `.Axes.legend` without any arguments and
242 without setting the labels manually will result in no legend being
243 drawn.
244  
245  
246 **2. Explicitly listing the artists and labels in the legend**
247  
248 For full control of which artists have a legend entry, it is possible
249 to pass an iterable of legend artists followed by an iterable of
250 legend labels respectively::
251  
252 ax.legend([line1, line2, line3], ['label1', 'label2', 'label3'])
253  
254  
255 **3. Explicitly listing the artists in the legend**
256  
257 This is similar to 2, but the labels are taken from the artists'
258 label properties. Example::
259  
260 line1, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label1')
261 line2, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label2')
262 ax.legend(handles=[line1, line2])
263  
264  
265 **4. Labeling existing plot elements**
266  
267 .. admonition:: Discouraged
268  
269 This call signature is discouraged, because the relation between
270 plot elements and labels is only implicit by their order and can
271 easily be mixed up.
272  
273 To make a legend for all artists on an Axes, call this function with
274 an iterable of strings, one for each legend item. For example::
275  
276 ax.plot([1, 2, 3])
277 ax.plot([5, 6, 7])
278 ax.legend(['First line', 'Second line'])
279  
280  
281 Parameters
282 ----------
283 handles : list of (`.Artist` or tuple of `.Artist`), optional
284 A list of Artists (lines, patches) to be added to the legend.
285 Use this together with *labels*, if you need full control on what
286 is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above
287 is not sufficient.
288  
289 The length of handles and labels should be the same in this
290 case. If they are not, they are truncated to the smaller length.
291  
  • E501 Line too long (88 > 79 characters)
292 If an entry contains a tuple, then the legend handler for all Artists in the
293 tuple will be placed alongside a single label.
294  
295 labels : list of str, optional
296 A list of labels to show next to the artists.
297 Use this together with *handles*, if you need full control on what
298 is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above
299 is not sufficient.
300  
301 Returns
302 -------
303 `~matplotlib.legend.Legend`
304  
305 Other Parameters
306 ----------------
307 %(_legend_kw_axes)s
308  
309 See Also
310 --------
311 .Figure.legend
312  
313 Notes
314 -----
315 Some artists are not supported by this function. See
316 :ref:`legend_guide` for details.
317  
318 Examples
319 --------
320 .. plot:: gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/legend.py
321 """
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
322 handles, labels, kwargs = mlegend._parse_legend_args([self], *args, **kwargs)
323 self.legend_ = mlegend.Legend(self, handles, labels, **kwargs)
324 self.legend_._remove_method = self._remove_legend
325 return self.legend_
326  
327 def _remove_legend(self, legend):
328 self.legend_ = None
329  
330 def inset_axes(self, bounds, *, transform=None, zorder=5, **kwargs):
331 """
332 Add a child inset Axes to this existing Axes.
333  
334 Warnings
335 --------
336 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change.
337  
338 Parameters
339 ----------
340 bounds : [x0, y0, width, height]
341 Lower-left corner of inset Axes, and its width and height.
342  
343 transform : `.Transform`
344 Defaults to `ax.transAxes`, i.e. the units of *rect* are in
345 Axes-relative coordinates.
346  
347 projection : {None, 'aitoff', 'hammer', 'lambert', 'mollweide', \
348 'polar', 'rectilinear', str}, optional
349 The projection type of the inset `~.axes.Axes`. *str* is the name
350 of a custom projection, see `~matplotlib.projections`. The default
351 None results in a 'rectilinear' projection.
352  
353 polar : bool, default: False
354 If True, equivalent to projection='polar'.
355  
356 axes_class : subclass type of `~.axes.Axes`, optional
357 The `.axes.Axes` subclass that is instantiated. This parameter
358 is incompatible with *projection* and *polar*. See
359 :ref:`axisartist_users-guide-index` for examples.
360  
361 zorder : number
362 Defaults to 5 (same as `.Axes.legend`). Adjust higher or lower
363 to change whether it is above or below data plotted on the
364 parent Axes.
365  
366 **kwargs
367 Other keyword arguments are passed on to the inset Axes class.
368  
369 Returns
370 -------
371 ax
372 The created `~.axes.Axes` instance.
373  
374 Examples
375 --------
376 This example makes two inset Axes, the first is in Axes-relative
377 coordinates, and the second in data-coordinates::
378  
379 fig, ax = plt.subplots()
380 ax.plot(range(10))
381 axin1 = ax.inset_axes([0.8, 0.1, 0.15, 0.15])
382 axin2 = ax.inset_axes(
383 [5, 7, 2.3, 2.3], transform=ax.transData)
384  
385 """
386 if transform is None:
387 transform = self.transAxes
388 kwargs.setdefault('label', 'inset_axes')
389  
390 # This puts the rectangle into figure-relative coordinates.
391 inset_locator = _TransformedBoundsLocator(bounds, transform)
392 bounds = inset_locator(self, None).bounds
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
393 projection_class, pkw = self.figure._process_projection_requirements(**kwargs)
394 inset_ax = projection_class(self.figure, bounds, zorder=zorder, **pkw)
395  
396 # this locator lets the axes move if in data coordinates.
397 # it gets called in `ax.apply_aspect() (of all places)
398 inset_ax.set_axes_locator(inset_locator)
399  
400 self.add_child_axes(inset_ax)
401  
402 return inset_ax
403  
404 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
405 def indicate_inset(self, bounds, inset_ax=None, *, transform=None,
406 facecolor='none', edgecolor='0.5', alpha=0.5,
407 zorder=4.99, **kwargs):
408 """
409 Add an inset indicator to the Axes. This is a rectangle on the plot
410 at the position indicated by *bounds* that optionally has lines that
411 connect the rectangle to an inset Axes (`.Axes.inset_axes`).
412  
413 Warnings
414 --------
415 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change.
416  
417 Parameters
418 ----------
419 bounds : [x0, y0, width, height]
420 Lower-left corner of rectangle to be marked, and its width
421 and height.
422  
423 inset_ax : `.Axes`
424 An optional inset Axes to draw connecting lines to. Two lines are
425 drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners
426 chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box.
427  
428 transform : `.Transform`
429 Transform for the rectangle coordinates. Defaults to
430 `ax.transAxes`, i.e. the units of *rect* are in Axes-relative
431 coordinates.
432  
433 facecolor : color, default: 'none'
434 Facecolor of the rectangle.
435  
436 edgecolor : color, default: '0.5'
437 Color of the rectangle and color of the connecting lines.
438  
439 alpha : float, default: 0.5
440 Transparency of the rectangle and connector lines.
441  
442 zorder : float, default: 4.99
443 Drawing order of the rectangle and connector lines. The default,
444 4.99, is just below the default level of inset Axes.
445  
446 **kwargs
447 Other keyword arguments are passed on to the `.Rectangle` patch:
448  
449 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s
450  
451 Returns
452 -------
453 rectangle_patch : `.patches.Rectangle`
454 The indicator frame.
455  
456 connector_lines : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch`
457 The four connector lines connecting to (lower_left, upper_left,
458 lower_right upper_right) corners of *inset_ax*. Two lines are
459 set with visibility to *False*, but the user can set the
460 visibility to True if the automatic choice is not deemed correct.
461  
462 """
463 # to make the axes connectors work, we need to apply the aspect to
464 # the parent axes.
465 self.apply_aspect()
466  
467 if transform is None:
468 transform = self.transData
469 kwargs.setdefault('label', '_indicate_inset')
470  
471 x, y, width, height = bounds
472 rectangle_patch = mpatches.Rectangle(
473 (x, y), width, height,
474 facecolor=facecolor, edgecolor=edgecolor, alpha=alpha,
475 zorder=zorder, transform=transform, **kwargs)
476 self.add_patch(rectangle_patch)
477  
478 connects = []
479  
480 if inset_ax is not None:
481 # connect the inset_axes to the rectangle
482 for xy_inset_ax in [(0, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 1)]:
483 # inset_ax positions are in axes coordinates
484 # The 0, 1 values define the four edges if the inset_ax
485 # lower_left, upper_left, lower_right upper_right.
486 ex, ey = xy_inset_ax
487 if self.xaxis.get_inverted():
488 ex = 1 - ex
489 if self.yaxis.get_inverted():
490 ey = 1 - ey
491 xy_data = x + ex * width, y + ey * height
492 p = mpatches.ConnectionPatch(
493 xyA=xy_inset_ax, coordsA=inset_ax.transAxes,
494 xyB=xy_data, coordsB=self.transData,
495 arrowstyle="-", zorder=zorder,
496 edgecolor=edgecolor, alpha=alpha)
497 connects.append(p)
498 self.add_patch(p)
499  
500 # decide which two of the lines to keep visible....
501 pos = inset_ax.get_position()
502 bboxins = pos.transformed(self.figure.transSubfigure)
503 rectbbox = mtransforms.Bbox.from_bounds(
504 *bounds
505 ).transformed(transform)
506 x0 = rectbbox.x0 < bboxins.x0
507 x1 = rectbbox.x1 < bboxins.x1
508 y0 = rectbbox.y0 < bboxins.y0
509 y1 = rectbbox.y1 < bboxins.y1
510 connects[0].set_visible(x0 ^ y0)
511 connects[1].set_visible(x0 == y1)
512 connects[2].set_visible(x1 == y0)
513 connects[3].set_visible(x1 ^ y1)
514  
515 return rectangle_patch, tuple(connects) if connects else None
516  
517 def indicate_inset_zoom(self, inset_ax, **kwargs):
518 """
519 Add an inset indicator rectangle to the Axes based on the axis
520 limits for an *inset_ax* and draw connectors between *inset_ax*
521 and the rectangle.
522  
523 Warnings
524 --------
525 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change.
526  
527 Parameters
528 ----------
529 inset_ax : `.Axes`
530 Inset Axes to draw connecting lines to. Two lines are
531 drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners
532 chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box.
533  
534 **kwargs
535 Other keyword arguments are passed on to `.Axes.indicate_inset`
536  
537 Returns
538 -------
539 rectangle_patch : `.patches.Rectangle`
540 Rectangle artist.
541  
542 connector_lines : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch`
543 Each of four connector lines coming from the rectangle drawn on
544 this axis, in the order lower left, upper left, lower right,
545 upper right.
546 Two are set with visibility to *False*, but the user can
547 set the visibility to *True* if the automatic choice is not deemed
548 correct.
549 """
550  
551 xlim = inset_ax.get_xlim()
552 ylim = inset_ax.get_ylim()
553 rect = (xlim[0], ylim[0], xlim[1] - xlim[0], ylim[1] - ylim[0])
554 return self.indicate_inset(rect, inset_ax, **kwargs)
555  
556 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
557 def secondary_xaxis(self, location, *, functions=None, **kwargs):
558 """
559 Add a second x-axis to this `~.axes.Axes`.
560  
561 For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on
562 the xaxis.
563  
564 %(_secax_docstring)s
565  
566 Examples
567 --------
568 The main axis shows frequency, and the secondary axis shows period.
569  
570 .. plot::
571  
572 fig, ax = plt.subplots()
573 ax.loglog(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5))
574 ax.set_xlabel('frequency [Hz]')
575  
576 def invert(x):
577 # 1/x with special treatment of x == 0
578 x = np.array(x).astype(float)
579 near_zero = np.isclose(x, 0)
580 x[near_zero] = np.inf
581 x[~near_zero] = 1 / x[~near_zero]
582 return x
583  
584 # the inverse of 1/x is itself
585 secax = ax.secondary_xaxis('top', functions=(invert, invert))
586 secax.set_xlabel('Period [s]')
587 plt.show()
588 """
589 if location in ['top', 'bottom'] or isinstance(location, Real):
590 secondary_ax = SecondaryAxis(self, 'x', location, functions,
591 **kwargs)
592 self.add_child_axes(secondary_ax)
593 return secondary_ax
594 else:
595 raise ValueError('secondary_xaxis location must be either '
596 'a float or "top"/"bottom"')
597  
598 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
599 def secondary_yaxis(self, location, *, functions=None, **kwargs):
600 """
601 Add a second y-axis to this `~.axes.Axes`.
602  
603 For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on
604 the yaxis.
605  
606 %(_secax_docstring)s
607  
608 Examples
609 --------
610 Add a secondary Axes that converts from radians to degrees
611  
612 .. plot::
613  
614 fig, ax = plt.subplots()
615 ax.plot(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5))
616 ax.set_ylabel('degrees')
617 secax = ax.secondary_yaxis('right', functions=(np.deg2rad,
618 np.rad2deg))
619 secax.set_ylabel('radians')
620 """
621 if location in ['left', 'right'] or isinstance(location, Real):
622 secondary_ax = SecondaryAxis(self, 'y', location,
623 functions, **kwargs)
624 self.add_child_axes(secondary_ax)
625 return secondary_ax
626 else:
627 raise ValueError('secondary_yaxis location must be either '
628 'a float or "left"/"right"')
629  
630 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
631 def text(self, x, y, s, fontdict=None, **kwargs):
632 """
633 Add text to the Axes.
634  
635 Add the text *s* to the Axes at location *x*, *y* in data coordinates,
636 with a default ``horizontalalignment`` on the ``left`` and
637 ``verticalalignment`` at the ``baseline``. See
638 :doc:`/gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/text_alignment`.
639  
640 Parameters
641 ----------
642 x, y : float
643 The position to place the text. By default, this is in data
644 coordinates. The coordinate system can be changed using the
645 *transform* parameter.
646  
647 s : str
648 The text.
649  
650 fontdict : dict, default: None
651  
652 .. admonition:: Discouraged
653  
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
654 The use of *fontdict* is discouraged. Parameters should be passed as
655 individual keyword arguments or using dictionary-unpacking
656 ``text(..., **fontdict)``.
657  
658 A dictionary to override the default text properties. If fontdict
659 is None, the defaults are determined by `.rcParams`.
660  
661 Returns
662 -------
663 `.Text`
664 The created `.Text` instance.
665  
666 Other Parameters
667 ----------------
668 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.text.Text` properties.
669 Other miscellaneous text parameters.
670  
671 %(Text:kwdoc)s
672  
673 Examples
674 --------
675 Individual keyword arguments can be used to override any given
676 parameter::
677  
678 >>> text(x, y, s, fontsize=12)
679  
680 The default transform specifies that text is in data coords,
681 alternatively, you can specify text in axis coords ((0, 0) is
682 lower-left and (1, 1) is upper-right). The example below places
683 text in the center of the Axes::
684  
685 >>> text(0.5, 0.5, 'matplotlib', horizontalalignment='center',
686 ... verticalalignment='center', transform=ax.transAxes)
687  
688 You can put a rectangular box around the text instance (e.g., to
689 set a background color) by using the keyword *bbox*. *bbox* is
690 a dictionary of `~matplotlib.patches.Rectangle`
691 properties. For example::
692  
693 >>> text(x, y, s, bbox=dict(facecolor='red', alpha=0.5))
694 """
695 effective_kwargs = {
696 'verticalalignment': 'baseline',
697 'horizontalalignment': 'left',
698 'transform': self.transData,
699 'clip_on': False,
700 **(fontdict if fontdict is not None else {}),
701 **kwargs,
702 }
703 t = mtext.Text(x, y, text=s, **effective_kwargs)
704 if t.get_clip_path() is None:
705 t.set_clip_path(self.patch)
706 self._add_text(t)
707 return t
708  
709 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
710 def annotate(self, text, xy, xytext=None, xycoords='data', textcoords=None,
711 arrowprops=None, annotation_clip=None, **kwargs):
712 # Signature must match Annotation. This is verified in
713 # test_annotate_signature().
714 a = mtext.Annotation(text, xy, xytext=xytext, xycoords=xycoords,
715 textcoords=textcoords, arrowprops=arrowprops,
716 annotation_clip=annotation_clip, **kwargs)
717 a.set_transform(mtransforms.IdentityTransform())
718 if kwargs.get('clip_on', False) and a.get_clip_path() is None:
719 a.set_clip_path(self.patch)
720 self._add_text(a)
721 return a
722 annotate.__doc__ = mtext.Annotation.__init__.__doc__
  • E266 Too many leading '#' for block comment
723 #### Lines and spans
724  
725 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
726 def axhline(self, y=0, xmin=0, xmax=1, **kwargs):
727 """
728 Add a horizontal line across the Axes.
729  
730 Parameters
731 ----------
732 y : float, default: 0
733 y position in data coordinates of the horizontal line.
734  
735 xmin : float, default: 0
736 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 1 the
737 far right of the plot.
738  
739 xmax : float, default: 1
740 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 1 the
741 far right of the plot.
742  
743 Returns
744 -------
745 `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
746  
747 Other Parameters
748 ----------------
749 **kwargs
750 Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, except for
751 'transform':
752  
753 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
754  
755 See Also
756 --------
757 hlines : Add horizontal lines in data coordinates.
758 axhspan : Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the axis.
759 axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope.
760  
761 Examples
762 --------
763 * draw a thick red hline at 'y' = 0 that spans the xrange::
764  
765 >>> axhline(linewidth=4, color='r')
766  
767 * draw a default hline at 'y' = 1 that spans the xrange::
768  
769 >>> axhline(y=1)
770  
771 * draw a default hline at 'y' = .5 that spans the middle half of
772 the xrange::
773  
774 >>> axhline(y=.5, xmin=0.25, xmax=0.75)
775 """
776 self._check_no_units([xmin, xmax], ['xmin', 'xmax'])
777 if "transform" in kwargs:
778 raise ValueError("'transform' is not allowed as a keyword "
779 "argument; axhline generates its own transform.")
780 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound()
781  
782 # Strip away the units for comparison with non-unitized bounds.
783 yy, = self._process_unit_info([("y", y)], kwargs)
784 scaley = (yy < ymin) or (yy > ymax)
785  
786 trans = self.get_yaxis_transform(which='grid')
  • E741 Ambiguous variable name 'l'
787 l = mlines.Line2D([xmin, xmax], [y, y], transform=trans, **kwargs)
788 self.add_line(l)
789 if scaley:
790 self._request_autoscale_view("y")
791 return l
792  
793 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
794 def axvline(self, x=0, ymin=0, ymax=1, **kwargs):
795 """
796 Add a vertical line across the Axes.
797  
798 Parameters
799 ----------
800 x : float, default: 0
801 x position in data coordinates of the vertical line.
802  
803 ymin : float, default: 0
804 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the
805 top of the plot.
806  
807 ymax : float, default: 1
808 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the
809 top of the plot.
810  
811 Returns
812 -------
813 `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D`
814  
815 Other Parameters
816 ----------------
817 **kwargs
818 Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, except for
819 'transform':
820  
821 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
822  
823 See Also
824 --------
825 vlines : Add vertical lines in data coordinates.
826 axvspan : Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the axis.
827 axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope.
828  
829 Examples
830 --------
831 * draw a thick red vline at *x* = 0 that spans the yrange::
832  
833 >>> axvline(linewidth=4, color='r')
834  
835 * draw a default vline at *x* = 1 that spans the yrange::
836  
837 >>> axvline(x=1)
838  
839 * draw a default vline at *x* = .5 that spans the middle half of
840 the yrange::
841  
842 >>> axvline(x=.5, ymin=0.25, ymax=0.75)
843 """
844 self._check_no_units([ymin, ymax], ['ymin', 'ymax'])
845 if "transform" in kwargs:
846 raise ValueError("'transform' is not allowed as a keyword "
847 "argument; axvline generates its own transform.")
848 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound()
849  
850 # Strip away the units for comparison with non-unitized bounds.
851 xx, = self._process_unit_info([("x", x)], kwargs)
852 scalex = (xx < xmin) or (xx > xmax)
853  
854 trans = self.get_xaxis_transform(which='grid')
  • E741 Ambiguous variable name 'l'
855 l = mlines.Line2D([x, x], [ymin, ymax], transform=trans, **kwargs)
856 self.add_line(l)
857 if scalex:
858 self._request_autoscale_view("x")
859 return l
860  
861 @staticmethod
862 def _check_no_units(vals, names):
863 # Helper method to check that vals are not unitized
864 for val, name in zip(vals, names):
865 if not munits._is_natively_supported(val):
866 raise ValueError(f"{name} must be a single scalar value, "
867 f"but got {val}")
868  
869 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
870 def axline(self, xy1, xy2=None, *, slope=None, **kwargs):
871 """
872 Add an infinitely long straight line.
873  
874 The line can be defined either by two points *xy1* and *xy2*, or
875 by one point *xy1* and a *slope*.
876  
877 This draws a straight line "on the screen", regardless of the x and y
878 scales, and is thus also suitable for drawing exponential decays in
879 semilog plots, power laws in loglog plots, etc. However, *slope*
880 should only be used with linear scales; It has no clear meaning for
881 all other scales, and thus the behavior is undefined. Please specify
882 the line using the points *xy1*, *xy2* for non-linear scales.
883  
884 The *transform* keyword argument only applies to the points *xy1*,
885 *xy2*. The *slope* (if given) is always in data coordinates. This can
886 be used e.g. with ``ax.transAxes`` for drawing grid lines with a fixed
887 slope.
888  
889 Parameters
890 ----------
891 xy1, xy2 : (float, float)
892 Points for the line to pass through.
893 Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given.
894 slope : float, optional
895 The slope of the line. Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given.
896  
897 Returns
898 -------
899 `.AxLine`
900  
901 Other Parameters
902 ----------------
903 **kwargs
904 Valid kwargs are `.Line2D` properties
905  
906 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
907  
908 See Also
909 --------
910 axhline : for horizontal lines
911 axvline : for vertical lines
912  
913 Examples
914 --------
915 Draw a thick red line passing through (0, 0) and (1, 1)::
916  
917 >>> axline((0, 0), (1, 1), linewidth=4, color='r')
918 """
919 if slope is not None and (self.get_xscale() != 'linear' or
920 self.get_yscale() != 'linear'):
921 raise TypeError("'slope' cannot be used with non-linear scales")
922  
923 datalim = [xy1] if xy2 is None else [xy1, xy2]
924 if "transform" in kwargs:
925 # if a transform is passed (i.e. line points not in data space),
926 # data limits should not be adjusted.
927 datalim = []
928  
929 line = mlines.AxLine(xy1, xy2, slope, **kwargs)
930 # Like add_line, but correctly handling data limits.
931 self._set_artist_props(line)
932 if line.get_clip_path() is None:
933 line.set_clip_path(self.patch)
934 if not line.get_label():
935 line.set_label(f"_child{len(self._children)}")
936 self._children.append(line)
937 line._remove_method = self._children.remove
938 self.update_datalim(datalim)
939  
940 self._request_autoscale_view()
941 return line
942  
943 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
944 def axhspan(self, ymin, ymax, xmin=0, xmax=1, **kwargs):
945 """
946 Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the Axes.
947  
948 The rectangle spans from *ymin* to *ymax* vertically, and, by default,
949 the whole x-axis horizontally. The x-span can be set using *xmin*
950 (default: 0) and *xmax* (default: 1) which are in axis units; e.g.
951 ``xmin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the x-axis regardless of
952 the limits set by `~.Axes.set_xlim`.
953  
954 Parameters
955 ----------
956 ymin : float
957 Lower y-coordinate of the span, in data units.
958 ymax : float
959 Upper y-coordinate of the span, in data units.
960 xmin : float, default: 0
961 Lower x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units.
962 xmax : float, default: 1
963 Upper x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units.
964  
965 Returns
966 -------
967 `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon`
968 Horizontal span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax).
969  
970 Other Parameters
971 ----------------
972 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` properties
973  
974 %(Polygon:kwdoc)s
975  
976 See Also
977 --------
978 axvspan : Add a vertical span across the Axes.
979 """
980 # Strip units away.
981 self._check_no_units([xmin, xmax], ['xmin', 'xmax'])
982 (ymin, ymax), = self._process_unit_info([("y", [ymin, ymax])], kwargs)
983  
984 verts = (xmin, ymin), (xmin, ymax), (xmax, ymax), (xmax, ymin)
985 p = mpatches.Polygon(verts, **kwargs)
986 p.set_transform(self.get_yaxis_transform(which="grid"))
987 self.add_patch(p)
988 self._request_autoscale_view("y")
989 return p
990  
991 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
992 def axvspan(self, xmin, xmax, ymin=0, ymax=1, **kwargs):
993 """
994 Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the Axes.
995  
996 The rectangle spans from *xmin* to *xmax* horizontally, and, by
997 default, the whole y-axis vertically. The y-span can be set using
998 *ymin* (default: 0) and *ymax* (default: 1) which are in axis units;
999 e.g. ``ymin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the y-axis
1000 regardless of the limits set by `~.Axes.set_ylim`.
1001  
1002 Parameters
1003 ----------
1004 xmin : float
1005 Lower x-coordinate of the span, in data units.
1006 xmax : float
1007 Upper x-coordinate of the span, in data units.
1008 ymin : float, default: 0
1009 Lower y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1).
1010 ymax : float, default: 1
1011 Upper y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1).
1012  
1013 Returns
1014 -------
1015 `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon`
1016 Vertical span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax).
1017  
1018 Other Parameters
1019 ----------------
1020 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` properties
1021  
1022 %(Polygon:kwdoc)s
1023  
1024 See Also
1025 --------
1026 axhspan : Add a horizontal span across the Axes.
1027  
1028 Examples
1029 --------
1030 Draw a vertical, green, translucent rectangle from x = 1.25 to
1031 x = 1.55 that spans the yrange of the Axes.
1032  
1033 >>> axvspan(1.25, 1.55, facecolor='g', alpha=0.5)
1034  
1035 """
1036 # Strip units away.
1037 self._check_no_units([ymin, ymax], ['ymin', 'ymax'])
1038 (xmin, xmax), = self._process_unit_info([("x", [xmin, xmax])], kwargs)
1039  
1040 verts = [(xmin, ymin), (xmin, ymax), (xmax, ymax), (xmax, ymin)]
1041 p = mpatches.Polygon(verts, **kwargs)
1042 p.set_transform(self.get_xaxis_transform(which="grid"))
1043 p.get_path()._interpolation_steps = 100
1044 self.add_patch(p)
1045 self._request_autoscale_view("x")
1046 return p
1047  
1048 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["y", "xmin", "xmax", "colors"],
1049 label_namer="y")
1050 def hlines(self, y, xmin, xmax, colors=None, linestyles='solid',
1051 label='', **kwargs):
1052 """
1053 Plot horizontal lines at each *y* from *xmin* to *xmax*.
1054  
1055 Parameters
1056 ----------
1057 y : float or array-like
1058 y-indexes where to plot the lines.
1059  
1060 xmin, xmax : float or array-like
1061 Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are
1062 provided, all lines will have the same length.
1063  
1064 colors : color or list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color`
1065  
1066 linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, default: 'solid'
1067  
1068 label : str, default: ''
1069  
1070 Returns
1071 -------
1072 `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection`
1073  
1074 Other Parameters
1075 ----------------
1076 data : indexable object, optional
1077 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
1078 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties.
1079  
1080 See Also
1081 --------
1082 vlines : vertical lines
1083 axhline : horizontal line across the Axes
1084 """
1085  
1086 # We do the conversion first since not all unitized data is uniform
1087 xmin, xmax, y = self._process_unit_info(
1088 [("x", xmin), ("x", xmax), ("y", y)], kwargs)
1089  
1090 if not np.iterable(y):
1091 y = [y]
1092 if not np.iterable(xmin):
1093 xmin = [xmin]
1094 if not np.iterable(xmax):
1095 xmax = [xmax]
1096  
1097 # Create and combine masked_arrays from input
1098 y, xmin, xmax = cbook._combine_masks(y, xmin, xmax)
1099 y = np.ravel(y)
1100 xmin = np.ravel(xmin)
1101 xmax = np.ravel(xmax)
1102  
1103 masked_verts = np.ma.empty((len(y), 2, 2))
1104 masked_verts[:, 0, 0] = xmin
1105 masked_verts[:, 0, 1] = y
1106 masked_verts[:, 1, 0] = xmax
1107 masked_verts[:, 1, 1] = y
1108  
1109 lines = mcoll.LineCollection(masked_verts, colors=colors,
1110 linestyles=linestyles, label=label)
1111 self.add_collection(lines, autolim=False)
1112 lines._internal_update(kwargs)
1113  
1114 if len(y) > 0:
1115 # Extreme values of xmin/xmax/y. Using masked_verts here handles
1116 # the case of y being a masked *object* array (as can be generated
1117 # e.g. by errorbar()), which would make nanmin/nanmax stumble.
1118 updatex = True
1119 updatey = True
1120 if self.name == "rectilinear":
1121 datalim = lines.get_datalim(self.transData)
1122 t = lines.get_transform()
1123 updatex, updatey = t.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)
1124 minx = np.nanmin(datalim.xmin)
1125 maxx = np.nanmax(datalim.xmax)
1126 miny = np.nanmin(datalim.ymin)
1127 maxy = np.nanmax(datalim.ymax)
1128 else:
1129 minx = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 0])
1130 maxx = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 0])
1131 miny = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 1])
1132 maxy = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 1])
1133  
1134 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy)
1135 self.update_datalim(corners, updatex, updatey)
1136 self._request_autoscale_view()
1137 return lines
1138  
1139 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "ymin", "ymax", "colors"],
1140 label_namer="x")
1141 def vlines(self, x, ymin, ymax, colors=None, linestyles='solid',
1142 label='', **kwargs):
1143 """
1144 Plot vertical lines at each *x* from *ymin* to *ymax*.
1145  
1146 Parameters
1147 ----------
1148 x : float or array-like
1149 x-indexes where to plot the lines.
1150  
1151 ymin, ymax : float or array-like
1152 Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are
1153 provided, all lines will have the same length.
1154  
1155 colors : color or list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color`
1156  
1157 linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, default: 'solid'
1158  
1159 label : str, default: ''
1160  
1161 Returns
1162 -------
1163 `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection`
1164  
1165 Other Parameters
1166 ----------------
1167 data : indexable object, optional
1168 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
1169 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties.
1170  
1171 See Also
1172 --------
1173 hlines : horizontal lines
1174 axvline : vertical line across the Axes
1175 """
1176  
1177 # We do the conversion first since not all unitized data is uniform
1178 x, ymin, ymax = self._process_unit_info(
1179 [("x", x), ("y", ymin), ("y", ymax)], kwargs)
1180  
1181 if not np.iterable(x):
1182 x = [x]
1183 if not np.iterable(ymin):
1184 ymin = [ymin]
1185 if not np.iterable(ymax):
1186 ymax = [ymax]
1187  
1188 # Create and combine masked_arrays from input
1189 x, ymin, ymax = cbook._combine_masks(x, ymin, ymax)
1190 x = np.ravel(x)
1191 ymin = np.ravel(ymin)
1192 ymax = np.ravel(ymax)
1193  
1194 masked_verts = np.ma.empty((len(x), 2, 2))
1195 masked_verts[:, 0, 0] = x
1196 masked_verts[:, 0, 1] = ymin
1197 masked_verts[:, 1, 0] = x
1198 masked_verts[:, 1, 1] = ymax
1199  
1200 lines = mcoll.LineCollection(masked_verts, colors=colors,
1201 linestyles=linestyles, label=label)
1202 self.add_collection(lines, autolim=False)
1203 lines._internal_update(kwargs)
1204  
1205 if len(x) > 0:
1206 # Extreme values of x/ymin/ymax. Using masked_verts here handles
1207 # the case of x being a masked *object* array (as can be generated
1208 # e.g. by errorbar()), which would make nanmin/nanmax stumble.
1209 updatex = True
1210 updatey = True
1211 if self.name == "rectilinear":
1212 datalim = lines.get_datalim(self.transData)
1213 t = lines.get_transform()
1214 updatex, updatey = t.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)
1215 minx = np.nanmin(datalim.xmin)
1216 maxx = np.nanmax(datalim.xmax)
1217 miny = np.nanmin(datalim.ymin)
1218 maxy = np.nanmax(datalim.ymax)
1219 else:
1220 minx = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 0])
1221 maxx = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 0])
1222 miny = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 1])
1223 maxy = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 1])
1224  
1225 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy)
1226 self.update_datalim(corners, updatex, updatey)
1227 self._request_autoscale_view()
1228 return lines
1229  
1230 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["positions", "lineoffsets",
1231 "linelengths", "linewidths",
1232 "colors", "linestyles"])
1233 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1234 def eventplot(self, positions, orientation='horizontal', lineoffsets=1,
1235 linelengths=1, linewidths=None, colors=None, alpha=None,
1236 linestyles='solid', **kwargs):
1237 """
1238 Plot identical parallel lines at the given positions.
1239  
1240 This type of plot is commonly used in neuroscience for representing
1241 neural events, where it is usually called a spike raster, dot raster,
1242 or raster plot.
1243  
1244 However, it is useful in any situation where you wish to show the
1245 timing or position of multiple sets of discrete events, such as the
1246 arrival times of people to a business on each day of the month or the
1247 date of hurricanes each year of the last century.
1248  
1249 Parameters
1250 ----------
1251 positions : array-like or list of array-like
1252 A 1D array-like defines the positions of one sequence of events.
1253  
1254 Multiple groups of events may be passed as a list of array-likes.
1255 Each group can be styled independently by passing lists of values
1256 to *lineoffsets*, *linelengths*, *linewidths*, *colors* and
1257 *linestyles*.
1258  
1259 Note that *positions* can be a 2D array, but in practice different
1260 event groups usually have different counts so that one will use a
1261 list of different-length arrays rather than a 2D array.
1262  
1263 orientation : {'horizontal', 'vertical'}, default: 'horizontal'
1264 The direction of the event sequence:
1265  
1266 - 'horizontal': the events are arranged horizontally.
1267 The indicator lines are vertical.
1268 - 'vertical': the events are arranged vertically.
1269 The indicator lines are horizontal.
1270  
1271 lineoffsets : float or array-like, default: 1
1272 The offset of the center of the lines from the origin, in the
1273 direction orthogonal to *orientation*.
1274  
1275 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching
1276 the length of *positions*.
1277  
1278 linelengths : float or array-like, default: 1
1279 The total height of the lines (i.e. the lines stretches from
1280 ``lineoffset - linelength/2`` to ``lineoffset + linelength/2``).
1281  
1282 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching
1283 the length of *positions*.
1284  
1285 linewidths : float or array-like, default: :rc:`lines.linewidth`
1286 The line width(s) of the event lines, in points.
1287  
1288 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching
1289 the length of *positions*.
1290  
1291 colors : color or list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color`
1292 The color(s) of the event lines.
1293  
1294 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching
1295 the length of *positions*.
1296  
1297 alpha : float or array-like, default: 1
1298 The alpha blending value(s), between 0 (transparent) and 1
1299 (opaque).
1300  
1301 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching
1302 the length of *positions*.
1303  
1304 linestyles : str or tuple or list of such values, default: 'solid'
1305 Default is 'solid'. Valid strings are ['solid', 'dashed',
1306 'dashdot', 'dotted', '-', '--', '-.', ':']. Dash tuples
1307 should be of the form::
1308  
1309 (offset, onoffseq),
1310  
1311 where *onoffseq* is an even length tuple of on and off ink
1312 in points.
1313  
1314 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching
1315 the length of *positions*.
1316  
1317 data : indexable object, optional
1318 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
1319  
1320 **kwargs
1321 Other keyword arguments are line collection properties. See
1322 `.LineCollection` for a list of the valid properties.
1323  
1324 Returns
1325 -------
1326 list of `.EventCollection`
1327 The `.EventCollection` that were added.
1328  
1329 Notes
1330 -----
1331 For *linelengths*, *linewidths*, *colors*, *alpha* and *linestyles*, if
1332 only a single value is given, that value is applied to all lines. If an
1333 array-like is given, it must have the same length as *positions*, and
1334 each value will be applied to the corresponding row of the array.
1335  
1336 Examples
1337 --------
1338 .. plot:: gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/eventplot_demo.py
1339 """
1340  
1341 lineoffsets, linelengths = self._process_unit_info(
1342 [("y", lineoffsets), ("y", linelengths)], kwargs)
1343  
1344 # fix positions, noting that it can be a list of lists:
1345 if not np.iterable(positions):
1346 positions = [positions]
1347 elif any(np.iterable(position) for position in positions):
1348 positions = [np.asanyarray(position) for position in positions]
1349 else:
1350 positions = [np.asanyarray(positions)]
1351  
1352 poss = []
1353 for position in positions:
1354 poss += self._process_unit_info([("x", position)], kwargs)
1355 positions = poss
1356  
1357 # prevent 'singular' keys from **kwargs dict from overriding the effect
1358 # of 'plural' keyword arguments (e.g. 'color' overriding 'colors')
1359 colors = cbook._local_over_kwdict(colors, kwargs, 'color')
1360 linewidths = cbook._local_over_kwdict(linewidths, kwargs, 'linewidth')
1361 linestyles = cbook._local_over_kwdict(linestyles, kwargs, 'linestyle')
1362  
1363 if not np.iterable(lineoffsets):
1364 lineoffsets = [lineoffsets]
1365 if not np.iterable(linelengths):
1366 linelengths = [linelengths]
1367 if not np.iterable(linewidths):
1368 linewidths = [linewidths]
1369 if not np.iterable(colors):
1370 colors = [colors]
1371 if not np.iterable(alpha):
1372 alpha = [alpha]
1373 if hasattr(linestyles, 'lower') or not np.iterable(linestyles):
1374 linestyles = [linestyles]
1375  
1376 lineoffsets = np.asarray(lineoffsets)
1377 linelengths = np.asarray(linelengths)
1378 linewidths = np.asarray(linewidths)
1379  
1380 if len(lineoffsets) == 0:
1381 raise ValueError('lineoffsets cannot be empty')
1382 if len(linelengths) == 0:
1383 raise ValueError('linelengths cannot be empty')
1384 if len(linestyles) == 0:
1385 raise ValueError('linestyles cannot be empty')
1386 if len(linewidths) == 0:
1387 raise ValueError('linewidths cannot be empty')
1388 if len(alpha) == 0:
1389 raise ValueError('alpha cannot be empty')
1390 if len(colors) == 0:
1391 colors = [None]
1392 try:
1393 # Early conversion of the colors into RGBA values to take care
1394 # of cases like colors='0.5' or colors='C1'. (Issue #8193)
1395 colors = mcolors.to_rgba_array(colors)
1396 except ValueError:
1397 # Will fail if any element of *colors* is None. But as long
1398 # as len(colors) == 1 or len(positions), the rest of the
1399 # code should process *colors* properly.
1400 pass
1401  
1402 if len(lineoffsets) == 1 and len(positions) != 1:
1403 lineoffsets = np.tile(lineoffsets, len(positions))
1404 lineoffsets[0] = 0
1405 lineoffsets = np.cumsum(lineoffsets)
1406 if len(linelengths) == 1:
1407 linelengths = np.tile(linelengths, len(positions))
1408 if len(linewidths) == 1:
1409 linewidths = np.tile(linewidths, len(positions))
1410 if len(colors) == 1:
1411 colors = list(colors) * len(positions)
1412 if len(alpha) == 1:
1413 alpha = list(alpha) * len(positions)
1414 if len(linestyles) == 1:
1415 linestyles = [linestyles] * len(positions)
1416  
1417 if len(lineoffsets) != len(positions):
1418 raise ValueError('lineoffsets and positions are unequal sized '
1419 'sequences')
1420 if len(linelengths) != len(positions):
1421 raise ValueError('linelengths and positions are unequal sized '
1422 'sequences')
1423 if len(linewidths) != len(positions):
1424 raise ValueError('linewidths and positions are unequal sized '
1425 'sequences')
1426 if len(colors) != len(positions):
1427 raise ValueError('colors and positions are unequal sized '
1428 'sequences')
1429 if len(alpha) != len(positions):
1430 raise ValueError('alpha and positions are unequal sized '
1431 'sequences')
1432 if len(linestyles) != len(positions):
1433 raise ValueError('linestyles and positions are unequal sized '
1434 'sequences')
1435  
1436 colls = []
1437 for position, lineoffset, linelength, linewidth, color, alpha_, \
1438 linestyle in \
1439 zip(positions, lineoffsets, linelengths, linewidths,
1440 colors, alpha, linestyles):
1441 coll = mcoll.EventCollection(position,
1442 orientation=orientation,
1443 lineoffset=lineoffset,
1444 linelength=linelength,
1445 linewidth=linewidth,
1446 color=color,
1447 alpha=alpha_,
1448 linestyle=linestyle)
1449 self.add_collection(coll, autolim=False)
1450 coll._internal_update(kwargs)
1451 colls.append(coll)
1452  
1453 if len(positions) > 0:
1454 # try to get min/max
1455 min_max = [(np.min(_p), np.max(_p)) for _p in positions
1456 if len(_p) > 0]
1457 # if we have any non-empty positions, try to autoscale
1458 if len(min_max) > 0:
1459 mins, maxes = zip(*min_max)
1460 minpos = np.min(mins)
1461 maxpos = np.max(maxes)
1462  
1463 minline = (lineoffsets - linelengths).min()
1464 maxline = (lineoffsets + linelengths).max()
1465  
1466 if orientation == "vertical":
1467 corners = (minline, minpos), (maxline, maxpos)
1468 else: # "horizontal"
1469 corners = (minpos, minline), (maxpos, maxline)
1470 self.update_datalim(corners)
1471 self._request_autoscale_view()
1472  
1473 return colls
1474  
  • E266 Too many leading '#' for block comment
1475 #### Basic plotting
1476  
1477 # Uses a custom implementation of data-kwarg handling in
1478 # _process_plot_var_args.
1479 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1480 def plot(self, *args, scalex=True, scaley=True, data=None, **kwargs):
1481 """
1482 Plot y versus x as lines and/or markers.
1483  
1484 Call signatures::
1485  
1486 plot([x], y, [fmt], *, data=None, **kwargs)
1487 plot([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)
1488  
1489 The coordinates of the points or line nodes are given by *x*, *y*.
1490  
1491 The optional parameter *fmt* is a convenient way for defining basic
1492 formatting like color, marker and linestyle. It's a shortcut string
1493 notation described in the *Notes* section below.
1494  
1495 >>> plot(x, y) # plot x and y using default line style and color
1496 >>> plot(x, y, 'bo') # plot x and y using blue circle markers
1497 >>> plot(y) # plot y using x as index array 0..N-1
1498 >>> plot(y, 'r+') # ditto, but with red plusses
1499  
1500 You can use `.Line2D` properties as keyword arguments for more
1501 control on the appearance. Line properties and *fmt* can be mixed.
1502 The following two calls yield identical results:
1503  
1504 >>> plot(x, y, 'go--', linewidth=2, markersize=12)
1505 >>> plot(x, y, color='green', marker='o', linestyle='dashed',
1506 ... linewidth=2, markersize=12)
1507  
1508 When conflicting with *fmt*, keyword arguments take precedence.
1509  
1510  
1511 **Plotting labelled data**
1512  
1513 There's a convenient way for plotting objects with labelled data (i.e.
1514 data that can be accessed by index ``obj['y']``). Instead of giving
1515 the data in *x* and *y*, you can provide the object in the *data*
1516 parameter and just give the labels for *x* and *y*::
1517  
1518 >>> plot('xlabel', 'ylabel', data=obj)
1519  
1520 All indexable objects are supported. This could e.g. be a `dict`, a
1521 `pandas.DataFrame` or a structured numpy array.
1522  
1523  
1524 **Plotting multiple sets of data**
1525  
1526 There are various ways to plot multiple sets of data.
1527  
1528 - The most straight forward way is just to call `plot` multiple times.
1529 Example:
1530  
1531 >>> plot(x1, y1, 'bo')
1532 >>> plot(x2, y2, 'go')
1533  
1534 - If *x* and/or *y* are 2D arrays a separate data set will be drawn
1535 for every column. If both *x* and *y* are 2D, they must have the
1536 same shape. If only one of them is 2D with shape (N, m) the other
1537 must have length N and will be used for every data set m.
1538  
1539 Example:
1540  
1541 >>> x = [1, 2, 3]
1542 >>> y = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6]])
1543 >>> plot(x, y)
1544  
1545 is equivalent to:
1546  
1547 >>> for col in range(y.shape[1]):
1548 ... plot(x, y[:, col])
1549  
1550 - The third way is to specify multiple sets of *[x]*, *y*, *[fmt]*
1551 groups::
1552  
1553 >>> plot(x1, y1, 'g^', x2, y2, 'g-')
1554  
1555 In this case, any additional keyword argument applies to all
1556 datasets. Also, this syntax cannot be combined with the *data*
1557 parameter.
1558  
1559 By default, each line is assigned a different style specified by a
1560 'style cycle'. The *fmt* and line property parameters are only
1561 necessary if you want explicit deviations from these defaults.
1562 Alternatively, you can also change the style cycle using
1563 :rc:`axes.prop_cycle`.
1564  
1565  
1566 Parameters
1567 ----------
1568 x, y : array-like or scalar
1569 The horizontal / vertical coordinates of the data points.
1570 *x* values are optional and default to ``range(len(y))``.
1571  
1572 Commonly, these parameters are 1D arrays.
1573  
1574 They can also be scalars, or two-dimensional (in that case, the
1575 columns represent separate data sets).
1576  
1577 These arguments cannot be passed as keywords.
1578  
1579 fmt : str, optional
1580 A format string, e.g. 'ro' for red circles. See the *Notes*
1581 section for a full description of the format strings.
1582  
1583 Format strings are just an abbreviation for quickly setting
1584 basic line properties. All of these and more can also be
1585 controlled by keyword arguments.
1586  
1587 This argument cannot be passed as keyword.
1588  
1589 data : indexable object, optional
1590 An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to
1591 plot in *x* and *y*.
1592  
1593 .. note::
1594 Technically there's a slight ambiguity in calls where the
1595 second label is a valid *fmt*. ``plot('n', 'o', data=obj)``
1596 could be ``plt(x, y)`` or ``plt(y, fmt)``. In such cases,
1597 the former interpretation is chosen, but a warning is issued.
1598 You may suppress the warning by adding an empty format string
1599 ``plot('n', 'o', '', data=obj)``.
1600  
1601 Returns
1602 -------
1603 list of `.Line2D`
1604 A list of lines representing the plotted data.
1605  
1606 Other Parameters
1607 ----------------
1608 scalex, scaley : bool, default: True
1609 These parameters determine if the view limits are adapted to the
1610 data limits. The values are passed on to
1611 `~.axes.Axes.autoscale_view`.
1612  
1613 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` properties, optional
1614 *kwargs* are used to specify properties like a line label (for
1615 auto legends), linewidth, antialiasing, marker face color.
1616 Example::
1617  
1618 >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 2, 3], 'go-', label='line 1', linewidth=2)
1619 >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 4, 9], 'rs', label='line 2')
1620  
1621 If you specify multiple lines with one plot call, the kwargs apply
1622 to all those lines. In case the label object is iterable, each
1623 element is used as labels for each set of data.
1624  
1625 Here is a list of available `.Line2D` properties:
1626  
1627 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
1628  
1629 See Also
1630 --------
1631 scatter : XY scatter plot with markers of varying size and/or color (
1632 sometimes also called bubble chart).
1633  
1634 Notes
1635 -----
1636 **Format Strings**
1637  
1638 A format string consists of a part for color, marker and line::
1639  
1640 fmt = '[marker][line][color]'
1641  
1642 Each of them is optional. If not provided, the value from the style
1643 cycle is used. Exception: If ``line`` is given, but no ``marker``,
1644 the data will be a line without markers.
1645  
1646 Other combinations such as ``[color][marker][line]`` are also
1647 supported, but note that their parsing may be ambiguous.
1648  
1649 **Markers**
1650  
1651 ============= ===============================
1652 character description
1653 ============= ===============================
1654 ``'.'`` point marker
1655 ``','`` pixel marker
1656 ``'o'`` circle marker
1657 ``'v'`` triangle_down marker
1658 ``'^'`` triangle_up marker
1659 ``'<'`` triangle_left marker
1660 ``'>'`` triangle_right marker
1661 ``'1'`` tri_down marker
1662 ``'2'`` tri_up marker
1663 ``'3'`` tri_left marker
1664 ``'4'`` tri_right marker
1665 ``'8'`` octagon marker
1666 ``'s'`` square marker
1667 ``'p'`` pentagon marker
1668 ``'P'`` plus (filled) marker
1669 ``'*'`` star marker
1670 ``'h'`` hexagon1 marker
1671 ``'H'`` hexagon2 marker
1672 ``'+'`` plus marker
1673 ``'x'`` x marker
1674 ``'X'`` x (filled) marker
1675 ``'D'`` diamond marker
1676 ``'d'`` thin_diamond marker
1677 ``'|'`` vline marker
1678 ``'_'`` hline marker
1679 ============= ===============================
1680  
1681 **Line Styles**
1682  
1683 ============= ===============================
1684 character description
1685 ============= ===============================
1686 ``'-'`` solid line style
1687 ``'--'`` dashed line style
1688 ``'-.'`` dash-dot line style
1689 ``':'`` dotted line style
1690 ============= ===============================
1691  
1692 Example format strings::
1693  
1694 'b' # blue markers with default shape
1695 'or' # red circles
1696 '-g' # green solid line
1697 '--' # dashed line with default color
1698 '^k:' # black triangle_up markers connected by a dotted line
1699  
1700 **Colors**
1701  
1702 The supported color abbreviations are the single letter codes
1703  
1704 ============= ===============================
1705 character color
1706 ============= ===============================
1707 ``'b'`` blue
1708 ``'g'`` green
1709 ``'r'`` red
1710 ``'c'`` cyan
1711 ``'m'`` magenta
1712 ``'y'`` yellow
1713 ``'k'`` black
1714 ``'w'`` white
1715 ============= ===============================
1716  
1717 and the ``'CN'`` colors that index into the default property cycle.
1718  
1719 If the color is the only part of the format string, you can
1720 additionally use any `matplotlib.colors` spec, e.g. full names
1721 (``'green'``) or hex strings (``'#008000'``).
1722 """
1723 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mlines.Line2D)
1724 lines = [*self._get_lines(self, *args, data=data, **kwargs)]
1725 for line in lines:
1726 self.add_line(line)
1727 if scalex:
1728 self._request_autoscale_view("x")
1729 if scaley:
1730 self._request_autoscale_view("y")
1731 return lines
1732  
1733 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"], label_namer="y")
1734 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1735 def plot_date(self, x, y, fmt='o', tz=None, xdate=True, ydate=False,
1736 **kwargs):
1737 """
1738 [*Discouraged*] Plot coercing the axis to treat floats as dates.
1739  
1740 .. admonition:: Discouraged
1741  
1742 This method exists for historic reasons and will be deprecated in
1743 the future.
1744  
1745 - ``datetime``-like data should directly be plotted using
1746 `~.Axes.plot`.
1747 - If you need to plot plain numeric data as :ref:`date-format` or
1748 need to set a timezone, call ``ax.xaxis.axis_date`` /
1749 ``ax.yaxis.axis_date`` before `~.Axes.plot`. See
1750 `.Axis.axis_date`.
1751  
1752 Similar to `.plot`, this plots *y* vs. *x* as lines or markers.
1753 However, the axis labels are formatted as dates depending on *xdate*
1754 and *ydate*. Note that `.plot` will work with `datetime` and
1755 `numpy.datetime64` objects without resorting to this method.
1756  
1757 Parameters
1758 ----------
1759 x, y : array-like
1760 The coordinates of the data points. If *xdate* or *ydate* is
1761 *True*, the respective values *x* or *y* are interpreted as
1762 :ref:`Matplotlib dates <date-format>`.
1763  
1764 fmt : str, optional
1765 The plot format string. For details, see the corresponding
1766 parameter in `.plot`.
1767  
1768 tz : timezone string or `datetime.tzinfo`, default: :rc:`timezone`
1769 The time zone to use in labeling dates.
1770  
1771 xdate : bool, default: True
1772 If *True*, the *x*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates.
1773  
1774 ydate : bool, default: False
1775 If *True*, the *y*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates.
1776  
1777 Returns
1778 -------
1779 list of `.Line2D`
1780 Objects representing the plotted data.
1781  
1782 Other Parameters
1783 ----------------
1784 data : indexable object, optional
1785 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
1786 **kwargs
1787 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties:
1788  
1789 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
1790  
1791 See Also
1792 --------
1793 matplotlib.dates : Helper functions on dates.
1794 matplotlib.dates.date2num : Convert dates to num.
1795 matplotlib.dates.num2date : Convert num to dates.
1796 matplotlib.dates.drange : Create an equally spaced sequence of dates.
1797  
1798 Notes
1799 -----
1800 If you are using custom date tickers and formatters, it may be
1801 necessary to set the formatters/locators after the call to
1802 `.plot_date`. `.plot_date` will set the default tick locator to
1803 `.AutoDateLocator` (if the tick locator is not already set to a
1804 `.DateLocator` instance) and the default tick formatter to
1805 `.AutoDateFormatter` (if the tick formatter is not already set to a
1806 `.DateFormatter` instance).
1807 """
1808 if xdate:
1809 self.xaxis_date(tz)
1810 if ydate:
1811 self.yaxis_date(tz)
1812 return self.plot(x, y, fmt, **kwargs)
1813  
1814 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking..
1815 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1816 def loglog(self, *args, **kwargs):
1817 """
1818 Make a plot with log scaling on both the x- and y-axis.
1819  
1820 Call signatures::
1821  
1822 loglog([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs)
1823 loglog([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)
1824  
1825 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes
1826 both the x-axis and the y-axis to log scaling. All the concepts and
1827 parameters of plot can be used here as well.
1828  
1829 The additional parameters *base*, *subs* and *nonpositive* control the
1830 x/y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale` and
1831 `.Axes.set_yscale`. To use different properties on the x-axis and the
1832 y-axis, use e.g.
1833 ``ax.set_xscale("log", base=10); ax.set_yscale("log", base=2)``.
1834  
1835 Parameters
1836 ----------
1837 base : float, default: 10
1838 Base of the logarithm.
1839  
1840 subs : sequence, optional
1841 The location of the minor ticks. If *None*, reasonable locations
1842 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the
1843 plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale`/`.Axes.set_yscale` for details.
1844  
1845 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'clip'
1846 Non-positive values can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a very
1847 small positive number.
1848  
1849 **kwargs
1850 All parameters supported by `.plot`.
1851  
1852 Returns
1853 -------
1854 list of `.Line2D`
1855 Objects representing the plotted data.
1856 """
1857 dx = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items()
1858 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive',
1859 'basex', 'subsx', 'nonposx']}
1860 self.set_xscale('log', **dx)
1861 dy = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items()
1862 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive',
1863 'basey', 'subsy', 'nonposy']}
1864 self.set_yscale('log', **dy)
1865 return self.plot(
1866 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in {*dx, *dy}})
1867  
1868 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking..
1869 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1870 def semilogx(self, *args, **kwargs):
1871 """
1872 Make a plot with log scaling on the x-axis.
1873  
1874 Call signatures::
1875  
1876 semilogx([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs)
1877 semilogx([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)
1878  
1879 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes
1880 the x-axis to log scaling. All the concepts and parameters of plot can
1881 be used here as well.
1882  
1883 The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the
1884 x-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale`.
1885  
1886 Parameters
1887 ----------
1888 base : float, default: 10
1889 Base of the x logarithm.
1890  
1891 subs : array-like, optional
1892 The location of the minor xticks. If *None*, reasonable locations
1893 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the
1894 plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale` for details.
1895  
1896 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'clip'
1897 Non-positive values in x can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a
1898 very small positive number.
1899  
1900 **kwargs
1901 All parameters supported by `.plot`.
1902  
1903 Returns
1904 -------
1905 list of `.Line2D`
1906 Objects representing the plotted data.
1907 """
1908 d = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items()
1909 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive',
1910 'basex', 'subsx', 'nonposx']}
1911 self.set_xscale('log', **d)
1912 return self.plot(
1913 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in d})
1914  
1915 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking..
1916 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1917 def semilogy(self, *args, **kwargs):
1918 """
1919 Make a plot with log scaling on the y-axis.
1920  
1921 Call signatures::
1922  
1923 semilogy([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs)
1924 semilogy([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs)
1925  
1926 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes
1927 the y-axis to log scaling. All the concepts and parameters of plot can
1928 be used here as well.
1929  
1930 The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the
1931 y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_yscale`.
1932  
1933 Parameters
1934 ----------
1935 base : float, default: 10
1936 Base of the y logarithm.
1937  
1938 subs : array-like, optional
1939 The location of the minor yticks. If *None*, reasonable locations
1940 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the
1941 plot. See `.Axes.set_yscale` for details.
1942  
1943 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'clip'
1944 Non-positive values in y can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a
1945 very small positive number.
1946  
1947 **kwargs
1948 All parameters supported by `.plot`.
1949  
1950 Returns
1951 -------
1952 list of `.Line2D`
1953 Objects representing the plotted data.
1954 """
1955 d = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items()
1956 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive',
1957 'basey', 'subsy', 'nonposy']}
1958 self.set_yscale('log', **d)
1959 return self.plot(
1960 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in d})
1961  
1962 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"], label_namer="x")
1963 def acorr(self, x, **kwargs):
1964 """
1965 Plot the autocorrelation of *x*.
1966  
1967 Parameters
1968 ----------
1969 x : array-like
1970  
1971 detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending)
1972 A detrending function applied to *x*. It must have the
1973 signature ::
1974  
1975 detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray
1976  
1977 normed : bool, default: True
1978 If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length.
1979  
1980 usevlines : bool, default: True
1981 Determines the plot style.
1982  
1983 If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the acorr value
1984 using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted
1985 at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`.
1986  
1987 If ``False``, markers are plotted at the acorr values using
1988 `.Axes.plot`.
1989  
1990 maxlags : int, default: 10
1991 Number of lags to show. If ``None``, will return all
1992 ``2 * len(x) - 1`` lags.
1993  
1994 Returns
1995 -------
1996 lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
1997 The lag vector.
1998 c : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
1999 The auto correlation vector.
2000 line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D`
2001 `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation:
2002  
2003 - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True.
2004 - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False.
2005 b : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` or None
2006 Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True
2007 None *usevlines* is False.
2008  
2009 Other Parameters
2010 ----------------
2011 linestyle : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` property, optional
2012 The linestyle for plotting the data points.
2013 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.
2014  
2015 marker : str, default: 'o'
2016 The marker for plotting the data points.
2017 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.
2018  
2019 data : indexable object, optional
2020 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
2021  
2022 **kwargs
2023 Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and
2024 `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are
2025 passed to `.Axes.plot`.
2026  
2027 Notes
2028 -----
2029 The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with
2030 ``mode = "full"``.
2031 """
2032 return self.xcorr(x, x, **kwargs)
2033  
2034 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"], label_namer="y")
2035 def xcorr(self, x, y, normed=True, detrend=mlab.detrend_none,
2036 usevlines=True, maxlags=10, **kwargs):
2037 r"""
2038 Plot the cross correlation between *x* and *y*.
2039  
2040 The correlation with lag k is defined as
2041 :math:`\sum_n x[n+k] \cdot y^*[n]`, where :math:`y^*` is the complex
2042 conjugate of :math:`y`.
2043  
2044 Parameters
2045 ----------
2046 x, y : array-like of length n
2047  
2048 detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending)
2049 A detrending function applied to *x* and *y*. It must have the
2050 signature ::
2051  
2052 detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray
2053  
2054 normed : bool, default: True
2055 If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length.
2056  
2057 usevlines : bool, default: True
2058 Determines the plot style.
2059  
2060 If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the xcorr value
2061 using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted
2062 at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`.
2063  
2064 If ``False``, markers are plotted at the xcorr values using
2065 `.Axes.plot`.
2066  
2067 maxlags : int, default: 10
2068 Number of lags to show. If None, will return all ``2 * len(x) - 1``
2069 lags.
2070  
2071 Returns
2072 -------
2073 lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
2074 The lag vector.
2075 c : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``)
2076 The auto correlation vector.
2077 line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D`
2078 `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation:
2079  
2080 - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True.
2081 - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False.
2082 b : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` or None
2083 Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True
2084 None *usevlines* is False.
2085  
2086 Other Parameters
2087 ----------------
2088 linestyle : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` property, optional
2089 The linestyle for plotting the data points.
2090 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.
2091  
2092 marker : str, default: 'o'
2093 The marker for plotting the data points.
2094 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``.
2095  
2096 data : indexable object, optional
2097 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
2098  
2099 **kwargs
2100 Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and
2101 `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are
2102 passed to `.Axes.plot`.
2103  
2104 Notes
2105 -----
2106 The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with
2107 ``mode = "full"``.
2108 """
2109 Nx = len(x)
2110 if Nx != len(y):
2111 raise ValueError('x and y must be equal length')
2112  
2113 x = detrend(np.asarray(x))
2114 y = detrend(np.asarray(y))
2115  
2116 correls = np.correlate(x, y, mode="full")
2117  
2118 if normed:
2119 correls = correls / np.sqrt(np.dot(x, x) * np.dot(y, y))
2120  
2121 if maxlags is None:
2122 maxlags = Nx - 1
2123  
2124 if maxlags >= Nx or maxlags < 1:
2125 raise ValueError('maxlags must be None or strictly '
2126 'positive < %d' % Nx)
2127  
2128 lags = np.arange(-maxlags, maxlags + 1)
2129 correls = correls[Nx - 1 - maxlags:Nx + maxlags]
2130  
2131 if usevlines:
2132 a = self.vlines(lags, [0], correls, **kwargs)
2133 # Make label empty so only vertical lines get a legend entry
2134 kwargs.pop('label', '')
2135 b = self.axhline(**kwargs)
2136 else:
2137 kwargs.setdefault('marker', 'o')
2138 kwargs.setdefault('linestyle', 'None')
2139 a, = self.plot(lags, correls, **kwargs)
2140 b = None
2141 return lags, correls, a, b
2142  
  • E266 Too many leading '#' for block comment
2143 #### Specialized plotting
2144  
2145 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking..
2146 def step(self, x, y, *args, where='pre', data=None, **kwargs):
2147 """
2148 Make a step plot.
2149  
2150 Call signatures::
2151  
2152 step(x, y, [fmt], *, data=None, where='pre', **kwargs)
2153 step(x, y, [fmt], x2, y2, [fmt2], ..., *, where='pre', **kwargs)
2154  
2155 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which changes some
2156 formatting options. Most of the concepts and parameters of plot can be
2157 used here as well.
2158  
2159 .. note::
2160  
2161 This method uses a standard plot with a step drawstyle: The *x*
2162 values are the reference positions and steps extend left/right/both
2163 directions depending on *where*.
2164  
2165 For the common case where you know the values and edges of the
2166 steps, use `~.Axes.stairs` instead.
2167  
2168 Parameters
2169 ----------
2170 x : array-like
2171 1D sequence of x positions. It is assumed, but not checked, that
2172 it is uniformly increasing.
2173  
2174 y : array-like
2175 1D sequence of y levels.
2176  
2177 fmt : str, optional
2178 A format string, e.g. 'g' for a green line. See `.plot` for a more
2179 detailed description.
2180  
2181 Note: While full format strings are accepted, it is recommended to
2182 only specify the color. Line styles are currently ignored (use
2183 the keyword argument *linestyle* instead). Markers are accepted
2184 and plotted on the given positions, however, this is a rarely
2185 needed feature for step plots.
2186  
2187 where : {'pre', 'post', 'mid'}, default: 'pre'
2188 Define where the steps should be placed:
2189  
2190 - 'pre': The y value is continued constantly to the left from
2191 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``(x[i-1], x[i]]`` has the
2192 value ``y[i]``.
2193 - 'post': The y value is continued constantly to the right from
2194 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``[x[i], x[i+1])`` has the
2195 value ``y[i]``.
2196 - 'mid': Steps occur half-way between the *x* positions.
2197  
2198 data : indexable object, optional
2199 An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to
2200 plot in *x* and *y*.
2201  
2202 **kwargs
2203 Additional parameters are the same as those for `.plot`.
2204  
2205 Returns
2206 -------
2207 list of `.Line2D`
2208 Objects representing the plotted data.
2209 """
2210 _api.check_in_list(('pre', 'post', 'mid'), where=where)
2211 kwargs['drawstyle'] = 'steps-' + where
2212 return self.plot(x, y, *args, data=data, **kwargs)
2213  
2214 @staticmethod
2215 def _convert_dx(dx, x0, xconv, convert):
2216 """
2217 Small helper to do logic of width conversion flexibly.
2218  
2219 *dx* and *x0* have units, but *xconv* has already been converted
2220 to unitless (and is an ndarray). This allows the *dx* to have units
2221 that are different from *x0*, but are still accepted by the
2222 ``__add__`` operator of *x0*.
2223 """
2224  
2225 # x should be an array...
2226 assert type(xconv) is np.ndarray
2227  
2228 if xconv.size == 0:
2229 # xconv has already been converted, but maybe empty...
2230 return convert(dx)
2231  
2232 try:
2233 # attempt to add the width to x0; this works for
2234 # datetime+timedelta, for instance
2235  
2236 # only use the first element of x and x0. This saves
2237 # having to be sure addition works across the whole
2238 # vector. This is particularly an issue if
2239 # x0 and dx are lists so x0 + dx just concatenates the lists.
2240 # We can't just cast x0 and dx to numpy arrays because that
2241 # removes the units from unit packages like `pint` that
2242 # wrap numpy arrays.
2243 try:
2244 x0 = cbook._safe_first_finite(x0)
2245 except (TypeError, IndexError, KeyError):
2246 pass
2247  
2248 try:
2249 x = cbook._safe_first_finite(xconv)
2250 except (TypeError, IndexError, KeyError):
2251 x = xconv
2252  
2253 delist = False
2254 if not np.iterable(dx):
2255 dx = [dx]
2256 delist = True
2257 dx = [convert(x0 + ddx) - x for ddx in dx]
2258 if delist:
2259 dx = dx[0]
2260 except (ValueError, TypeError, AttributeError):
2261 # if the above fails (for any reason) just fallback to what
2262 # we do by default and convert dx by itself.
2263 dx = convert(dx)
2264 return dx
2265  
2266 @_preprocess_data()
2267 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
2268 def bar(self, x, height, width=0.8, bottom=None, *, align="center",
2269 **kwargs):
2270 r"""
2271 Make a bar plot.
2272  
2273 The bars are positioned at *x* with the given *align*\ment. Their
2274 dimensions are given by *height* and *width*. The vertical baseline
2275 is *bottom* (default 0).
2276  
2277 Many parameters can take either a single value applying to all bars
2278 or a sequence of values, one for each bar.
2279  
2280 Parameters
2281 ----------
2282 x : float or array-like
2283 The x coordinates of the bars. See also *align* for the
2284 alignment of the bars to the coordinates.
2285  
2286 height : float or array-like
2287 The height(s) of the bars.
2288  
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
2289 Note that if *bottom* has units (e.g. datetime), *height* should be in
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
2290 units that are a difference from the value of *bottom* (e.g. timedelta).
2291  
2292 width : float or array-like, default: 0.8
2293 The width(s) of the bars.
2294  
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
2295 Note that if *x* has units (e.g. datetime), then *width* should be in
2296 units that are a difference (e.g. timedelta) around the *x* values.
2297  
2298 bottom : float or array-like, default: 0
2299 The y coordinate(s) of the bottom side(s) of the bars.
2300  
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
2301 Note that if *bottom* has units, then the y-axis will get a Locator and
2302 Formatter appropriate for the units (e.g. dates, or categorical).
2303  
2304 align : {'center', 'edge'}, default: 'center'
2305 Alignment of the bars to the *x* coordinates:
2306  
2307 - 'center': Center the base on the *x* positions.
2308 - 'edge': Align the left edges of the bars with the *x* positions.
2309  
2310 To align the bars on the right edge pass a negative *width* and
2311 ``align='edge'``.
2312  
2313 Returns
2314 -------
2315 `.BarContainer`
2316 Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars.
2317  
2318 Other Parameters
2319 ----------------
2320 color : color or list of color, optional
2321 The colors of the bar faces.
2322  
2323 edgecolor : color or list of color, optional
2324 The colors of the bar edges.
2325  
2326 linewidth : float or array-like, optional
2327 Width of the bar edge(s). If 0, don't draw edges.
2328  
2329 tick_label : str or list of str, optional
2330 The tick labels of the bars.
2331 Default: None (Use default numeric labels.)
2332  
2333 label : str or list of str, optional
2334 A single label is attached to the resulting `.BarContainer` as a
2335 label for the whole dataset.
2336 If a list is provided, it must be the same length as *x* and
2337 labels the individual bars. Repeated labels are not de-duplicated
2338 and will cause repeated label entries, so this is best used when
2339 bars also differ in style (e.g., by passing a list to *color*.)
2340  
2341 xerr, yerr : float or array-like of shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional
2342 If not *None*, add horizontal / vertical errorbars to the bar tips.
2343 The values are +/- sizes relative to the data:
2344  
2345 - scalar: symmetric +/- values for all bars
2346 - shape(N,): symmetric +/- values for each bar
2347 - shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row
2348 contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper
2349 errors.
2350 - *None*: No errorbar. (Default)
2351  
2352 See :doc:`/gallery/statistics/errorbar_features` for an example on
2353 the usage of *xerr* and *yerr*.
2354  
2355 ecolor : color or list of color, default: 'black'
2356 The line color of the errorbars.
2357  
2358 capsize : float, default: :rc:`errorbar.capsize`
2359 The length of the error bar caps in points.
2360  
2361 error_kw : dict, optional
2362 Dictionary of keyword arguments to be passed to the
2363 `~.Axes.errorbar` method. Values of *ecolor* or *capsize* defined
2364 here take precedence over the independent keyword arguments.
2365  
2366 log : bool, default: False
2367 If *True*, set the y-axis to be log scale.
2368  
2369 data : indexable object, optional
2370 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
2371  
2372 **kwargs : `.Rectangle` properties
2373  
2374 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s
2375  
2376 See Also
2377 --------
2378 barh : Plot a horizontal bar plot.
2379  
2380 Notes
2381 -----
2382 Stacked bars can be achieved by passing individual *bottom* values per
2383 bar. See :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/bar_stacked`.
2384 """
2385 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mpatches.Patch)
2386 color = kwargs.pop('color', None)
2387 if color is None:
2388 color = self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color()
2389 edgecolor = kwargs.pop('edgecolor', None)
2390 linewidth = kwargs.pop('linewidth', None)
2391 hatch = kwargs.pop('hatch', None)
2392  
2393 # Because xerr and yerr will be passed to errorbar, most dimension
2394 # checking and processing will be left to the errorbar method.
2395 xerr = kwargs.pop('xerr', None)
2396 yerr = kwargs.pop('yerr', None)
2397 error_kw = kwargs.pop('error_kw', None)
2398 error_kw = {} if error_kw is None else error_kw.copy()
2399 ezorder = error_kw.pop('zorder', None)
2400 if ezorder is None:
2401 ezorder = kwargs.get('zorder', None)
2402 if ezorder is not None:
