2403 # If using the bar zorder, increment slightly to make sure
2404 # errorbars are drawn on top of bars
2405 ezorder += 0.01
2406 error_kw.setdefault('zorder', ezorder)
2407 ecolor = kwargs.pop('ecolor', 'k')
2408 capsize = kwargs.pop('capsize', mpl.rcParams["errorbar.capsize"])
2409 error_kw.setdefault('ecolor', ecolor)
2410 error_kw.setdefault('capsize', capsize)
2411  
2412 # The keyword argument *orientation* is used by barh() to defer all
2413 # logic and drawing to bar(). It is considered internal and is
2414 # intentionally not mentioned in the docstring.
2415 orientation = kwargs.pop('orientation', 'vertical')
2416 _api.check_in_list(['vertical', 'horizontal'], orientation=orientation)
2417 log = kwargs.pop('log', False)
2418 label = kwargs.pop('label', '')
2419 tick_labels = kwargs.pop('tick_label', None)
2420  
2421 y = bottom # Matches barh call signature.
2422 if orientation == 'vertical':
2423 if y is None:
2424 y = 0
2425 else: # horizontal
2426 if x is None:
2427 x = 0
2428  
2429 if orientation == 'vertical':
2430 # It is possible for y (bottom) to contain unit information.
2431 # However, it is also possible for y=0 for the default and height
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
2432 # to contain unit information. This will prioritize the units of y.
2433 self._process_unit_info(
2434 [("x", x), ("y", y), ("y", height)], kwargs, convert=False)
2435 if log:
2436 self.set_yscale('log', nonpositive='clip')
2437 else: # horizontal
2438 # It is possible for x (left) to contain unit information.
2439 # However, it is also possible for x=0 for the default and width
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
2440 # to contain unit information. This will prioritize the units of x.
2441 self._process_unit_info(
2442 [("x", x), ("x", width), ("y", y)], kwargs, convert=False)
2443 if log:
2444 self.set_xscale('log', nonpositive='clip')
2445  
2446 # lets do some conversions now since some types cannot be
2447 # subtracted uniformly
2448 if self.xaxis is not None:
2449 x0 = x
2450 x = np.asarray(self.convert_xunits(x))
2451 width = self._convert_dx(width, x0, x, self.convert_xunits)
2452 if xerr is not None:
2453 xerr = self._convert_dx(xerr, x0, x, self.convert_xunits)
2454 if self.yaxis is not None:
2455 y0 = y
2456 y = np.asarray(self.convert_yunits(y))
2457 height = self._convert_dx(height, y0, y, self.convert_yunits)
2458 if yerr is not None:
2459 yerr = self._convert_dx(yerr, y0, y, self.convert_yunits)
2460  
2461 x, height, width, y, linewidth, hatch = np.broadcast_arrays(
2462 # Make args iterable too.
2463 np.atleast_1d(x), height, width, y, linewidth, hatch)
2464  
2465 # Now that units have been converted, set the tick locations.
2466 if orientation == 'vertical':
2467 tick_label_axis = self.xaxis
2468 tick_label_position = x
2469 else: # horizontal
2470 tick_label_axis = self.yaxis
2471 tick_label_position = y
2472  
2473 if not isinstance(label, str) and np.iterable(label):
2474 bar_container_label = '_nolegend_'
2475 patch_labels = label
2476 else:
2477 bar_container_label = label
2478 patch_labels = ['_nolegend_'] * len(x)
2479 if len(patch_labels) != len(x):
2480 raise ValueError(f'number of labels ({len(patch_labels)}) '
2481 f'does not match number of bars ({len(x)}).')
2482  
2483 linewidth = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(linewidth))
2484 hatch = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(hatch))
2485 color = itertools.chain(itertools.cycle(mcolors.to_rgba_array(color)),
2486 # Fallback if color == "none".
2487 itertools.repeat('none'))
2488 if edgecolor is None:
2489 edgecolor = itertools.repeat(None)
2490 else:
2491 edgecolor = itertools.chain(
2492 itertools.cycle(mcolors.to_rgba_array(edgecolor)),
2493 # Fallback if edgecolor == "none".
2494 itertools.repeat('none'))
2495  
2496 # We will now resolve the alignment and really have
2497 # left, bottom, width, height vectors
2498 _api.check_in_list(['center', 'edge'], align=align)
2499 if align == 'center':
2500 if orientation == 'vertical':
2501 try:
2502 left = x - width / 2
2503 except TypeError as e:
2504 raise TypeError(f'the dtypes of parameters x ({x.dtype}) '
2505 f'and width ({width.dtype}) '
2506 f'are incompatible') from e
2507 bottom = y
2508 else: # horizontal
2509 try:
2510 bottom = y - height / 2
2511 except TypeError as e:
2512 raise TypeError(f'the dtypes of parameters y ({y.dtype}) '
2513 f'and height ({height.dtype}) '
2514 f'are incompatible') from e
2515 left = x
2516 else: # edge
2517 left = x
2518 bottom = y
2519  
2520 patches = []
2521 args = zip(left, bottom, width, height, color, edgecolor, linewidth,
2522 hatch, patch_labels)
  • E741 Ambiguous variable name 'l'
2523 for l, b, w, h, c, e, lw, htch, lbl in args:
2524 r = mpatches.Rectangle(
2525 xy=(l, b), width=w, height=h,
2526 facecolor=c,
2527 edgecolor=e,
2528 linewidth=lw,
2529 label=lbl,
2530 hatch=htch,
2531 )
2532 r._internal_update(kwargs)
2533 r.get_path()._interpolation_steps = 100
2534 if orientation == 'vertical':
2535 r.sticky_edges.y.append(b)
2536 else: # horizontal
2537 r.sticky_edges.x.append(l)
2538 self.add_patch(r)
2539 patches.append(r)
2540  
2541 if xerr is not None or yerr is not None:
2542 if orientation == 'vertical':
2543 # using list comps rather than arrays to preserve unit info
  • E741 Ambiguous variable name 'l'
2544 ex = [l + 0.5 * w for l, w in zip(left, width)]
2545 ey = [b + h for b, h in zip(bottom, height)]
2546  
2547 else: # horizontal
2548 # using list comps rather than arrays to preserve unit info
  • E741 Ambiguous variable name 'l'
2549 ex = [l + w for l, w in zip(left, width)]
2550 ey = [b + 0.5 * h for b, h in zip(bottom, height)]
2551  
2552 error_kw.setdefault("label", '_nolegend_')
2553  
2554 errorbar = self.errorbar(ex, ey, yerr=yerr, xerr=xerr, fmt='none',
2555 **error_kw)
2556 else:
2557 errorbar = None
2558  
2559 self._request_autoscale_view()
2560  
2561 if orientation == 'vertical':
2562 datavalues = height
2563 else: # horizontal
2564 datavalues = width
2565  
2566 bar_container = BarContainer(patches, errorbar, datavalues=datavalues,
2567 orientation=orientation,
2568 label=bar_container_label)
2569 self.add_container(bar_container)
2570  
2571 if tick_labels is not None:
2572 tick_labels = np.broadcast_to(tick_labels, len(patches))
2573 tick_label_axis.set_ticks(tick_label_position)
2574 tick_label_axis.set_ticklabels(tick_labels)
2575  
2576 return bar_container
2577  
2578 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'bar' do the unpacking..
2579 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
2580 def barh(self, y, width, height=0.8, left=None, *, align="center",
2581 data=None, **kwargs):
2582 r"""
2583 Make a horizontal bar plot.
2584  
2585 The bars are positioned at *y* with the given *align*\ment. Their
2586 dimensions are given by *width* and *height*. The horizontal baseline
2587 is *left* (default 0).
2588  
2589 Many parameters can take either a single value applying to all bars
2590 or a sequence of values, one for each bar.
2591  
2592 Parameters
2593 ----------
2594 y : float or array-like
2595 The y coordinates of the bars. See also *align* for the
2596 alignment of the bars to the coordinates.
2597  
2598 width : float or array-like
2599 The width(s) of the bars.
2600  
2601 Note that if *left* has units (e.g. datetime), *width* should be in
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
2602 units that are a difference from the value of *left* (e.g. timedelta).
2603  
2604 height : float or array-like, default: 0.8
2605 The heights of the bars.
2606  
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
2607 Note that if *y* has units (e.g. datetime), then *height* should be in
2608 units that are a difference (e.g. timedelta) around the *y* values.
2609  
2610 left : float or array-like, default: 0
2611 The x coordinates of the left side(s) of the bars.
2612  
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
2613 Note that if *left* has units, then the x-axis will get a Locator and
2614 Formatter appropriate for the units (e.g. dates, or categorical).
2615  
2616 align : {'center', 'edge'}, default: 'center'
2617 Alignment of the base to the *y* coordinates*:
2618  
2619 - 'center': Center the bars on the *y* positions.
2620 - 'edge': Align the bottom edges of the bars with the *y*
2621 positions.
2622  
2623 To align the bars on the top edge pass a negative *height* and
2624 ``align='edge'``.
2625  
2626 Returns
2627 -------
2628 `.BarContainer`
2629 Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars.
2630  
2631 Other Parameters
2632 ----------------
2633 color : color or list of color, optional
2634 The colors of the bar faces.
2635  
2636 edgecolor : color or list of color, optional
2637 The colors of the bar edges.
2638  
2639 linewidth : float or array-like, optional
2640 Width of the bar edge(s). If 0, don't draw edges.
2641  
2642 tick_label : str or list of str, optional
2643 The tick labels of the bars.
2644 Default: None (Use default numeric labels.)
2645  
2646 label : str or list of str, optional
2647 A single label is attached to the resulting `.BarContainer` as a
2648 label for the whole dataset.
2649 If a list is provided, it must be the same length as *y* and
2650 labels the individual bars. Repeated labels are not de-duplicated
2651 and will cause repeated label entries, so this is best used when
2652 bars also differ in style (e.g., by passing a list to *color*.)
2653  
2654 xerr, yerr : float or array-like of shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional
2655 If not *None*, add horizontal / vertical errorbars to the bar tips.
2656 The values are +/- sizes relative to the data:
2657  
2658 - scalar: symmetric +/- values for all bars
2659 - shape(N,): symmetric +/- values for each bar
2660 - shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row
2661 contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper
2662 errors.
2663 - *None*: No errorbar. (default)
2664  
2665 See :doc:`/gallery/statistics/errorbar_features` for an example on
2666 the usage of *xerr* and *yerr*.
2667  
2668 ecolor : color or list of color, default: 'black'
2669 The line color of the errorbars.
2670  
2671 capsize : float, default: :rc:`errorbar.capsize`
2672 The length of the error bar caps in points.
2673  
2674 error_kw : dict, optional
2675 Dictionary of keyword arguments to be passed to the
2676 `~.Axes.errorbar` method. Values of *ecolor* or *capsize* defined
2677 here take precedence over the independent keyword arguments.
2678  
2679 log : bool, default: False
2680 If ``True``, set the x-axis to be log scale.
2681  
2682 data : indexable object, optional
2683 If given, all parameters also accept a string ``s``, which is
2684 interpreted as ``data[s]`` (unless this raises an exception).
2685  
2686 **kwargs : `.Rectangle` properties
2687  
2688 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s
2689  
2690 See Also
2691 --------
2692 bar : Plot a vertical bar plot.
2693  
2694 Notes
2695 -----
2696 Stacked bars can be achieved by passing individual *left* values per
2697 bar. See
2698 :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/horizontal_barchart_distribution`.
2699 """
2700 kwargs.setdefault('orientation', 'horizontal')
2701 patches = self.bar(x=left, height=height, width=width, bottom=y,
2702 align=align, data=data, **kwargs)
2703 return patches
2704  
2705 def bar_label(self, container, labels=None, *, fmt="%g", label_type="edge",
2706 padding=0, **kwargs):
2707 """
2708 Label a bar plot.
2709  
2710 Adds labels to bars in the given `.BarContainer`.
2711 You may need to adjust the axis limits to fit the labels.
2712  
2713 Parameters
2714 ----------
2715 container : `.BarContainer`
2716 Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars, likely
2717 returned from `.bar` or `.barh`.
2718  
2719 labels : array-like, optional
2720 A list of label texts, that should be displayed. If not given, the
2721 label texts will be the data values formatted with *fmt*.
2722  
2723 fmt : str or callable, default: '%g'
2724 An unnamed %-style or {}-style format string for the label or a
2725 function to call with the value as the first argument.
2726 When *fmt* is a string and can be interpreted in both formats,
2727 %-style takes precedence over {}-style.
2728  
2729 .. versionadded:: 3.7
2730 Support for {}-style format string and callables.
2731  
2732 label_type : {'edge', 'center'}, default: 'edge'
2733 The label type. Possible values:
2734  
2735 - 'edge': label placed at the end-point of the bar segment, and the
2736 value displayed will be the position of that end-point.
2737 - 'center': label placed in the center of the bar segment, and the
2738 value displayed will be the length of that segment.
2739 (useful for stacked bars, i.e.,
2740 :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/bar_label_demo`)
2741  
2742 padding : float, default: 0
2743 Distance of label from the end of the bar, in points.
2744  
2745 **kwargs
2746 Any remaining keyword arguments are passed through to
2747 `.Axes.annotate`. The alignment parameters (
2748 *horizontalalignment* / *ha*, *verticalalignment* / *va*) are
2749 not supported because the labels are automatically aligned to
2750 the bars.
2751  
2752 Returns
2753 -------
2754 list of `.Annotation`
2755 A list of `.Annotation` instances for the labels.
2756 """
2757 for key in ['horizontalalignment', 'ha', 'verticalalignment', 'va']:
2758 if key in kwargs:
2759 raise ValueError(
2760 f"Passing {key!r} to bar_label() is not supported.")
2761  
2762 a, b = self.yaxis.get_view_interval()
2763 y_inverted = a > b
2764 c, d = self.xaxis.get_view_interval()
2765 x_inverted = c > d
2766  
2767 # want to know whether to put label on positive or negative direction
2768 # cannot use np.sign here because it will return 0 if x == 0
2769 def sign(x):
2770 return 1 if x >= 0 else -1
2771  
2772 _api.check_in_list(['edge', 'center'], label_type=label_type)
2773  
2774 bars = container.patches
2775 errorbar = container.errorbar
2776 datavalues = container.datavalues
2777 orientation = container.orientation
2778  
2779 if errorbar:
2780 # check "ErrorbarContainer" for the definition of these elements
2781 lines = errorbar.lines # attribute of "ErrorbarContainer" (tuple)
2782 barlinecols = lines[2] # 0: data_line, 1: caplines, 2: barlinecols
2783 barlinecol = barlinecols[0] # the "LineCollection" of error bars
2784 errs = barlinecol.get_segments()
2785 else:
2786 errs = []
2787  
2788 if labels is None:
2789 labels = []
2790  
2791 annotations = []
2792  
2793 for bar, err, dat, lbl in itertools.zip_longest(
2794 bars, errs, datavalues, labels
2795 ):
2796 (x0, y0), (x1, y1) = bar.get_bbox().get_points()
2797 xc, yc = (x0 + x1) / 2, (y0 + y1) / 2
2798  
2799 if orientation == "vertical":
2800 extrema = max(y0, y1) if dat >= 0 else min(y0, y1)
2801 length = abs(y0 - y1)
2802 else: # horizontal
2803 extrema = max(x0, x1) if dat >= 0 else min(x0, x1)
2804 length = abs(x0 - x1)
2805  
2806 if err is None or np.size(err) == 0:
2807 endpt = extrema
2808 elif orientation == "vertical":
2809 endpt = err[:, 1].max() if dat >= 0 else err[:, 1].min()
2810 else: # horizontal
2811 endpt = err[:, 0].max() if dat >= 0 else err[:, 0].min()
2812  
2813 if label_type == "center":
2814 value = sign(dat) * length
2815 else: # edge
2816 value = extrema
2817  
2818 if label_type == "center":
2819 xy = (0.5, 0.5)
2820 kwargs["xycoords"] = (
2821 lambda r, b=bar:
2822 mtransforms.Bbox.intersection(
2823 b.get_window_extent(r), b.get_clip_box()
2824 ) or mtransforms.Bbox.null()
2825 )
2826 else: # edge
2827 if orientation == "vertical":
2828 xy = xc, endpt
2829 else: # horizontal
2830 xy = endpt, yc
2831  
2832 if orientation == "vertical":
2833 y_direction = -1 if y_inverted else 1
2834 xytext = 0, y_direction * sign(dat) * padding
2835 else: # horizontal
2836 x_direction = -1 if x_inverted else 1
2837 xytext = x_direction * sign(dat) * padding, 0
2838  
2839 if label_type == "center":
2840 ha, va = "center", "center"
2841 else: # edge
2842 if orientation == "vertical":
2843 ha = 'center'
2844 if y_inverted:
2845 va = 'top' if dat > 0 else 'bottom' # also handles NaN
2846 else:
2847 va = 'top' if dat < 0 else 'bottom' # also handles NaN
2848 else: # horizontal
2849 if x_inverted:
2850 ha = 'right' if dat > 0 else 'left' # also handles NaN
2851 else:
2852 ha = 'right' if dat < 0 else 'left' # also handles NaN
2853 va = 'center'
2854  
2855 if np.isnan(dat):
2856 lbl = ''
2857  
2858 if lbl is None:
2859 if isinstance(fmt, str):
2860 lbl = cbook._auto_format_str(fmt, value)
2861 elif callable(fmt):
2862 lbl = fmt(value)
2863 else:
2864 raise TypeError("fmt must be a str or callable")
2865 annotation = self.annotate(lbl,
2866 xy, xytext, textcoords="offset points",
2867 ha=ha, va=va, **kwargs)
2868 annotations.append(annotation)
2869  
2870 return annotations
2871  
2872 @_preprocess_data()
2873 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
2874 def broken_barh(self, xranges, yrange, **kwargs):
2875 """
2876 Plot a horizontal sequence of rectangles.
2877  
2878 A rectangle is drawn for each element of *xranges*. All rectangles
2879 have the same vertical position and size defined by *yrange*.
2880  
2881 Parameters
2882 ----------
2883 xranges : sequence of tuples (*xmin*, *xwidth*)
2884 The x-positions and extents of the rectangles. For each tuple
2885 (*xmin*, *xwidth*) a rectangle is drawn from *xmin* to *xmin* +
2886 *xwidth*.
2887 yrange : (*ymin*, *yheight*)
2888 The y-position and extent for all the rectangles.
2889  
2890 Returns
2891 -------
2892 `~.collections.PolyCollection`
2893  
2894 Other Parameters
2895 ----------------
2896 data : indexable object, optional
2897 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
2898 **kwargs : `.PolyCollection` properties
2899  
2900 Each *kwarg* can be either a single argument applying to all
2901 rectangles, e.g.::
2902  
2903 facecolors='black'
2904  
2905 or a sequence of arguments over which is cycled, e.g.::
2906  
2907 facecolors=('black', 'blue')
2908  
2909 would create interleaving black and blue rectangles.
2910  
2911 Supported keywords:
2912  
2913 %(PolyCollection:kwdoc)s
2914 """
2915 # process the unit information
2916 xdata = cbook._safe_first_finite(xranges) if len(xranges) else None
2917 ydata = cbook._safe_first_finite(yrange) if len(yrange) else None
2918 self._process_unit_info(
2919 [("x", xdata), ("y", ydata)], kwargs, convert=False)
2920  
2921 vertices = []
2922 y0, dy = yrange
2923 y0, y1 = self.convert_yunits((y0, y0 + dy))
2924 for xr in xranges: # convert the absolute values, not the x and dx
2925 try:
2926 x0, dx = xr
2927 except Exception:
2928 raise ValueError(
2929 "each range in xrange must be a sequence with two "
2930 "elements (i.e. xrange must be an (N, 2) array)") from None
2931 x0, x1 = self.convert_xunits((x0, x0 + dx))
2932 vertices.append([(x0, y0), (x0, y1), (x1, y1), (x1, y0)])
2933  
2934 col = mcoll.PolyCollection(np.array(vertices), **kwargs)
2935 self.add_collection(col, autolim=True)
2936 self._request_autoscale_view()
2937  
2938 return col
2939  
2940 @_preprocess_data()
2941 def stem(self, *args, linefmt=None, markerfmt=None, basefmt=None, bottom=0,
2942 label=None, orientation='vertical'):
2943 """
2944 Create a stem plot.
2945  
2946 A stem plot draws lines perpendicular to a baseline at each location
2947 *locs* from the baseline to *heads*, and places a marker there. For
2948 vertical stem plots (the default), the *locs* are *x* positions, and
2949 the *heads* are *y* values. For horizontal stem plots, the *locs* are
2950 *y* positions, and the *heads* are *x* values.
2951  
2952 Call signature::
2953  
2954 stem([locs,] heads, linefmt=None, markerfmt=None, basefmt=None)
2955  
2956 The *locs*-positions are optional. *linefmt* may be provided as
2957 positional, but all other formats must be provided as keyword
2958 arguments.
2959  
2960 Parameters
2961 ----------
2962 locs : array-like, default: (0, 1, ..., len(heads) - 1)
2963 For vertical stem plots, the x-positions of the stems.
2964 For horizontal stem plots, the y-positions of the stems.
2965  
2966 heads : array-like
2967 For vertical stem plots, the y-values of the stem heads.
2968 For horizontal stem plots, the x-values of the stem heads.
2969  
2970 linefmt : str, optional
2971 A string defining the color and/or linestyle of the vertical lines:
2972  
2973 ========= =============
2974 Character Line Style
2975 ========= =============
2976 ``'-'`` solid line
2977 ``'--'`` dashed line
2978 ``'-.'`` dash-dot line
2979 ``':'`` dotted line
2980 ========= =============
2981  
2982 Default: 'C0-', i.e. solid line with the first color of the color
2983 cycle.
2984  
2985 Note: Markers specified through this parameter (e.g. 'x') will be
2986 silently ignored. Instead, markers should be specified using
2987 *markerfmt*.
2988  
2989 markerfmt : str, optional
2990 A string defining the color and/or shape of the markers at the stem
2991 heads. If the marker is not given, use the marker 'o', i.e. filled
2992 circles. If the color is not given, use the color from *linefmt*.
2993  
2994 basefmt : str, default: 'C3-' ('C2-' in classic mode)
2995 A format string defining the properties of the baseline.
2996  
2997 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical'
2998 If 'vertical', will produce a plot with stems oriented vertically,
2999 If 'horizontal', the stems will be oriented horizontally.
3000  
3001 bottom : float, default: 0
3002 The y/x-position of the baseline (depending on orientation).
3003  
3004 label : str, default: None
3005 The label to use for the stems in legends.
3006  
3007 data : indexable object, optional
3008 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
3009  
3010 Returns
3011 -------
3012 `.StemContainer`
3013 The container may be treated like a tuple
3014 (*markerline*, *stemlines*, *baseline*)
3015  
3016 Notes
3017 -----
3018 .. seealso::
3019 The MATLAB function
3020 `stem <https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/stem.html>`_
3021 which inspired this method.
3022 """
3023 if not 1 <= len(args) <= 3:
3024 raise _api.nargs_error('stem', '1-3', len(args))
3025 _api.check_in_list(['horizontal', 'vertical'], orientation=orientation)
3026  
3027 if len(args) == 1:
3028 heads, = args
3029 locs = np.arange(len(heads))
3030 args = ()
3031 elif isinstance(args[1], str):
3032 heads, *args = args
3033 locs = np.arange(len(heads))
3034 else:
3035 locs, heads, *args = args
3036  
3037 if orientation == 'vertical':
3038 locs, heads = self._process_unit_info([("x", locs), ("y", heads)])
3039 else: # horizontal
3040 heads, locs = self._process_unit_info([("x", heads), ("y", locs)])
3041  
3042 # resolve line format
3043 if linefmt is None:
3044 linefmt = args[0] if len(args) > 0 else "C0-"
3045 linestyle, linemarker, linecolor = _process_plot_format(linefmt)
3046  
3047 # resolve marker format
3048 if markerfmt is None:
3049 # if not given as kwarg, fall back to 'o'
3050 markerfmt = "o"
3051 if markerfmt == '':
3052 markerfmt = ' ' # = empty line style; '' would resolve rcParams
3053 markerstyle, markermarker, markercolor = \
3054 _process_plot_format(markerfmt)
3055 if markermarker is None:
3056 markermarker = 'o'
3057 if markerstyle is None:
3058 markerstyle = 'None'
3059 if markercolor is None:
3060 markercolor = linecolor
3061  
3062 # resolve baseline format
3063 if basefmt is None:
3064 basefmt = ("C2-" if mpl.rcParams["_internal.classic_mode"] else
3065 "C3-")
3066 basestyle, basemarker, basecolor = _process_plot_format(basefmt)
3067  
3068 # New behaviour in 3.1 is to use a LineCollection for the stemlines
3069 if linestyle is None:
3070 linestyle = mpl.rcParams['lines.linestyle']
3071 xlines = self.vlines if orientation == "vertical" else self.hlines
3072 stemlines = xlines(
3073 locs, bottom, heads,
3074 colors=linecolor, linestyles=linestyle, label="_nolegend_")
3075  
3076 if orientation == 'horizontal':
3077 marker_x = heads
3078 marker_y = locs
3079 baseline_x = [bottom, bottom]
3080 baseline_y = [np.min(locs), np.max(locs)]
3081 else:
3082 marker_x = locs
3083 marker_y = heads
3084 baseline_x = [np.min(locs), np.max(locs)]
3085 baseline_y = [bottom, bottom]
3086  
3087 markerline, = self.plot(marker_x, marker_y,
3088 color=markercolor, linestyle=markerstyle,
3089 marker=markermarker, label="_nolegend_")
3090  
3091 baseline, = self.plot(baseline_x, baseline_y,
3092 color=basecolor, linestyle=basestyle,
3093 marker=basemarker, label="_nolegend_")
3094  
3095 stem_container = StemContainer((markerline, stemlines, baseline),
3096 label=label)
3097 self.add_container(stem_container)
3098 return stem_container
3099  
3100 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "explode", "labels", "colors"])
3101 def pie(self, x, explode=None, labels=None, colors=None,
3102 autopct=None, pctdistance=0.6, shadow=False, labeldistance=1.1,
3103 startangle=0, radius=1, counterclock=True,
3104 wedgeprops=None, textprops=None, center=(0, 0),
3105 frame=False, rotatelabels=False, *, normalize=True, hatch=None):
3106 """
3107 Plot a pie chart.
3108  
3109 Make a pie chart of array *x*. The fractional area of each wedge is
3110 given by ``x/sum(x)``.
3111  
3112 The wedges are plotted counterclockwise, by default starting from the
3113 x-axis.
3114  
3115 Parameters
3116 ----------
3117 x : 1D array-like
3118 The wedge sizes.
3119  
3120 explode : array-like, default: None
3121 If not *None*, is a ``len(x)`` array which specifies the fraction
3122 of the radius with which to offset each wedge.
3123  
3124 labels : list, default: None
3125 A sequence of strings providing the labels for each wedge
3126  
3127 colors : color or array-like of color, default: None
3128 A sequence of colors through which the pie chart will cycle. If
3129 *None*, will use the colors in the currently active cycle.
3130  
3131 hatch : str or list, default: None
3132 Hatching pattern applied to all pie wedges or sequence of patterns
3133 through which the chart will cycle. For a list of valid patterns,
3134 see :doc:`/gallery/shapes_and_collections/hatch_style_reference`.
3135  
3136 .. versionadded:: 3.7
3137  
3138 autopct : None or str or callable, default: None
3139 If not *None*, *autopct* is a string or function used to label the
3140 wedges with their numeric value. The label will be placed inside
3141 the wedge. If *autopct* is a format string, the label will be
3142 ``fmt % pct``. If *autopct* is a function, then it will be called.
3143  
3144 pctdistance : float, default: 0.6
3145 The relative distance along the radius at which the text
3146 generated by *autopct* is drawn. To draw the text outside the pie,
3147 set *pctdistance* > 1. This parameter is ignored if *autopct* is
3148 ``None``.
3149  
3150 labeldistance : float or None, default: 1.1
3151 The relative distance along the radius at which the labels are
3152 drawn. To draw the labels inside the pie, set *labeldistance* < 1.
3153 If set to ``None``, labels are not drawn but are still stored for
3154 use in `.legend`.
3155  
3156 shadow : bool or dict, default: False
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
3157 If bool, whether to draw a shadow beneath the pie. If dict, draw a shadow
3158 passing the properties in the dict to `.Shadow`.
3159  
3160 .. versionadded:: 3.8
3161 *shadow* can be a dict.
3162  
3163 startangle : float, default: 0 degrees
3164 The angle by which the start of the pie is rotated,
3165 counterclockwise from the x-axis.
3166  
3167 radius : float, default: 1
3168 The radius of the pie.
3169  
3170 counterclock : bool, default: True
3171 Specify fractions direction, clockwise or counterclockwise.
3172  
3173 wedgeprops : dict, default: None
3174 Dict of arguments passed to each `.patches.Wedge` of the pie.
3175 For example, ``wedgeprops = {'linewidth': 3}`` sets the width of
3176 the wedge border lines equal to 3. By default, ``clip_on=False``.
3177 When there is a conflict between these properties and other
3178 keywords, properties passed to *wedgeprops* take precedence.
3179  
3180 textprops : dict, default: None
3181 Dict of arguments to pass to the text objects.
3182  
3183 center : (float, float), default: (0, 0)
3184 The coordinates of the center of the chart.
3185  
3186 frame : bool, default: False
3187 Plot Axes frame with the chart if true.
3188  
3189 rotatelabels : bool, default: False
3190 Rotate each label to the angle of the corresponding slice if true.
3191  
3192 normalize : bool, default: True
3193 When *True*, always make a full pie by normalizing x so that
3194 ``sum(x) == 1``. *False* makes a partial pie if ``sum(x) <= 1``
3195 and raises a `ValueError` for ``sum(x) > 1``.
3196  
3197 data : indexable object, optional
3198 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
3199  
3200 Returns
3201 -------
3202 patches : list
3203 A sequence of `matplotlib.patches.Wedge` instances
3204  
3205 texts : list
3206 A list of the label `.Text` instances.
3207  
3208 autotexts : list
3209 A list of `.Text` instances for the numeric labels. This will only
3210 be returned if the parameter *autopct* is not *None*.
3211  
3212 Notes
3213 -----
3214 The pie chart will probably look best if the figure and Axes are
3215 square, or the Axes aspect is equal.
3216 This method sets the aspect ratio of the axis to "equal".
3217 The Axes aspect ratio can be controlled with `.Axes.set_aspect`.
3218 """
3219 self.set_aspect('equal')
3220 # The use of float32 is "historical", but can't be changed without
3221 # regenerating the test baselines.
3222 x = np.asarray(x, np.float32)
3223 if x.ndim > 1:
3224 raise ValueError("x must be 1D")
3225  
3226 if np.any(x < 0):
3227 raise ValueError("Wedge sizes 'x' must be non negative values")
3228  
3229 sx = x.sum()
3230  
3231 if normalize:
3232 x = x / sx
3233 elif sx > 1:
3234 raise ValueError('Cannot plot an unnormalized pie with sum(x) > 1')
3235 if labels is None:
3236 labels = [''] * len(x)
3237 if explode is None:
3238 explode = [0] * len(x)
3239 if len(x) != len(labels):
3240 raise ValueError("'label' must be of length 'x'")
3241 if len(x) != len(explode):
3242 raise ValueError("'explode' must be of length 'x'")
3243 if colors is None:
3244 get_next_color = self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color
3245 else:
3246 color_cycle = itertools.cycle(colors)
3247  
3248 def get_next_color():
3249 return next(color_cycle)
3250  
3251 hatch_cycle = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(hatch))
3252  
3253 _api.check_isinstance(Real, radius=radius, startangle=startangle)
3254 if radius <= 0:
3255 raise ValueError(f'radius must be a positive number, not {radius}')
3256  
3257 # Starting theta1 is the start fraction of the circle
3258 theta1 = startangle / 360
3259  
3260 if wedgeprops is None:
3261 wedgeprops = {}
3262 if textprops is None:
3263 textprops = {}
3264  
3265 texts = []
3266 slices = []
3267 autotexts = []
3268  
3269 for frac, label, expl in zip(x, labels, explode):
3270 x, y = center
3271 theta2 = (theta1 + frac) if counterclock else (theta1 - frac)
3272 thetam = 2 * np.pi * 0.5 * (theta1 + theta2)
3273 x += expl * math.cos(thetam)
3274 y += expl * math.sin(thetam)
3275  
3276 w = mpatches.Wedge((x, y), radius, 360. * min(theta1, theta2),
3277 360. * max(theta1, theta2),
3278 facecolor=get_next_color(),
3279 hatch=next(hatch_cycle),
3280 clip_on=False,
3281 label=label)
3282 w.set(**wedgeprops)
3283 slices.append(w)
3284 self.add_patch(w)
3285  
3286 if shadow:
3287 # Make sure to add a shadow after the call to add_patch so the
3288 # figure and transform props will be set.
3289 shadow_dict = {'ox': -0.02, 'oy': -0.02, 'label': '_nolegend_'}
3290 if isinstance(shadow, dict):
3291 shadow_dict.update(shadow)
3292 self.add_patch(mpatches.Shadow(w, **shadow_dict))
3293  
3294 if labeldistance is not None:
3295 xt = x + labeldistance * radius * math.cos(thetam)
3296 yt = y + labeldistance * radius * math.sin(thetam)
3297 label_alignment_h = 'left' if xt > 0 else 'right'
3298 label_alignment_v = 'center'
3299 label_rotation = 'horizontal'
3300 if rotatelabels:
3301 label_alignment_v = 'bottom' if yt > 0 else 'top'
3302 label_rotation = (np.rad2deg(thetam)
3303 + (0 if xt > 0 else 180))
3304 t = self.text(xt, yt, label,
3305 clip_on=False,
3306 horizontalalignment=label_alignment_h,
3307 verticalalignment=label_alignment_v,
3308 rotation=label_rotation,
3309 size=mpl.rcParams['xtick.labelsize'])
3310 t.set(**textprops)
3311 texts.append(t)
3312  
3313 if autopct is not None:
3314 xt = x + pctdistance * radius * math.cos(thetam)
3315 yt = y + pctdistance * radius * math.sin(thetam)
3316 if isinstance(autopct, str):
3317 s = autopct % (100. * frac)
3318 elif callable(autopct):
3319 s = autopct(100. * frac)
3320 else:
3321 raise TypeError(
3322 'autopct must be callable or a format string')
3323 t = self.text(xt, yt, s,
3324 clip_on=False,
3325 horizontalalignment='center',
3326 verticalalignment='center')
3327 t.set(**textprops)
3328 autotexts.append(t)
3329  
3330 theta1 = theta2
3331  
3332 if frame:
3333 self._request_autoscale_view()
3334 else:
3335 self.set(frame_on=False, xticks=[], yticks=[],
3336 xlim=(-1.25 + center[0], 1.25 + center[0]),
3337 ylim=(-1.25 + center[1], 1.25 + center[1]))
3338  
3339 if autopct is None:
3340 return slices, texts
3341 else:
3342 return slices, texts, autotexts
3343  
3344 @staticmethod
3345 def _errorevery_to_mask(x, errorevery):
3346 """
3347 Normalize `errorbar`'s *errorevery* to be a boolean mask for data *x*.
3348  
3349 This function is split out to be usable both by 2D and 3D errorbars.
3350 """
3351 if isinstance(errorevery, Integral):
3352 errorevery = (0, errorevery)
3353 if isinstance(errorevery, tuple):
3354 if (len(errorevery) == 2 and
3355 isinstance(errorevery[0], Integral) and
3356 isinstance(errorevery[1], Integral)):
3357 errorevery = slice(errorevery[0], None, errorevery[1])
3358 else:
3359 raise ValueError(
3360 f'{errorevery=!r} is a not a tuple of two integers')
3361 elif isinstance(errorevery, slice):
3362 pass
3363 elif not isinstance(errorevery, str) and np.iterable(errorevery):
3364 try:
3365 x[errorevery] # fancy indexing
3366 except (ValueError, IndexError) as err:
3367 raise ValueError(
3368 f"{errorevery=!r} is iterable but not a valid NumPy fancy "
3369 "index to match 'xerr'/'yerr'") from err
3370 else:
3371 raise ValueError(f"{errorevery=!r} is not a recognized value")
3372 everymask = np.zeros(len(x), bool)
3373 everymask[errorevery] = True
3374 return everymask
3375  
3376 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y", "xerr", "yerr"],
3377 label_namer="y")
3378 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
3379 def errorbar(self, x, y, yerr=None, xerr=None,
3380 fmt='', ecolor=None, elinewidth=None, capsize=None,
3381 barsabove=False, lolims=False, uplims=False,
3382 xlolims=False, xuplims=False, errorevery=1, capthick=None,
3383 **kwargs):
3384 """
3385 Plot y versus x as lines and/or markers with attached errorbars.
3386  
3387 *x*, *y* define the data locations, *xerr*, *yerr* define the errorbar
3388 sizes. By default, this draws the data markers/lines as well as the
3389 errorbars. Use fmt='none' to draw errorbars without any data markers.
3390  
3391 .. versionadded:: 3.7
3392 Caps and error lines are drawn in polar coordinates on polar plots.
3393  
3394  
3395 Parameters
3396 ----------
3397 x, y : float or array-like
3398 The data positions.
3399  
3400 xerr, yerr : float or array-like, shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional
3401 The errorbar sizes:
3402  
3403 - scalar: Symmetric +/- values for all data points.
3404 - shape(N,): Symmetric +/-values for each data point.
3405 - shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row
3406 contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper
3407 errors.
3408 - *None*: No errorbar.
3409  
3410 All values must be >= 0.
3411  
3412 See :doc:`/gallery/statistics/errorbar_features`
3413 for an example on the usage of ``xerr`` and ``yerr``.
3414  
3415 fmt : str, default: ''
3416 The format for the data points / data lines. See `.plot` for
3417 details.
3418  
3419 Use 'none' (case-insensitive) to plot errorbars without any data
3420 markers.
3421  
3422 ecolor : color, default: None
3423 The color of the errorbar lines. If None, use the color of the
3424 line connecting the markers.
3425  
3426 elinewidth : float, default: None
3427 The linewidth of the errorbar lines. If None, the linewidth of
3428 the current style is used.
3429  
3430 capsize : float, default: :rc:`errorbar.capsize`
3431 The length of the error bar caps in points.
3432  
3433 capthick : float, default: None
3434 An alias to the keyword argument *markeredgewidth* (a.k.a. *mew*).
3435 This setting is a more sensible name for the property that
3436 controls the thickness of the error bar cap in points. For
3437 backwards compatibility, if *mew* or *markeredgewidth* are given,
3438 then they will over-ride *capthick*. This may change in future
3439 releases.
3440  
3441 barsabove : bool, default: False
3442 If True, will plot the errorbars above the plot
3443 symbols. Default is below.
3444  
3445 lolims, uplims, xlolims, xuplims : bool or array-like, default: False
3446 These arguments can be used to indicate that a value gives only
3447 upper/lower limits. In that case a caret symbol is used to
3448 indicate this. *lims*-arguments may be scalars, or array-likes of
3449 the same length as *xerr* and *yerr*. To use limits with inverted
3450 axes, `~.Axes.set_xlim` or `~.Axes.set_ylim` must be called before
3451 :meth:`errorbar`. Note the tricky parameter names: setting e.g.
3452 *lolims* to True means that the y-value is a *lower* limit of the
3453 True value, so, only an *upward*-pointing arrow will be drawn!
3454  
3455 errorevery : int or (int, int), default: 1
3456 draws error bars on a subset of the data. *errorevery* =N draws
3457 error bars on the points (x[::N], y[::N]).
3458 *errorevery* =(start, N) draws error bars on the points
3459 (x[start::N], y[start::N]). e.g. errorevery=(6, 3)
3460 adds error bars to the data at (x[6], x[9], x[12], x[15], ...).
3461 Used to avoid overlapping error bars when two series share x-axis
3462 values.
3463  
3464 Returns
3465 -------
3466 `.ErrorbarContainer`
3467 The container contains:
3468  
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
3469 - plotline: `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` instance of x, y plot markers
3470 and/or line.
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
3471 - caplines: A tuple of `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` instances of the error
3472 bar caps.
3473 - barlinecols: A tuple of `.LineCollection` with the horizontal and
3474 vertical error ranges.
3475  
3476 Other Parameters
3477 ----------------
3478 data : indexable object, optional
3479 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
3480  
3481 **kwargs
3482 All other keyword arguments are passed on to the `~.Axes.plot` call
3483 drawing the markers. For example, this code makes big red squares
3484 with thick green edges::
3485  
3486 x, y, yerr = rand(3, 10)
3487 errorbar(x, y, yerr, marker='s', mfc='red',
3488 mec='green', ms=20, mew=4)
3489  
3490 where *mfc*, *mec*, *ms* and *mew* are aliases for the longer
3491 property names, *markerfacecolor*, *markeredgecolor*, *markersize*
3492 and *markeredgewidth*.
3493  
3494 Valid kwargs for the marker properties are:
3495  
3496 - *dashes*
3497 - *dash_capstyle*
3498 - *dash_joinstyle*
3499 - *drawstyle*
3500 - *fillstyle*
3501 - *linestyle*
3502 - *marker*
3503 - *markeredgecolor*
3504 - *markeredgewidth*
3505 - *markerfacecolor*
3506 - *markerfacecoloralt*
3507 - *markersize*
3508 - *markevery*
3509 - *solid_capstyle*
3510 - *solid_joinstyle*
3511  
3512 Refer to the corresponding `.Line2D` property for more details:
3513  
3514 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s
3515 """
3516 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mlines.Line2D)
3517 # Drop anything that comes in as None to use the default instead.
3518 kwargs = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if v is not None}
3519 kwargs.setdefault('zorder', 2)
3520  
3521 # Casting to object arrays preserves units.
3522 if not isinstance(x, np.ndarray):
3523 x = np.asarray(x, dtype=object)
3524 if not isinstance(y, np.ndarray):
3525 y = np.asarray(y, dtype=object)
3526  
3527 def _upcast_err(err):
3528 """
3529 Safely handle tuple of containers that carry units.
3530  
3531 This function covers the case where the input to the xerr/yerr is a
3532 length 2 tuple of equal length ndarray-subclasses that carry the
3533 unit information in the container.
3534  
3535 If we have a tuple of nested numpy array (subclasses), we defer
3536 coercing the units to be consistent to the underlying unit
3537 library (and implicitly the broadcasting).
3538  
3539 Otherwise, fallback to casting to an object array.
3540 """
3541  
3542 if (
3543 # make sure it is not a scalar
3544 np.iterable(err) and
3545 # and it is not empty
3546 len(err) > 0 and
3547 # and the first element is an array sub-class use
3548 # safe_first_element because getitem is index-first not
3549 # location first on pandas objects so err[0] almost always
3550 # fails.
3551 isinstance(cbook._safe_first_finite(err), np.ndarray)
3552 ):
3553 # Get the type of the first element
3554 atype = type(cbook._safe_first_finite(err))
3555 # Promote the outer container to match the inner container
3556 if atype is np.ndarray:
3557 # Converts using np.asarray, because data cannot
3558 # be directly passed to init of np.ndarray
3559 return np.asarray(err, dtype=object)
3560 # If atype is not np.ndarray, directly pass data to init.
3561 # This works for types such as unyts and astropy units
3562 return atype(err)
3563 # Otherwise wrap it in an object array
3564 return np.asarray(err, dtype=object)
3565  
3566 if xerr is not None and not isinstance(xerr, np.ndarray):
3567 xerr = _upcast_err(xerr)
3568 if yerr is not None and not isinstance(yerr, np.ndarray):
3569 yerr = _upcast_err(yerr)
3570 x, y = np.atleast_1d(x, y) # Make sure all the args are iterable.
3571 if len(x) != len(y):
3572 raise ValueError("'x' and 'y' must have the same size")
3573  
3574 everymask = self._errorevery_to_mask(x, errorevery)
3575  
3576 label = kwargs.pop("label", None)
3577 kwargs['label'] = '_nolegend_'
3578  
3579 # Create the main line and determine overall kwargs for child artists.
3580 # We avoid calling self.plot() directly, or self._get_lines(), because
3581 # that would call self._process_unit_info again, and do other indirect
3582 # data processing.
3583 (data_line, base_style), = self._get_lines._plot_args(
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
3584 self, (x, y) if fmt == '' else (x, y, fmt), kwargs, return_kwargs=True)
3585  
3586 # Do this after creating `data_line` to avoid modifying `base_style`.
3587 if barsabove:
3588 data_line.set_zorder(kwargs['zorder'] - .1)
3589 else:
3590 data_line.set_zorder(kwargs['zorder'] + .1)
3591  
3592 # Add line to plot, or throw it away and use it to determine kwargs.
3593 if fmt.lower() != 'none':
3594 self.add_line(data_line)
3595 else:
3596 data_line = None
3597 # Remove alpha=0 color that _get_lines._plot_args returns for
3598 # 'none' format, and replace it with user-specified color, if
3599 # supplied.
3600 base_style.pop('color')
3601 if 'color' in kwargs:
3602 base_style['color'] = kwargs.pop('color')
3603  
3604 if 'color' not in base_style:
3605 base_style['color'] = 'C0'
3606 if ecolor is None:
3607 ecolor = base_style['color']
3608  
3609 # Eject any line-specific information from format string, as it's not
3610 # needed for bars or caps.
3611 for key in ['marker', 'markersize', 'markerfacecolor',
3612 'markerfacecoloralt',
3613 'markeredgewidth', 'markeredgecolor', 'markevery',
3614 'linestyle', 'fillstyle', 'drawstyle', 'dash_capstyle',
3615 'dash_joinstyle', 'solid_capstyle', 'solid_joinstyle',
3616 'dashes']:
3617 base_style.pop(key, None)
3618  
3619 # Make the style dict for the line collections (the bars).
3620 eb_lines_style = {**base_style, 'color': ecolor}
3621  
3622 if elinewidth is not None:
3623 eb_lines_style['linewidth'] = elinewidth
3624 elif 'linewidth' in kwargs:
3625 eb_lines_style['linewidth'] = kwargs['linewidth']
3626  
3627 for key in ('transform', 'alpha', 'zorder', 'rasterized'):
3628 if key in kwargs:
3629 eb_lines_style[key] = kwargs[key]
3630  
3631 # Make the style dict for caps (the "hats").
3632 eb_cap_style = {**base_style, 'linestyle': 'none'}
3633 if capsize is None:
3634 capsize = mpl.rcParams["errorbar.capsize"]
3635 if capsize > 0:
3636 eb_cap_style['markersize'] = 2. * capsize
3637 if capthick is not None:
3638 eb_cap_style['markeredgewidth'] = capthick
3639  
3640 # For backwards-compat, allow explicit setting of
3641 # 'markeredgewidth' to over-ride capthick.
3642 for key in ('markeredgewidth', 'transform', 'alpha',
3643 'zorder', 'rasterized'):
3644 if key in kwargs:
3645 eb_cap_style[key] = kwargs[key]
3646 eb_cap_style['color'] = ecolor
3647  
3648 barcols = []
3649 caplines = {'x': [], 'y': []}
3650  
3651 # Vectorized fancy-indexer.
3652 def apply_mask(arrays, mask):
3653 return [array[mask] for array in arrays]
3654  
3655 # dep: dependent dataset, indep: independent dataset
3656 for (dep_axis, dep, err, lolims, uplims, indep, lines_func,
3657 marker, lomarker, himarker) in [
3658 ("x", x, xerr, xlolims, xuplims, y, self.hlines,
3659 "|", mlines.CARETRIGHTBASE, mlines.CARETLEFTBASE),
3660 ("y", y, yerr, lolims, uplims, x, self.vlines,
3661 "_", mlines.CARETUPBASE, mlines.CARETDOWNBASE),
3662 ]:
3663 if err is None:
3664 continue
3665 lolims = np.broadcast_to(lolims, len(dep)).astype(bool)
3666 uplims = np.broadcast_to(uplims, len(dep)).astype(bool)
3667 try:
3668 np.broadcast_to(err, (2, len(dep)))
3669 except ValueError:
3670 raise ValueError(
3671 f"'{dep_axis}err' (shape: {np.shape(err)}) must be a "
3672 f"scalar or a 1D or (2, n) array-like whose shape matches "
3673 f"'{dep_axis}' (shape: {np.shape(dep)})") from None
3674 res = np.zeros(err.shape, dtype=bool) # Default in case of nan
3675 if np.any(np.less(err, -err, out=res, where=(err == err))):
3676 # like err<0, but also works for timedelta and nan.
3677 raise ValueError(
3678 f"'{dep_axis}err' must not contain negative values")
3679 # This is like
3680 # elow, ehigh = np.broadcast_to(...)
3681 # return dep - elow * ~lolims, dep + ehigh * ~uplims
3682 # except that broadcast_to would strip units.
3683 low, high = dep + np.vstack([-(1 - lolims), 1 - uplims]) * err
3684 barcols.append(lines_func(
3685 *apply_mask([indep, low, high], everymask), **eb_lines_style))
3686 if self.name == "polar" and dep_axis == "x":
3687 for b in barcols:
3688 for p in b.get_paths():
3689 p._interpolation_steps = 2
3690 # Normal errorbars for points without upper/lower limits.
3691 nolims = ~(lolims | uplims)
3692 if nolims.any() and capsize > 0:
3693 indep_masked, lo_masked, hi_masked = apply_mask(
3694 [indep, low, high], nolims & everymask)
3695 for lh_masked in [lo_masked, hi_masked]:
3696 # Since this has to work for x and y as dependent data, we
3697 # first set both x and y to the independent variable and
3698 # overwrite the respective dependent data in a second step.
3699 line = mlines.Line2D(indep_masked, indep_masked,
3700 marker=marker, **eb_cap_style)
3701 line.set(**{f"{dep_axis}data": lh_masked})
3702 caplines[dep_axis].append(line)
3703 for idx, (lims, hl) in enumerate([(lolims, high), (uplims, low)]):
3704 if not lims.any():
3705 continue
3706 hlmarker = (
3707 himarker
3708 if self._axis_map[dep_axis].get_inverted() ^ idx
3709 else lomarker)
3710 x_masked, y_masked, hl_masked = apply_mask(
3711 [x, y, hl], lims & everymask)
3712 # As above, we set the dependent data in a second step.
3713 line = mlines.Line2D(x_masked, y_masked,
3714 marker=hlmarker, **eb_cap_style)
3715 line.set(**{f"{dep_axis}data": hl_masked})
3716 caplines[dep_axis].append(line)
3717 if capsize > 0:
3718 caplines[dep_axis].append(mlines.Line2D(
3719 x_masked, y_masked, marker=marker, **eb_cap_style))
3720 if self.name == 'polar':
3721 for axis in caplines:
  • E741 Ambiguous variable name 'l'
3722 for l in caplines[axis]:
3723 # Rotate caps to be perpendicular to the error bars
3724 for theta, r in zip(l.get_xdata(), l.get_ydata()):
3725 rotation = mtransforms.Affine2D().rotate(theta)
3726 if axis == 'y':
3727 rotation.rotate(-np.pi / 2)
3728 ms = mmarkers.MarkerStyle(marker=marker,
3729 transform=rotation)
3730 self.add_line(mlines.Line2D([theta], [r], marker=ms,
3731 **eb_cap_style))
3732 else:
3733 for axis in caplines:
  • E741 Ambiguous variable name 'l'
3734 for l in caplines[axis]:
3735 self.add_line(l)
3736  
3737 self._request_autoscale_view()
3738 caplines = caplines['x'] + caplines['y']
3739 errorbar_container = ErrorbarContainer(
3740 (data_line, tuple(caplines), tuple(barcols)),
3741 has_xerr=(xerr is not None), has_yerr=(yerr is not None),
3742 label=label)
3743 self.containers.append(errorbar_container)
3744  
3745 return errorbar_container # (l0, caplines, barcols)
3746  
3747 @_preprocess_data()
3748 def boxplot(self, x, notch=None, sym=None, vert=None, whis=None,
3749 positions=None, widths=None, patch_artist=None,
3750 bootstrap=None, usermedians=None, conf_intervals=None,
3751 meanline=None, showmeans=None, showcaps=None,
3752 showbox=None, showfliers=None, boxprops=None,
3753 labels=None, flierprops=None, medianprops=None,
3754 meanprops=None, capprops=None, whiskerprops=None,
3755 manage_ticks=True, autorange=False, zorder=None,
3756 capwidths=None):
3757 """
3758 Draw a box and whisker plot.
3759  
3760 The box extends from the first quartile (Q1) to the third
3761 quartile (Q3) of the data, with a line at the median.
3762 The whiskers extend from the box to the farthest data point
3763 lying within 1.5x the inter-quartile range (IQR) from the box.
3764 Flier points are those past the end of the whiskers.
3765 See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Box_plot for reference.
3766  
3767 .. code-block:: none
3768  
3769 Q1-1.5IQR Q1 median Q3 Q3+1.5IQR
3770 |-----:-----|
3771 o |--------| : |--------| o o
3772 |-----:-----|
3773 flier <-----------> fliers
3774 IQR
3775  
3776  
3777 Parameters
3778 ----------
3779 x : Array or a sequence of vectors.
3780 The input data. If a 2D array, a boxplot is drawn for each column
3781 in *x*. If a sequence of 1D arrays, a boxplot is drawn for each
3782 array in *x*.
3783  
3784 notch : bool, default: False
3785 Whether to draw a notched boxplot (`True`), or a rectangular
3786 boxplot (`False`). The notches represent the confidence interval
3787 (CI) around the median. The documentation for *bootstrap*
3788 describes how the locations of the notches are computed by
3789 default, but their locations may also be overridden by setting the
3790 *conf_intervals* parameter.
3791  
3792 .. note::
3793  
3794 In cases where the values of the CI are less than the
3795 lower quartile or greater than the upper quartile, the
3796 notches will extend beyond the box, giving it a
3797 distinctive "flipped" appearance. This is expected
3798 behavior and consistent with other statistical
3799 visualization packages.
3800  
3801 sym : str, optional
3802 The default symbol for flier points. An empty string ('') hides
3803 the fliers. If `None`, then the fliers default to 'b+'. More
3804 control is provided by the *flierprops* parameter.
3805  
3806 vert : bool, default: True
3807 If `True`, draws vertical boxes.
3808 If `False`, draw horizontal boxes.
3809  
3810 whis : float or (float, float), default: 1.5
3811 The position of the whiskers.
3812  
3813 If a float, the lower whisker is at the lowest datum above
3814 ``Q1 - whis*(Q3-Q1)``, and the upper whisker at the highest datum
3815 below ``Q3 + whis*(Q3-Q1)``, where Q1 and Q3 are the first and
3816 third quartiles. The default value of ``whis = 1.5`` corresponds
3817 to Tukey's original definition of boxplots.
3818  
3819 If a pair of floats, they indicate the percentiles at which to
3820 draw the whiskers (e.g., (5, 95)). In particular, setting this to
3821 (0, 100) results in whiskers covering the whole range of the data.
3822  
3823 In the edge case where ``Q1 == Q3``, *whis* is automatically set
3824 to (0, 100) (cover the whole range of the data) if *autorange* is
3825 True.
3826  
3827 Beyond the whiskers, data are considered outliers and are plotted
3828 as individual points.
3829  
3830 bootstrap : int, optional
3831 Specifies whether to bootstrap the confidence intervals
3832 around the median for notched boxplots. If *bootstrap* is
3833 None, no bootstrapping is performed, and notches are
3834 calculated using a Gaussian-based asymptotic approximation
3835 (see McGill, R., Tukey, J.W., and Larsen, W.A., 1978, and
3836 Kendall and Stuart, 1967). Otherwise, bootstrap specifies
3837 the number of times to bootstrap the median to determine its
3838 95% confidence intervals. Values between 1000 and 10000 are
3839 recommended.
3840  
3841 usermedians : 1D array-like, optional
3842 A 1D array-like of length ``len(x)``. Each entry that is not
3843 `None` forces the value of the median for the corresponding
3844 dataset. For entries that are `None`, the medians are computed
3845 by Matplotlib as normal.
3846  
3847 conf_intervals : array-like, optional
3848 A 2D array-like of shape ``(len(x), 2)``. Each entry that is not
3849 None forces the location of the corresponding notch (which is
3850 only drawn if *notch* is `True`). For entries that are `None`,
3851 the notches are computed by the method specified by the other
3852 parameters (e.g., *bootstrap*).
3853  
3854 positions : array-like, optional
3855 The positions of the boxes. The ticks and limits are
3856 automatically set to match the positions. Defaults to
3857 ``range(1, N+1)`` where N is the number of boxes to be drawn.
3858  
3859 widths : float or array-like
3860 The widths of the boxes. The default is 0.5, or ``0.15*(distance
3861 between extreme positions)``, if that is smaller.
3862  
3863 patch_artist : bool, default: False
3864 If `False` produces boxes with the Line2D artist. Otherwise,
3865 boxes are drawn with Patch artists.
3866  
3867 labels : sequence, optional
3868 Labels for each dataset (one per dataset).
3869  
3870 manage_ticks : bool, default: True
3871 If True, the tick locations and labels will be adjusted to match
3872 the boxplot positions.
3873  
3874 autorange : bool, default: False
3875 When `True` and the data are distributed such that the 25th and
3876 75th percentiles are equal, *whis* is set to (0, 100) such
3877 that the whisker ends are at the minimum and maximum of the data.
3878  
3879 meanline : bool, default: False
3880 If `True` (and *showmeans* is `True`), will try to render the
3881 mean as a line spanning the full width of the box according to
3882 *meanprops* (see below). Not recommended if *shownotches* is also
3883 True. Otherwise, means will be shown as points.
3884  
3885 zorder : float, default: ``Line2D.zorder = 2``
3886 The zorder of the boxplot.
3887  
3888 Returns
3889 -------
3890 dict
3891 A dictionary mapping each component of the boxplot to a list
3892 of the `.Line2D` instances created. That dictionary has the
3893 following keys (assuming vertical boxplots):
3894  
3895 - ``boxes``: the main body of the boxplot showing the
3896 quartiles and the median's confidence intervals if
3897 enabled.
3898  
3899 - ``medians``: horizontal lines at the median of each box.
3900  
3901 - ``whiskers``: the vertical lines extending to the most
3902 extreme, non-outlier data points.
3903  
3904 - ``caps``: the horizontal lines at the ends of the
3905 whiskers.
3906  
3907 - ``fliers``: points representing data that extend beyond
3908 the whiskers (fliers).
3909  
3910 - ``means``: points or lines representing the means.
3911  
3912 Other Parameters
3913 ----------------
3914 showcaps : bool, default: True
3915 Show the caps on the ends of whiskers.
3916 showbox : bool, default: True
3917 Show the central box.
3918 showfliers : bool, default: True
3919 Show the outliers beyond the caps.
3920 showmeans : bool, default: False
3921 Show the arithmetic means.
3922 capprops : dict, default: None
3923 The style of the caps.
3924 capwidths : float or array, default: None
3925 The widths of the caps.
3926 boxprops : dict, default: None
3927 The style of the box.
3928 whiskerprops : dict, default: None
3929 The style of the whiskers.
3930 flierprops : dict, default: None
3931 The style of the fliers.
3932 medianprops : dict, default: None
3933 The style of the median.
3934 meanprops : dict, default: None
3935 The style of the mean.
3936 data : indexable object, optional
3937 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
3938  
3939 See Also
3940 --------
3941 violinplot : Draw an estimate of the probability density function.
3942 """
3943  
3944 # Missing arguments default to rcParams.
3945 if whis is None:
3946 whis = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.whiskers']
3947 if bootstrap is None:
3948 bootstrap = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.bootstrap']
3949  
3950 bxpstats = cbook.boxplot_stats(x, whis=whis, bootstrap=bootstrap,
3951 labels=labels, autorange=autorange)
3952 if notch is None:
3953 notch = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.notch']
3954 if vert is None:
3955 vert = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.vertical']
3956 if patch_artist is None:
3957 patch_artist = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.patchartist']
3958 if meanline is None:
3959 meanline = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.meanline']
3960 if showmeans is None:
3961 showmeans = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.showmeans']
3962 if showcaps is None:
3963 showcaps = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.showcaps']
3964 if showbox is None:
3965 showbox = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.showbox']
3966 if showfliers is None:
3967 showfliers = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.showfliers']
3968  
3969 if boxprops is None:
3970 boxprops = {}
3971 if whiskerprops is None:
3972 whiskerprops = {}
3973 if capprops is None:
3974 capprops = {}
3975 if medianprops is None:
3976 medianprops = {}
3977 if meanprops is None:
3978 meanprops = {}
3979 if flierprops is None:
3980 flierprops = {}
3981  
3982 if patch_artist:
3983 boxprops['linestyle'] = 'solid' # Not consistent with bxp.
3984 if 'color' in boxprops:
3985 boxprops['edgecolor'] = boxprops.pop('color')
3986  
3987 # if non-default sym value, put it into the flier dictionary
3988 # the logic for providing the default symbol ('b+') now lives
3989 # in bxp in the initial value of flierkw
3990 # handle all of the *sym* related logic here so we only have to pass
3991 # on the flierprops dict.
3992 if sym is not None:
3993 # no-flier case, which should really be done with
3994 # 'showfliers=False' but none-the-less deal with it to keep back
3995 # compatibility
3996 if sym == '':
3997 # blow away existing dict and make one for invisible markers
3998 flierprops = dict(linestyle='none', marker='', color='none')
3999 # turn the fliers off just to be safe
4000 showfliers = False
4001 # now process the symbol string
4002 else:
4003 # process the symbol string
4004 # discarded linestyle
4005 _, marker, color = _process_plot_format(sym)
4006 # if we have a marker, use it
4007 if marker is not None:
4008 flierprops['marker'] = marker
4009 # if we have a color, use it
4010 if color is not None:
4011 # assume that if color is passed in the user want
4012 # filled symbol, if the users want more control use
4013 # flierprops
4014 flierprops['color'] = color
4015 flierprops['markerfacecolor'] = color
4016 flierprops['markeredgecolor'] = color
4017  
4018 # replace medians if necessary:
4019 if usermedians is not None:
4020 if (len(np.ravel(usermedians)) != len(bxpstats) or
4021 np.shape(usermedians)[0] != len(bxpstats)):
4022 raise ValueError(
4023 "'usermedians' and 'x' have different lengths")
4024 else:
4025 # reassign medians as necessary
4026 for stats, med in zip(bxpstats, usermedians):
4027 if med is not None:
4028 stats['med'] = med
4029  
4030 if conf_intervals is not None:
4031 if len(conf_intervals) != len(bxpstats):
4032 raise ValueError(
4033 "'conf_intervals' and 'x' have different lengths")
4034 else:
4035 for stats, ci in zip(bxpstats, conf_intervals):
4036 if ci is not None:
4037 if len(ci) != 2:
4038 raise ValueError('each confidence interval must '
4039 'have two values')
4040 else:
4041 if ci[0] is not None:
4042 stats['cilo'] = ci[0]
4043 if ci[1] is not None:
4044 stats['cihi'] = ci[1]
4045  
4046 artists = self.bxp(bxpstats, positions=positions, widths=widths,
4047 vert=vert, patch_artist=patch_artist,
4048 shownotches=notch, showmeans=showmeans,
4049 showcaps=showcaps, showbox=showbox,
4050 boxprops=boxprops, flierprops=flierprops,
4051 medianprops=medianprops, meanprops=meanprops,
4052 meanline=meanline, showfliers=showfliers,
4053 capprops=capprops, whiskerprops=whiskerprops,
4054 manage_ticks=manage_ticks, zorder=zorder,
4055 capwidths=capwidths)
4056 return artists
4057  
4058 def bxp(self, bxpstats, positions=None, widths=None, vert=True,
4059 patch_artist=False, shownotches=False, showmeans=False,
4060 showcaps=True, showbox=True, showfliers=True,
4061 boxprops=None, whiskerprops=None, flierprops=None,
4062 medianprops=None, capprops=None, meanprops=None,
4063 meanline=False, manage_ticks=True, zorder=None,
4064 capwidths=None):
4065 """
4066 Drawing function for box and whisker plots.
4067  
4068 Make a box and whisker plot for each column of *x* or each
4069 vector in sequence *x*. The box extends from the lower to
4070 upper quartile values of the data, with a line at the median.
4071 The whiskers extend from the box to show the range of the
4072 data. Flier points are those past the end of the whiskers.
4073  
4074 Parameters
4075 ----------
4076 bxpstats : list of dicts
4077 A list of dictionaries containing stats for each boxplot.
4078 Required keys are:
4079  
4080 - ``med``: Median (scalar).
4081 - ``q1``, ``q3``: First & third quartiles (scalars).
4082 - ``whislo``, ``whishi``: Lower & upper whisker positions (scalars).
4083  
4084 Optional keys are:
4085  
4086 - ``mean``: Mean (scalar). Needed if ``showmeans=True``.
4087 - ``fliers``: Data beyond the whiskers (array-like).
4088 Needed if ``showfliers=True``.
4089 - ``cilo``, ``cihi``: Lower & upper confidence intervals
4090 about the median. Needed if ``shownotches=True``.
4091 - ``label``: Name of the dataset (str). If available,
4092 this will be used a tick label for the boxplot
4093  
4094 positions : array-like, default: [1, 2, ..., n]
4095 The positions of the boxes. The ticks and limits
4096 are automatically set to match the positions.
4097  
4098 widths : float or array-like, default: None
4099 The widths of the boxes. The default is
4100 ``clip(0.15*(distance between extreme positions), 0.15, 0.5)``.
4101  
4102 capwidths : float or array-like, default: None
4103 Either a scalar or a vector and sets the width of each cap.
4104 The default is ``0.5*(width of the box)``, see *widths*.
4105  
4106 vert : bool, default: True
4107 If `True` (default), makes the boxes vertical.
4108 If `False`, makes horizontal boxes.
4109  
4110 patch_artist : bool, default: False
4111 If `False` produces boxes with the `.Line2D` artist.
4112 If `True` produces boxes with the `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` artist.
4113  
4114 shownotches, showmeans, showcaps, showbox, showfliers : bool
4115 Whether to draw the CI notches, the mean value (both default to
4116 False), the caps, the box, and the fliers (all three default to
4117 True).
4118  
4119 boxprops, whiskerprops, capprops, flierprops, medianprops, meanprops :\
4120 dict, optional
4121 Artist properties for the boxes, whiskers, caps, fliers, medians, and
4122 means.
4123  
4124 meanline : bool, default: False
4125 If `True` (and *showmeans* is `True`), will try to render the mean
4126 as a line spanning the full width of the box according to
4127 *meanprops*. Not recommended if *shownotches* is also True.
4128 Otherwise, means will be shown as points.
4129  
4130 manage_ticks : bool, default: True
4131 If True, the tick locations and labels will be adjusted to match the
4132 boxplot positions.
4133  
4134 zorder : float, default: ``Line2D.zorder = 2``
4135 The zorder of the resulting boxplot.
4136  
4137 Returns
4138 -------
4139 dict
4140 A dictionary mapping each component of the boxplot to a list
4141 of the `.Line2D` instances created. That dictionary has the
4142 following keys (assuming vertical boxplots):
4143  
4144 - ``boxes``: main bodies of the boxplot showing the quartiles, and
4145 the median's confidence intervals if enabled.
4146 - ``medians``: horizontal lines at the median of each box.
4147 - ``whiskers``: vertical lines up to the last non-outlier data.
4148 - ``caps``: horizontal lines at the ends of the whiskers.
4149 - ``fliers``: points representing data beyond the whiskers (fliers).
4150 - ``means``: points or lines representing the means.
4151  
4152 Examples
4153 --------
4154 .. plot:: gallery/statistics/bxp.py
4155 """
4156 # Clamp median line to edge of box by default.
4157 medianprops = {
4158 "solid_capstyle": "butt",
4159 "dash_capstyle": "butt",
4160 **(medianprops or {}),
4161 }
4162 meanprops = {
4163 "solid_capstyle": "butt",
4164 "dash_capstyle": "butt",
4165 **(meanprops or {}),
4166 }
4167  
4168 # lists of artists to be output
4169 whiskers = []
4170 caps = []
4171 boxes = []
4172 medians = []
4173 means = []
4174 fliers = []
4175  
4176 # empty list of xticklabels
4177 datalabels = []
4178  
4179 # Use default zorder if none specified
4180 if zorder is None:
4181 zorder = mlines.Line2D.zorder
4182  
4183 zdelta = 0.1
4184  
4185 def merge_kw_rc(subkey, explicit, zdelta=0, usemarker=True):
4186 d = {k.split('.')[-1]: v for k, v in mpl.rcParams.items()
4187 if k.startswith(f'boxplot.{subkey}props')}
4188 d['zorder'] = zorder + zdelta
4189 if not usemarker:
4190 d['marker'] = ''
4191 d.update(cbook.normalize_kwargs(explicit, mlines.Line2D))
4192 return d
4193  
4194 box_kw = {
4195 'linestyle': mpl.rcParams['boxplot.boxprops.linestyle'],
4196 'linewidth': mpl.rcParams['boxplot.boxprops.linewidth'],
4197 'edgecolor': mpl.rcParams['boxplot.boxprops.color'],
4198 'facecolor': ('white' if mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode']
4199 else mpl.rcParams['patch.facecolor']),
4200 'zorder': zorder,
4201 **cbook.normalize_kwargs(boxprops, mpatches.PathPatch)
4202 } if patch_artist else merge_kw_rc('box', boxprops, usemarker=False)
4203 whisker_kw = merge_kw_rc('whisker', whiskerprops, usemarker=False)
4204 cap_kw = merge_kw_rc('cap', capprops, usemarker=False)
4205 flier_kw = merge_kw_rc('flier', flierprops)
4206 median_kw = merge_kw_rc('median', medianprops, zdelta, usemarker=False)
4207 mean_kw = merge_kw_rc('mean', meanprops, zdelta)
4208 removed_prop = 'marker' if meanline else 'linestyle'
4209 # Only remove the property if it's not set explicitly as a parameter.
4210 if meanprops is None or removed_prop not in meanprops:
4211 mean_kw[removed_prop] = ''
4212  
4213 # vertical or horizontal plot?
4214 maybe_swap = slice(None) if vert else slice(None, None, -1)
4215  
4216 def do_plot(xs, ys, **kwargs):
4217 return self.plot(*[xs, ys][maybe_swap], **kwargs)[0]
4218  
4219 def do_patch(xs, ys, **kwargs):
4220 path = mpath.Path._create_closed(
4221 np.column_stack([xs, ys][maybe_swap]))
4222 patch = mpatches.PathPatch(path, **kwargs)
4223 self.add_artist(patch)
4224 return patch
4225  
4226 # input validation
4227 N = len(bxpstats)
4228 datashape_message = ("List of boxplot statistics and `{0}` "
4229 "values must have same the length")
4230 # check position
4231 if positions is None:
4232 positions = list(range(1, N + 1))
4233 elif len(positions) != N:
4234 raise ValueError(datashape_message.format("positions"))
4235  
4236 positions = np.array(positions)
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
4237 if len(positions) > 0 and not all(isinstance(p, Real) for p in positions):
4238 raise TypeError("positions should be an iterable of numbers")
4239  
4240 # width
4241 if widths is None:
4242 widths = [np.clip(0.15 * np.ptp(positions), 0.15, 0.5)] * N
4243 elif np.isscalar(widths):
4244 widths = [widths] * N
4245 elif len(widths) != N:
4246 raise ValueError(datashape_message.format("widths"))
4247  
4248 # capwidth
4249 if capwidths is None:
4250 capwidths = 0.5 * np.array(widths)
4251 elif np.isscalar(capwidths):
4252 capwidths = [capwidths] * N
4253 elif len(capwidths) != N:
4254 raise ValueError(datashape_message.format("capwidths"))
4255  
4256 for pos, width, stats, capwidth in zip(positions, widths, bxpstats,
4257 capwidths):
4258 # try to find a new label
4259 datalabels.append(stats.get('label', pos))
4260  
4261 # whisker coords
4262 whis_x = [pos, pos]
4263 whislo_y = [stats['q1'], stats['whislo']]
4264 whishi_y = [stats['q3'], stats['whishi']]
4265 # cap coords
4266 cap_left = pos - capwidth * 0.5
4267 cap_right = pos + capwidth * 0.5
4268 cap_x = [cap_left, cap_right]
4269 cap_lo = np.full(2, stats['whislo'])
4270 cap_hi = np.full(2, stats['whishi'])
4271 # box and median coords
4272 box_left = pos - width * 0.5
4273 box_right = pos + width * 0.5
4274 med_y = [stats['med'], stats['med']]
4275 # notched boxes
4276 if shownotches:
4277 notch_left = pos - width * 0.25
4278 notch_right = pos + width * 0.25
4279 box_x = [box_left, box_right, box_right, notch_right,
4280 box_right, box_right, box_left, box_left, notch_left,
4281 box_left, box_left]
4282 box_y = [stats['q1'], stats['q1'], stats['cilo'],
4283 stats['med'], stats['cihi'], stats['q3'],
4284 stats['q3'], stats['cihi'], stats['med'],
4285 stats['cilo'], stats['q1']]
4286 med_x = [notch_left, notch_right]
4287 # plain boxes
4288 else:
4289 box_x = [box_left, box_right, box_right, box_left, box_left]
4290 box_y = [stats['q1'], stats['q1'], stats['q3'], stats['q3'],
4291 stats['q1']]
4292 med_x = [box_left, box_right]
4293  
4294 # maybe draw the box
4295 if showbox:
4296 do_box = do_patch if patch_artist else do_plot
4297 boxes.append(do_box(box_x, box_y, **box_kw))
4298 # draw the whiskers
4299 whiskers.append(do_plot(whis_x, whislo_y, **whisker_kw))
4300 whiskers.append(do_plot(whis_x, whishi_y, **whisker_kw))
4301 # maybe draw the caps
4302 if showcaps:
4303 caps.append(do_plot(cap_x, cap_lo, **cap_kw))
4304 caps.append(do_plot(cap_x, cap_hi, **cap_kw))
4305 # draw the medians
4306 medians.append(do_plot(med_x, med_y, **median_kw))
4307 # maybe draw the means
4308 if showmeans:
4309 if meanline:
4310 means.append(do_plot(
4311 [box_left, box_right], [stats['mean'], stats['mean']],
4312 **mean_kw
4313 ))
4314 else:
4315 means.append(do_plot([pos], [stats['mean']], **mean_kw))
4316 # maybe draw the fliers
4317 if showfliers:
4318 flier_x = np.full(len(stats['fliers']), pos, dtype=np.float64)
4319 flier_y = stats['fliers']
4320 fliers.append(do_plot(flier_x, flier_y, **flier_kw))
4321  
4322 if manage_ticks:
4323 axis_name = "x" if vert else "y"
4324 interval = getattr(self.dataLim, f"interval{axis_name}")
4325 axis = self._axis_map[axis_name]
4326 positions = axis.convert_units(positions)
4327 # The 0.5 additional padding ensures reasonable-looking boxes
4328 # even when drawing a single box. We set the sticky edge to
4329 # prevent margins expansion, in order to match old behavior (back
4330 # when separate calls to boxplot() would completely reset the axis
4331 # limits regardless of what was drawn before). The sticky edges
4332 # are attached to the median lines, as they are always present.
4333 interval[:] = (min(interval[0], min(positions) - .5),
4334 max(interval[1], max(positions) + .5))
4335 for median, position in zip(medians, positions):
4336 getattr(median.sticky_edges, axis_name).extend(
4337 [position - .5, position + .5])
4338 # Modified from Axis.set_ticks and Axis.set_ticklabels.
4339 locator = axis.get_major_locator()
4340 if not isinstance(axis.get_major_locator(),
4341 mticker.FixedLocator):
4342 locator = mticker.FixedLocator([])
4343 axis.set_major_locator(locator)
4344 locator.locs = np.array([*locator.locs, *positions])
4345 formatter = axis.get_major_formatter()
4346 if not isinstance(axis.get_major_formatter(),
4347 mticker.FixedFormatter):
4348 formatter = mticker.FixedFormatter([])
4349 axis.set_major_formatter(formatter)
4350 formatter.seq = [*formatter.seq, *datalabels]
4351  
4352 self._request_autoscale_view()
4353  
4354 return dict(whiskers=whiskers, caps=caps, boxes=boxes,
4355 medians=medians, fliers=fliers, means=means)
4356  
4357 @staticmethod
4358 def _parse_scatter_color_args(c, edgecolors, kwargs, xsize,
4359 get_next_color_func):
4360 """
4361 Helper function to process color related arguments of `.Axes.scatter`.
4362  
4363 Argument precedence for facecolors:
4364  
4365 - c (if not None)
4366 - kwargs['facecolor']
4367 - kwargs['facecolors']
4368 - kwargs['color'] (==kwcolor)
4369 - 'b' if in classic mode else the result of ``get_next_color_func()``
4370  
4371 Argument precedence for edgecolors:
4372  
4373 - kwargs['edgecolor']
4374 - edgecolors (is an explicit kw argument in scatter())
4375 - kwargs['color'] (==kwcolor)
4376 - 'face' if not in classic mode else None
4377  
4378 Parameters
4379 ----------
4380 c : color or sequence or sequence of color or None
4381 See argument description of `.Axes.scatter`.
4382 edgecolors : color or sequence of color or {'face', 'none'} or None
4383 See argument description of `.Axes.scatter`.
4384 kwargs : dict
4385 Additional kwargs. If these keys exist, we pop and process them:
4386 'facecolors', 'facecolor', 'edgecolor', 'color'
4387 Note: The dict is modified by this function.
4388 xsize : int
4389 The size of the x and y arrays passed to `.Axes.scatter`.
4390 get_next_color_func : callable
4391 A callable that returns a color. This color is used as facecolor
4392 if no other color is provided.
4393  
4394 Note, that this is a function rather than a fixed color value to
4395 support conditional evaluation of the next color. As of the
4396 current implementation obtaining the next color from the
4397 property cycle advances the cycle. This must only happen if we
4398 actually use the color, which will only be decided within this
4399 method.
4400  
4401 Returns
4402 -------
4403 c
4404 The input *c* if it was not *None*, else a color derived from the
4405 other inputs or defaults.
4406 colors : array(N, 4) or None
4407 The facecolors as RGBA values, or *None* if a colormap is used.
4408 edgecolors
4409 The edgecolor.
4410  
4411 """
4412 facecolors = kwargs.pop('facecolors', None)
4413 facecolors = kwargs.pop('facecolor', facecolors)
4414 edgecolors = kwargs.pop('edgecolor', edgecolors)
4415  
4416 kwcolor = kwargs.pop('color', None)
4417  
4418 if kwcolor is not None and c is not None:
4419 raise ValueError("Supply a 'c' argument or a 'color'"
4420 " kwarg but not both; they differ but"
4421 " their functionalities overlap.")
4422  
4423 if kwcolor is not None:
4424 try:
4425 mcolors.to_rgba_array(kwcolor)
4426 except ValueError as err:
4427 raise ValueError(
4428 "'color' kwarg must be a color or sequence of color "
4429 "specs. For a sequence of values to be color-mapped, use "
4430 "the 'c' argument instead.") from err
4431 if edgecolors is None:
4432 edgecolors = kwcolor
4433 if facecolors is None:
4434 facecolors = kwcolor
4435  
4436 if edgecolors is None and not mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode']:
4437 edgecolors = mpl.rcParams['scatter.edgecolors']
4438  
4439 c_was_none = c is None
4440 if c is None:
4441 c = (facecolors if facecolors is not None
4442 else "b" if mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode']
4443 else get_next_color_func())
4444 c_is_string_or_strings = (
4445 isinstance(c, str)
4446 or (np.iterable(c) and len(c) > 0
4447 and isinstance(cbook._safe_first_finite(c), str)))
4448  
4449 def invalid_shape_exception(csize, xsize):
4450 return ValueError(
4451 f"'c' argument has {csize} elements, which is inconsistent "
4452 f"with 'x' and 'y' with size {xsize}.")
4453  
4454 c_is_mapped = False # Unless proven otherwise below.
4455 valid_shape = True # Unless proven otherwise below.
4456 if not c_was_none and kwcolor is None and not c_is_string_or_strings:
4457 try: # First, does 'c' look suitable for value-mapping?
4458 c = np.asanyarray(c, dtype=float)
4459 except ValueError:
4460 pass # Failed to convert to float array; must be color specs.
4461 else:
4462 # handle the documented special case of a 2D array with 1
4463 # row which as RGB(A) to broadcast.
4464 if c.shape == (1, 4) or c.shape == (1, 3):
4465 c_is_mapped = False
4466 if c.size != xsize:
4467 valid_shape = False
4468 # If c can be either mapped values or an RGB(A) color, prefer
4469 # the former if shapes match, the latter otherwise.
4470 elif c.size == xsize:
4471 c = c.ravel()
4472 c_is_mapped = True
4473 else: # Wrong size; it must not be intended for mapping.
4474 if c.shape in ((3,), (4,)):
4475 _api.warn_external(
4476 "*c* argument looks like a single numeric RGB or "
4477 "RGBA sequence, which should be avoided as value-"
4478 "mapping will have precedence in case its length "
4479 "matches with *x* & *y*. Please use the *color* "
4480 "keyword-argument or provide a 2D array "
4481 "with a single row if you intend to specify "
4482 "the same RGB or RGBA value for all points.")
4483 valid_shape = False
4484 if not c_is_mapped:
4485 try: # Is 'c' acceptable as PathCollection facecolors?
4486 colors = mcolors.to_rgba_array(c)
4487 except (TypeError, ValueError) as err:
4488 if "RGBA values should be within 0-1 range" in str(err):
4489 raise
4490 else:
4491 if not valid_shape:
4492 raise invalid_shape_exception(c.size, xsize) from err
4493 # Both the mapping *and* the RGBA conversion failed: pretty
4494 # severe failure => one may appreciate a verbose feedback.
4495 raise ValueError(
4496 f"'c' argument must be a color, a sequence of colors, "
4497 f"or a sequence of numbers, not {c!r}") from err
4498 else:
4499 if len(colors) not in (0, 1, xsize):
4500 # NB: remember that a single color is also acceptable.
4501 # Besides *colors* will be an empty array if c == 'none'.
4502 raise invalid_shape_exception(len(colors), xsize)
4503 else:
4504 colors = None # use cmap, norm after collection is created
4505 return c, colors, edgecolors
4506  
4507 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y", "s", "linewidths",
4508 "edgecolors", "c", "facecolor",
4509 "facecolors", "color"],
4510 label_namer="y")
4511 @_docstring.interpd
4512 def scatter(self, x, y, s=None, c=None, marker=None, cmap=None, norm=None,
4513 vmin=None, vmax=None, alpha=None, linewidths=None, *,
4514 edgecolors=None, plotnonfinite=False, **kwargs):
4515 """
4516 A scatter plot of *y* vs. *x* with varying marker size and/or color.
4517  
4518 Parameters
4519 ----------
4520 x, y : float or array-like, shape (n, )
4521 The data positions.
4522  
4523 s : float or array-like, shape (n, ), optional
4524 The marker size in points**2 (typographic points are 1/72 in.).
4525 Default is ``rcParams['lines.markersize'] ** 2``.
4526  
4527 The linewidth and edgecolor can visually interact with the marker
4528 size, and can lead to artifacts if the marker size is smaller than
4529 the linewidth.
4530  
4531 If the linewidth is greater than 0 and the edgecolor is anything
4532 but *'none'*, then the effective size of the marker will be
4533 increased by half the linewidth because the stroke will be centered
4534 on the edge of the shape.
4535  
4536 To eliminate the marker edge either set *linewidth=0* or
4537 *edgecolor='none'*.
4538  
4539 c : array-like or list of colors or color, optional
4540 The marker colors. Possible values:
4541  
4542 - A scalar or sequence of n numbers to be mapped to colors using
4543 *cmap* and *norm*.
4544 - A 2D array in which the rows are RGB or RGBA.
4545 - A sequence of colors of length n.
4546 - A single color format string.
4547  
4548 Note that *c* should not be a single numeric RGB or RGBA sequence
4549 because that is indistinguishable from an array of values to be
4550 colormapped. If you want to specify the same RGB or RGBA value for
4551 all points, use a 2D array with a single row. Otherwise,
4552 value-matching will have precedence in case of a size matching with
4553 *x* and *y*.
4554  
4555 If you wish to specify a single color for all points
4556 prefer the *color* keyword argument.
4557  
4558 Defaults to `None`. In that case the marker color is determined
4559 by the value of *color*, *facecolor* or *facecolors*. In case
4560 those are not specified or `None`, the marker color is determined
