4561 by the next color of the ``Axes``' current "shape and fill" color
4562 cycle. This cycle defaults to :rc:`axes.prop_cycle`.
4563  
4564 marker : `~.markers.MarkerStyle`, default: :rc:`scatter.marker`
4565 The marker style. *marker* can be either an instance of the class
4566 or the text shorthand for a particular marker.
4567 See :mod:`matplotlib.markers` for more information about marker
4568 styles.
4569  
4570 %(cmap_doc)s
4571  
4572 This parameter is ignored if *c* is RGB(A).
4573  
4574 %(norm_doc)s
4575  
4576 This parameter is ignored if *c* is RGB(A).
4577  
4578 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
4579  
4580 This parameter is ignored if *c* is RGB(A).
4581  
4582 alpha : float, default: None
4583 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
4584  
4585 linewidths : float or array-like, default: :rc:`lines.linewidth`
4586 The linewidth of the marker edges. Note: The default *edgecolors*
4587 is 'face'. You may want to change this as well.
4588  
4589 edgecolors : {'face', 'none', *None*} or color or sequence of color, \
4590 default: :rc:`scatter.edgecolors`
4591 The edge color of the marker. Possible values:
4592  
4593 - 'face': The edge color will always be the same as the face color.
4594 - 'none': No patch boundary will be drawn.
4595 - A color or sequence of colors.
4596  
4597 For non-filled markers, *edgecolors* is ignored. Instead, the color
4598 is determined like with 'face', i.e. from *c*, *colors*, or
4599 *facecolors*.
4600  
4601 plotnonfinite : bool, default: False
4602 Whether to plot points with nonfinite *c* (i.e. ``inf``, ``-inf``
4603 or ``nan``). If ``True`` the points are drawn with the *bad*
4604 colormap color (see `.Colormap.set_bad`).
4605  
4606 Returns
4607 -------
4608 `~matplotlib.collections.PathCollection`
4609  
4610 Other Parameters
4611 ----------------
4612 data : indexable object, optional
4613 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
4614 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.Collection` properties
4615  
4616 See Also
4617 --------
4618 plot : To plot scatter plots when markers are identical in size and
4619 color.
4620  
4621 Notes
4622 -----
4623 * The `.plot` function will be faster for scatterplots where markers
4624 don't vary in size or color.
4625  
4626 * Any or all of *x*, *y*, *s*, and *c* may be masked arrays, in which
4627 case all masks will be combined and only unmasked points will be
4628 plotted.
4629  
4630 * Fundamentally, scatter works with 1D arrays; *x*, *y*, *s*, and *c*
4631 may be input as N-D arrays, but within scatter they will be
4632 flattened. The exception is *c*, which will be flattened only if its
4633 size matches the size of *x* and *y*.
4634  
4635 """
4636 # add edgecolors and linewidths to kwargs so they
4637 # can be processed by normailze_kwargs
4638 if edgecolors is not None:
4639 kwargs.update({'edgecolors': edgecolors})
4640 if linewidths is not None:
4641 kwargs.update({'linewidths': linewidths})
4642  
4643 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mcoll.Collection)
4644 # re direct linewidth and edgecolor so it can be
4645 # further processed by the rest of the function
4646 linewidths = kwargs.pop('linewidth', None)
4647 edgecolors = kwargs.pop('edgecolor', None)
4648 # Process **kwargs to handle aliases, conflicts with explicit kwargs:
4649 x, y = self._process_unit_info([("x", x), ("y", y)], kwargs)
4650 # np.ma.ravel yields an ndarray, not a masked array,
4651 # unless its argument is a masked array.
4652 x = np.ma.ravel(x)
4653 y = np.ma.ravel(y)
4654 if x.size != y.size:
4655 raise ValueError("x and y must be the same size")
4656  
4657 if s is None:
4658 s = (20 if mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode'] else
4659 mpl.rcParams['lines.markersize'] ** 2.0)
4660 s = np.ma.ravel(s)
4661 if (len(s) not in (1, x.size) or
4662 (not np.issubdtype(s.dtype, np.floating) and
4663 not np.issubdtype(s.dtype, np.integer))):
4664 raise ValueError(
4665 "s must be a scalar, "
4666 "or float array-like with the same size as x and y")
4667  
4668 # get the original edgecolor the user passed before we normalize
4669 orig_edgecolor = edgecolors
4670 if edgecolors is None:
4671 orig_edgecolor = kwargs.get('edgecolor', None)
4672 c, colors, edgecolors = \
4673 self._parse_scatter_color_args(
4674 c, edgecolors, kwargs, x.size,
4675 get_next_color_func=self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color)
4676  
4677 if plotnonfinite and colors is None:
4678 c = np.ma.masked_invalid(c)
4679 x, y, s, edgecolors, linewidths = \
4680 cbook._combine_masks(x, y, s, edgecolors, linewidths)
4681 else:
4682 x, y, s, c, colors, edgecolors, linewidths = \
4683 cbook._combine_masks(
4684 x, y, s, c, colors, edgecolors, linewidths)
4685 # Unmask edgecolors if it was actually a single RGB or RGBA.
4686 if (x.size in (3, 4)
4687 and np.ma.is_masked(edgecolors)
4688 and not np.ma.is_masked(orig_edgecolor)):
4689 edgecolors = edgecolors.data
4690  
4691 scales = s # Renamed for readability below.
4692  
4693 # load default marker from rcParams
4694 if marker is None:
4695 marker = mpl.rcParams['scatter.marker']
4696  
4697 if isinstance(marker, mmarkers.MarkerStyle):
4698 marker_obj = marker
4699 else:
4700 marker_obj = mmarkers.MarkerStyle(marker)
4701  
4702 path = marker_obj.get_path().transformed(
4703 marker_obj.get_transform())
4704 if not marker_obj.is_filled():
4705 if orig_edgecolor is not None:
4706 _api.warn_external(
4707 f"You passed a edgecolor/edgecolors ({orig_edgecolor!r}) "
4708 f"for an unfilled marker ({marker!r}). Matplotlib is "
4709 "ignoring the edgecolor in favor of the facecolor. This "
4710 "behavior may change in the future."
4711 )
4712 # We need to handle markers that cannot be filled (like
4713 # '+' and 'x') differently than markers that can be
4714 # filled, but have their fillstyle set to 'none'. This is
4715 # to get:
4716 #
4717 # - respecting the fillestyle if set
4718 # - maintaining back-compatibility for querying the facecolor of
4719 # the un-fillable markers.
4720 #
4721 # While not an ideal situation, but is better than the
4722 # alternatives.
4723 if marker_obj.get_fillstyle() == 'none':
4724 # promote the facecolor to be the edgecolor
4725 edgecolors = colors
4726 # set the facecolor to 'none' (at the last chance) because
4727 # we cannot fill a path if the facecolor is non-null
4728 # (which is defendable at the renderer level).
4729 colors = 'none'
4730 else:
4731 # if we are not nulling the face color we can do this
4732 # simpler
4733 edgecolors = 'face'
4734  
4735 if linewidths is None:
4736 linewidths = mpl.rcParams['lines.linewidth']
4737 elif np.iterable(linewidths):
4738 linewidths = [
4739 lw if lw is not None else mpl.rcParams['lines.linewidth']
4740 for lw in linewidths]
4741  
4742 offsets = np.ma.column_stack([x, y])
4743  
4744 collection = mcoll.PathCollection(
4745 (path,), scales,
4746 facecolors=colors,
4747 edgecolors=edgecolors,
4748 linewidths=linewidths,
4749 offsets=offsets,
4750 offset_transform=kwargs.pop('transform', self.transData),
4751 alpha=alpha,
4752 )
4753 collection.set_transform(mtransforms.IdentityTransform())
4754 if colors is None:
4755 collection.set_array(c)
4756 collection.set_cmap(cmap)
4757 collection.set_norm(norm)
4758 collection._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
4759 else:
4760 extra_kwargs = {
4761 'cmap': cmap, 'norm': norm, 'vmin': vmin, 'vmax': vmax
4762 }
4763 extra_keys = [k for k, v in extra_kwargs.items() if v is not None]
4764 if any(extra_keys):
4765 keys_str = ", ".join(f"'{k}'" for k in extra_keys)
4766 _api.warn_external(
4767 "No data for colormapping provided via 'c'. "
4768 f"Parameters {keys_str} will be ignored")
4769 collection._internal_update(kwargs)
4770  
4771 # Classic mode only:
4772 # ensure there are margins to allow for the
4773 # finite size of the symbols. In v2.x, margins
4774 # are present by default, so we disable this
4775 # scatter-specific override.
4776 if mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode']:
4777 if self._xmargin < 0.05 and x.size > 0:
4778 self.set_xmargin(0.05)
4779 if self._ymargin < 0.05 and x.size > 0:
4780 self.set_ymargin(0.05)
4781  
4782 self.add_collection(collection)
4783 self._request_autoscale_view()
4784  
4785 return collection
4786  
4787 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y", "C"], label_namer="y")
4788 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
4789 def hexbin(self, x, y, C=None, gridsize=100, bins=None,
4790 xscale='linear', yscale='linear', extent=None,
4791 cmap=None, norm=None, vmin=None, vmax=None,
4792 alpha=None, linewidths=None, edgecolors='face',
4793 reduce_C_function=np.mean, mincnt=None, marginals=False,
4794 **kwargs):
4795 """
4796 Make a 2D hexagonal binning plot of points *x*, *y*.
4797  
4798 If *C* is *None*, the value of the hexagon is determined by the number
4799 of points in the hexagon. Otherwise, *C* specifies values at the
4800 coordinate (x[i], y[i]). For each hexagon, these values are reduced
4801 using *reduce_C_function*.
4802  
4803 Parameters
4804 ----------
4805 x, y : array-like
4806 The data positions. *x* and *y* must be of the same length.
4807  
4808 C : array-like, optional
4809 If given, these values are accumulated in the bins. Otherwise,
4810 every point has a value of 1. Must be of the same length as *x*
4811 and *y*.
4812  
4813 gridsize : int or (int, int), default: 100
4814 If a single int, the number of hexagons in the *x*-direction.
4815 The number of hexagons in the *y*-direction is chosen such that
4816 the hexagons are approximately regular.
4817  
4818 Alternatively, if a tuple (*nx*, *ny*), the number of hexagons
4819 in the *x*-direction and the *y*-direction. In the
4820 *y*-direction, counting is done along vertically aligned
4821 hexagons, not along the zig-zag chains of hexagons; see the
4822 following illustration.
4823  
4824 .. plot::
4825  
4826 import numpy
4827 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
4828  
4829 np.random.seed(19680801)
4830 n= 300
4831 x = np.random.standard_normal(n)
4832 y = np.random.standard_normal(n)
4833  
4834 fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(4, 4))
4835 h = ax.hexbin(x, y, gridsize=(5, 3))
4836 hx, hy = h.get_offsets().T
4837 ax.plot(hx[24::3], hy[24::3], 'ro-')
4838 ax.plot(hx[-3:], hy[-3:], 'ro-')
4839 ax.set_title('gridsize=(5, 3)')
4840 ax.axis('off')
4841  
4842 To get approximately regular hexagons, choose
4843 :math:`n_x = \\sqrt{3}\\,n_y`.
4844  
4845 bins : 'log' or int or sequence, default: None
4846 Discretization of the hexagon values.
4847  
4848 - If *None*, no binning is applied; the color of each hexagon
4849 directly corresponds to its count value.
4850 - If 'log', use a logarithmic scale for the colormap.
4851 Internally, :math:`log_{10}(i+1)` is used to determine the
4852 hexagon color. This is equivalent to ``norm=LogNorm()``.
4853 - If an integer, divide the counts in the specified number
4854 of bins, and color the hexagons accordingly.
4855 - If a sequence of values, the values of the lower bound of
4856 the bins to be used.
4857  
4858 xscale : {'linear', 'log'}, default: 'linear'
4859 Use a linear or log10 scale on the horizontal axis.
4860  
4861 yscale : {'linear', 'log'}, default: 'linear'
4862 Use a linear or log10 scale on the vertical axis.
4863  
4864 mincnt : int >= 0, default: *None*
4865 If not *None*, only display cells with at least *mincnt*
4866 number of points in the cell.
4867  
4868 marginals : bool, default: *False*
4869 If marginals is *True*, plot the marginal density as
4870 colormapped rectangles along the bottom of the x-axis and
4871 left of the y-axis.
4872  
4873 extent : 4-tuple of float, default: *None*
4874 The limits of the bins (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax).
4875 The default assigns the limits based on
4876 *gridsize*, *x*, *y*, *xscale* and *yscale*.
4877  
4878 If *xscale* or *yscale* is set to 'log', the limits are
4879 expected to be the exponent for a power of 10. E.g. for
4880 x-limits of 1 and 50 in 'linear' scale and y-limits
4881 of 10 and 1000 in 'log' scale, enter (1, 50, 1, 3).
4882  
4883 Returns
4884 -------
4885 `~matplotlib.collections.PolyCollection`
4886 A `.PolyCollection` defining the hexagonal bins.
4887  
4888 - `.PolyCollection.get_offsets` contains a Mx2 array containing
4889 the x, y positions of the M hexagon centers.
4890 - `.PolyCollection.get_array` contains the values of the M
4891 hexagons.
4892  
4893 If *marginals* is *True*, horizontal
4894 bar and vertical bar (both PolyCollections) will be attached
4895 to the return collection as attributes *hbar* and *vbar*.
4896  
4897 Other Parameters
4898 ----------------
4899 %(cmap_doc)s
4900  
4901 %(norm_doc)s
4902  
4903 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
4904  
4905 alpha : float between 0 and 1, optional
4906 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
4907  
4908 linewidths : float, default: *None*
4909 If *None*, defaults to :rc:`patch.linewidth`.
4910  
4911 edgecolors : {'face', 'none', *None*} or color, default: 'face'
4912 The color of the hexagon edges. Possible values are:
4913  
4914 - 'face': Draw the edges in the same color as the fill color.
4915 - 'none': No edges are drawn. This can sometimes lead to unsightly
4916 unpainted pixels between the hexagons.
4917 - *None*: Draw outlines in the default color.
4918 - An explicit color.
4919  
4920 reduce_C_function : callable, default: `numpy.mean`
4921 The function to aggregate *C* within the bins. It is ignored if
4922 *C* is not given. This must have the signature::
4923  
4924 def reduce_C_function(C: array) -> float
4925  
4926 Commonly used functions are:
4927  
4928 - `numpy.mean`: average of the points
4929 - `numpy.sum`: integral of the point values
4930 - `numpy.amax`: value taken from the largest point
4931  
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
4932 By default will only reduce cells with at least 1 point because some
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
4933 reduction functions (such as `numpy.amax`) will error/warn with empty
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
4934 input. Changing *mincnt* will adjust the cutoff, and if set to 0 will
4935 pass empty input to the reduction function.
4936  
4937 data : indexable object, optional
4938 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
4939  
4940 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.PolyCollection` properties
4941 All other keyword arguments are passed on to `.PolyCollection`:
4942  
4943 %(PolyCollection:kwdoc)s
4944  
4945 See Also
4946 --------
4947 hist2d : 2D histogram rectangular bins
4948 """
4949 self._process_unit_info([("x", x), ("y", y)], kwargs, convert=False)
4950  
4951 x, y, C = cbook.delete_masked_points(x, y, C)
4952  
4953 # Set the size of the hexagon grid
4954 if np.iterable(gridsize):
4955 nx, ny = gridsize
4956 else:
4957 nx = gridsize
4958 ny = int(nx / math.sqrt(3))
4959 # Count the number of data in each hexagon
4960 x = np.asarray(x, float)
4961 y = np.asarray(y, float)
4962  
4963 # Will be log()'d if necessary, and then rescaled.
4964 tx = x
4965 ty = y
4966  
4967 if xscale == 'log':
4968 if np.any(x <= 0.0):
4969 raise ValueError(
4970 "x contains non-positive values, so cannot be log-scaled")
4971 tx = np.log10(tx)
4972 if yscale == 'log':
4973 if np.any(y <= 0.0):
4974 raise ValueError(
4975 "y contains non-positive values, so cannot be log-scaled")
4976 ty = np.log10(ty)
4977 if extent is not None:
4978 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = extent
4979 else:
4980 xmin, xmax = (tx.min(), tx.max()) if len(x) else (0, 1)
4981 ymin, ymax = (ty.min(), ty.max()) if len(y) else (0, 1)
4982  
4983 # to avoid issues with singular data, expand the min/max pairs
4984 xmin, xmax = mtransforms.nonsingular(xmin, xmax, expander=0.1)
4985 ymin, ymax = mtransforms.nonsingular(ymin, ymax, expander=0.1)
4986  
4987 nx1 = nx + 1
4988 ny1 = ny + 1
4989 nx2 = nx
4990 ny2 = ny
4991 n = nx1 * ny1 + nx2 * ny2
4992  
4993 # In the x-direction, the hexagons exactly cover the region from
4994 # xmin to xmax. Need some padding to avoid roundoff errors.
4995 padding = 1.e-9 * (xmax - xmin)
4996 xmin -= padding
4997 xmax += padding
4998 sx = (xmax - xmin) / nx
4999 sy = (ymax - ymin) / ny
5000 # Positions in hexagon index coordinates.
5001 ix = (tx - xmin) / sx
5002 iy = (ty - ymin) / sy
5003 ix1 = np.round(ix).astype(int)
5004 iy1 = np.round(iy).astype(int)
5005 ix2 = np.floor(ix).astype(int)
5006 iy2 = np.floor(iy).astype(int)
5007 # flat indices, plus one so that out-of-range points go to position 0.
5008 i1 = np.where((0 <= ix1) & (ix1 < nx1) & (0 <= iy1) & (iy1 < ny1),
5009 ix1 * ny1 + iy1 + 1, 0)
5010 i2 = np.where((0 <= ix2) & (ix2 < nx2) & (0 <= iy2) & (iy2 < ny2),
5011 ix2 * ny2 + iy2 + 1, 0)
5012  
5013 d1 = (ix - ix1) ** 2 + 3.0 * (iy - iy1) ** 2
5014 d2 = (ix - ix2 - 0.5) ** 2 + 3.0 * (iy - iy2 - 0.5) ** 2
5015 bdist = (d1 < d2)
5016  
5017 if C is None: # [1:] drops out-of-range points.
5018 counts1 = np.bincount(i1[bdist], minlength=1 + nx1 * ny1)[1:]
5019 counts2 = np.bincount(i2[~bdist], minlength=1 + nx2 * ny2)[1:]
5020 accum = np.concatenate([counts1, counts2]).astype(float)
5021 if mincnt is not None:
5022 accum[accum < mincnt] = np.nan
5023 C = np.ones(len(x))
5024 else:
5025 # store the C values in a list per hexagon index
5026 Cs_at_i1 = [[] for _ in range(1 + nx1 * ny1)]
5027 Cs_at_i2 = [[] for _ in range(1 + nx2 * ny2)]
5028 for i in range(len(x)):
5029 if bdist[i]:
5030 Cs_at_i1[i1[i]].append(C[i])
5031 else:
5032 Cs_at_i2[i2[i]].append(C[i])
5033 if mincnt is None:
5034 mincnt = 1
5035 accum = np.array(
5036 [reduce_C_function(acc) if len(acc) >= mincnt else np.nan
5037 for Cs_at_i in [Cs_at_i1, Cs_at_i2]
5038 for acc in Cs_at_i[1:]], # [1:] drops out-of-range points.
5039 float)
5040  
5041 good_idxs = ~np.isnan(accum)
5042  
5043 offsets = np.zeros((n, 2), float)
5044 offsets[:nx1 * ny1, 0] = np.repeat(np.arange(nx1), ny1)
5045 offsets[:nx1 * ny1, 1] = np.tile(np.arange(ny1), nx1)
5046 offsets[nx1 * ny1:, 0] = np.repeat(np.arange(nx2) + 0.5, ny2)
5047 offsets[nx1 * ny1:, 1] = np.tile(np.arange(ny2), nx2) + 0.5
5048 offsets[:, 0] *= sx
5049 offsets[:, 1] *= sy
5050 offsets[:, 0] += xmin
5051 offsets[:, 1] += ymin
5052 # remove accumulation bins with no data
5053 offsets = offsets[good_idxs, :]
5054 accum = accum[good_idxs]
5055  
5056 polygon = [sx, sy / 3] * np.array(
5057 [[.5, -.5], [.5, .5], [0., 1.], [-.5, .5], [-.5, -.5], [0., -1.]])
5058  
5059 if linewidths is None:
5060 linewidths = [mpl.rcParams['patch.linewidth']]
5061  
5062 if xscale == 'log' or yscale == 'log':
5063 polygons = np.expand_dims(polygon, 0) + np.expand_dims(offsets, 1)
5064 if xscale == 'log':
5065 polygons[:, :, 0] = 10.0 ** polygons[:, :, 0]
5066 xmin = 10.0 ** xmin
5067 xmax = 10.0 ** xmax
5068 self.set_xscale(xscale)
5069 if yscale == 'log':
5070 polygons[:, :, 1] = 10.0 ** polygons[:, :, 1]
5071 ymin = 10.0 ** ymin
5072 ymax = 10.0 ** ymax
5073 self.set_yscale(yscale)
5074 collection = mcoll.PolyCollection(
5075 polygons,
5076 edgecolors=edgecolors,
5077 linewidths=linewidths,
5078 )
5079 else:
5080 collection = mcoll.PolyCollection(
5081 [polygon],
5082 edgecolors=edgecolors,
5083 linewidths=linewidths,
5084 offsets=offsets,
5085 offset_transform=mtransforms.AffineDeltaTransform(
5086 self.transData),
5087 )
5088  
5089 # Set normalizer if bins is 'log'
5090 if cbook._str_equal(bins, 'log'):
5091 if norm is not None:
5092 _api.warn_external("Only one of 'bins' and 'norm' arguments "
5093 f"can be supplied, ignoring {bins=}")
5094 else:
5095 norm = mcolors.LogNorm(vmin=vmin, vmax=vmax)
5096 vmin = vmax = None
5097 bins = None
5098  
5099 # autoscale the norm with current accum values if it hasn't been set
5100 if norm is not None:
5101 if norm.vmin is None and norm.vmax is None:
5102 norm.autoscale(accum)
5103  
5104 if bins is not None:
5105 if not np.iterable(bins):
5106 minimum, maximum = min(accum), max(accum)
5107 bins -= 1 # one less edge than bins
5108 bins = minimum + (maximum - minimum) * np.arange(bins) / bins
5109 bins = np.sort(bins)
5110 accum = bins.searchsorted(accum)
5111  
5112 collection.set_array(accum)
5113 collection.set_cmap(cmap)
5114 collection.set_norm(norm)
5115 collection.set_alpha(alpha)
5116 collection._internal_update(kwargs)
5117 collection._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
5118  
5119 corners = ((xmin, ymin), (xmax, ymax))
5120 self.update_datalim(corners)
5121 self._request_autoscale_view(tight=True)
5122  
5123 # add the collection last
5124 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False)
5125 if not marginals:
5126 return collection
5127  
5128 # Process marginals
5129 bars = []
5130 for zname, z, zmin, zmax, zscale, nbins in [
5131 ("x", x, xmin, xmax, xscale, nx),
5132 ("y", y, ymin, ymax, yscale, 2 * ny),
5133 ]:
5134  
5135 if zscale == "log":
5136 bin_edges = np.geomspace(zmin, zmax, nbins + 1)
5137 else:
5138 bin_edges = np.linspace(zmin, zmax, nbins + 1)
5139  
5140 verts = np.empty((nbins, 4, 2))
5141 verts[:, 0, 0] = verts[:, 1, 0] = bin_edges[:-1]
5142 verts[:, 2, 0] = verts[:, 3, 0] = bin_edges[1:]
5143 verts[:, 0, 1] = verts[:, 3, 1] = .00
5144 verts[:, 1, 1] = verts[:, 2, 1] = .05
5145 if zname == "y":
5146 verts = verts[:, :, ::-1] # Swap x and y.
5147  
5148 # Sort z-values into bins defined by bin_edges.
5149 bin_idxs = np.searchsorted(bin_edges, z) - 1
5150 values = np.empty(nbins)
5151 for i in range(nbins):
5152 # Get C-values for each bin, and compute bin value with
5153 # reduce_C_function.
5154 ci = C[bin_idxs == i]
5155 values[i] = reduce_C_function(ci) if len(ci) > 0 else np.nan
5156  
5157 mask = ~np.isnan(values)
5158 verts = verts[mask]
5159 values = values[mask]
5160  
5161 trans = getattr(self, f"get_{zname}axis_transform")(which="grid")
5162 bar = mcoll.PolyCollection(
5163 verts, transform=trans, edgecolors="face")
5164 bar.set_array(values)
5165 bar.set_cmap(cmap)
5166 bar.set_norm(norm)
5167 bar.set_alpha(alpha)
5168 bar._internal_update(kwargs)
5169 bars.append(self.add_collection(bar, autolim=False))
5170  
5171 collection.hbar, collection.vbar = bars
5172  
5173 def on_changed(collection):
5174 collection.hbar.set_cmap(collection.get_cmap())
5175 collection.hbar.set_cmap(collection.get_cmap())
5176 collection.vbar.set_clim(collection.get_clim())
5177 collection.vbar.set_clim(collection.get_clim())
5178  
5179 collection.callbacks.connect('changed', on_changed)
5180  
5181 return collection
5182  
5183 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
5184 def arrow(self, x, y, dx, dy, **kwargs):
5185 """
5186 Add an arrow to the Axes.
5187  
5188 This draws an arrow from ``(x, y)`` to ``(x+dx, y+dy)``.
5189  
5190 Parameters
5191 ----------
5192 %(FancyArrow)s
5193  
5194 Returns
5195 -------
5196 `.FancyArrow`
5197 The created `.FancyArrow` object.
5198  
5199 Notes
5200 -----
5201 The resulting arrow is affected by the Axes aspect ratio and limits.
5202 This may produce an arrow whose head is not square with its stem. To
5203 create an arrow whose head is square with its stem,
5204 use :meth:`annotate` for example:
5205  
5206 >>> ax.annotate("", xy=(0.5, 0.5), xytext=(0, 0),
5207 ... arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->"))
5208  
5209 """
5210 # Strip away units for the underlying patch since units
5211 # do not make sense to most patch-like code
5212 x = self.convert_xunits(x)
5213 y = self.convert_yunits(y)
5214 dx = self.convert_xunits(dx)
5215 dy = self.convert_yunits(dy)
5216  
5217 a = mpatches.FancyArrow(x, y, dx, dy, **kwargs)
5218 self.add_patch(a)
5219 self._request_autoscale_view()
5220 return a
5221  
5222 @_docstring.copy(mquiver.QuiverKey.__init__)

5228 # Handle units for x and y, if they've been passed
5229 def _quiver_units(self, args, kwargs):
5230 if len(args) > 3:
5231 x, y = args[0:2]
5232 x, y = self._process_unit_info([("x", x), ("y", y)], kwargs)
5233 return (x, y) + args[2:]
5234 return args
5235

5259  
5260 # Uses a custom implementation of data-kwarg handling in
5261 # _process_plot_var_args.
5262 def fill(self, *args, data=None, **kwargs):
5263 """
5264 Plot filled polygons.
5265  
5266 Parameters
5267 ----------
5268 *args : sequence of x, y, [color]
5269 Each polygon is defined by the lists of *x* and *y* positions of
5270 its nodes, optionally followed by a *color* specifier. See
5271 :mod:`matplotlib.colors` for supported color specifiers. The
5272 standard color cycle is used for polygons without a color
5273 specifier.
5274  
5275 You can plot multiple polygons by providing multiple *x*, *y*,
5276 *[color]* groups.
5277  
5278 For example, each of the following is legal::
5279  
5280 ax.fill(x, y) # a polygon with default color
5281 ax.fill(x, y, "b") # a blue polygon
5282 ax.fill(x, y, x2, y2) # two polygons
5283 ax.fill(x, y, "b", x2, y2, "r") # a blue and a red polygon
5284  
5285 data : indexable object, optional
5286 An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to
5287 plot in *x* and *y*, e.g.::
5288  
5289 ax.fill("time", "signal",
5290 data={"time": [0, 1, 2], "signal": [0, 1, 0]})
5291  
5292 Returns
5293 -------
5294 list of `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon`
5295  
5296 Other Parameters
5297 ----------------
5298 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` properties
5299  
5300 Notes
5301 -----
5302 Use :meth:`fill_between` if you would like to fill the region between
5303 two curves.
5304 """
5305 # For compatibility(!), get aliases from Line2D rather than Patch.
5306 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mlines.Line2D)
5307 # _get_patches_for_fill returns a generator, convert it to a list.
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
5308 patches = [*self._get_patches_for_fill(self, *args, data=data, **kwargs)]
5309 for poly in patches:
5310 self.add_patch(poly)
5311 self._request_autoscale_view()
5312 return patches
5313  
5314 def _fill_between_x_or_y(
5315 self, ind_dir, ind, dep1, dep2=0, *,
5316 where=None, interpolate=False, step=None, **kwargs):
5317 # Common implementation between fill_between (*ind_dir*="x") and
5318 # fill_betweenx (*ind_dir*="y"). *ind* is the independent variable,
5319 # *dep* the dependent variable. The docstring below is interpolated
5320 # to generate both methods' docstrings.
5321 """
5322 Fill the area between two {dir} curves.
5323  
5324 The curves are defined by the points (*{ind}*, *{dep}1*) and (*{ind}*,
5325 *{dep}2*). This creates one or multiple polygons describing the filled
5326 area.
5327  
5328 You may exclude some {dir} sections from filling using *where*.
5329  
5330 By default, the edges connect the given points directly. Use *step*
5331 if the filling should be a step function, i.e. constant in between
5332 *{ind}*.
5333  
5334 Parameters
5335 ----------
5336 {ind} : array (length N)
5337 The {ind} coordinates of the nodes defining the curves.
5338  
5339 {dep}1 : array (length N) or scalar
5340 The {dep} coordinates of the nodes defining the first curve.
5341  
5342 {dep}2 : array (length N) or scalar, default: 0
5343 The {dep} coordinates of the nodes defining the second curve.
5344  
5345 where : array of bool (length N), optional
5346 Define *where* to exclude some {dir} regions from being filled.
5347 The filled regions are defined by the coordinates ``{ind}[where]``.
5348 More precisely, fill between ``{ind}[i]`` and ``{ind}[i+1]`` if
5349 ``where[i] and where[i+1]``. Note that this definition implies
5350 that an isolated *True* value between two *False* values in *where*
5351 will not result in filling. Both sides of the *True* position
5352 remain unfilled due to the adjacent *False* values.
5353  
5354 interpolate : bool, default: False
5355 This option is only relevant if *where* is used and the two curves
5356 are crossing each other.
5357  
5358 Semantically, *where* is often used for *{dep}1* > *{dep}2* or
5359 similar. By default, the nodes of the polygon defining the filled
5360 region will only be placed at the positions in the *{ind}* array.
5361 Such a polygon cannot describe the above semantics close to the
5362 intersection. The {ind}-sections containing the intersection are
5363 simply clipped.
5364  
5365 Setting *interpolate* to *True* will calculate the actual
5366 intersection point and extend the filled region up to this point.
5367  
5368 step : {{'pre', 'post', 'mid'}}, optional
5369 Define *step* if the filling should be a step function,
5370 i.e. constant in between *{ind}*. The value determines where the
5371 step will occur:
5372  
5373 - 'pre': The y value is continued constantly to the left from
5374 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``(x[i-1], x[i]]`` has the
5375 value ``y[i]``.
5376 - 'post': The y value is continued constantly to the right from
5377 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``[x[i], x[i+1])`` has the
5378 value ``y[i]``.
5379 - 'mid': Steps occur half-way between the *x* positions.
5380  
5381 Returns
5382 -------
5383 `.PolyCollection`
5384 A `.PolyCollection` containing the plotted polygons.
5385  
5386 Other Parameters
5387 ----------------
5388 data : indexable object, optional
5389 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
5390  
5391 **kwargs
5392 All other keyword arguments are passed on to `.PolyCollection`.
5393 They control the `.Polygon` properties:
5394  
5395 %(PolyCollection:kwdoc)s
5396  
5397 See Also
5398 --------
5399 fill_between : Fill between two sets of y-values.
5400 fill_betweenx : Fill between two sets of x-values.
5401 """
5402  
5403 dep_dir = {"x": "y", "y": "x"}[ind_dir]
5404  
5405 if not mpl.rcParams["_internal.classic_mode"]:
5406 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mcoll.Collection)
5407 if not any(c in kwargs for c in ("color", "facecolor")):
5408 kwargs["facecolor"] = \
5409 self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color()
5410  
5411 # Handle united data, such as dates
5412 ind, dep1, dep2 = map(
5413 ma.masked_invalid, self._process_unit_info(
5414 [(ind_dir, ind), (dep_dir, dep1), (dep_dir, dep2)], kwargs))
5415  
5416 for name, array in [
5417 (ind_dir, ind), (f"{dep_dir}1", dep1), (f"{dep_dir}2", dep2)]:
5418 if array.ndim > 1:
5419 raise ValueError(f"{name!r} is not 1-dimensional")
5420  
5421 if where is None:
5422 where = True
5423 else:
5424 where = np.asarray(where, dtype=bool)
5425 if where.size != ind.size:
5426 raise ValueError(f"where size ({where.size}) does not match "
5427 f"{ind_dir} size ({ind.size})")
5428 where = where & ~functools.reduce(
5429 np.logical_or, map(np.ma.getmaskarray, [ind, dep1, dep2]))
5430  
5431 ind, dep1, dep2 = np.broadcast_arrays(
5432 np.atleast_1d(ind), dep1, dep2, subok=True)
5433  
5434 polys = []
5435 for idx0, idx1 in cbook.contiguous_regions(where):
5436 indslice = ind[idx0:idx1]
5437 dep1slice = dep1[idx0:idx1]
5438 dep2slice = dep2[idx0:idx1]
5439 if step is not None:
5440 step_func = cbook.STEP_LOOKUP_MAP["steps-" + step]
5441 indslice, dep1slice, dep2slice = \
5442 step_func(indslice, dep1slice, dep2slice)
5443  
5444 if not len(indslice):
5445 continue
5446  
5447 N = len(indslice)
5448 pts = np.zeros((2 * N + 2, 2))
5449  
5450 if interpolate:
5451 def get_interp_point(idx):
5452 im1 = max(idx - 1, 0)
5453 ind_values = ind[im1:idx+1]
5454 diff_values = dep1[im1:idx+1] - dep2[im1:idx+1]
5455 dep1_values = dep1[im1:idx+1]
5456  
5457 if len(diff_values) == 2:
5458 if np.ma.is_masked(diff_values[1]):
5459 return ind[im1], dep1[im1]
5460 elif np.ma.is_masked(diff_values[0]):
5461 return ind[idx], dep1[idx]
5462  
5463 diff_order = diff_values.argsort()
5464 diff_root_ind = np.interp(
5465 0, diff_values[diff_order], ind_values[diff_order])
5466 ind_order = ind_values.argsort()
5467 diff_root_dep = np.interp(
5468 diff_root_ind,
5469 ind_values[ind_order], dep1_values[ind_order])
5470 return diff_root_ind, diff_root_dep
5471  
5472 start = get_interp_point(idx0)
5473 end = get_interp_point(idx1)
5474 else:
5475 # Handle scalar dep2 (e.g. 0): the fill should go all
5476 # the way down to 0 even if none of the dep1 sample points do.
5477 start = indslice[0], dep2slice[0]
5478 end = indslice[-1], dep2slice[-1]
5479  
5480 pts[0] = start
5481 pts[N + 1] = end
5482  
5483 pts[1:N+1, 0] = indslice
5484 pts[1:N+1, 1] = dep1slice
5485 pts[N+2:, 0] = indslice[::-1]
5486 pts[N+2:, 1] = dep2slice[::-1]
5487  
5488 if ind_dir == "y":
5489 pts = pts[:, ::-1]
5490  
5491 polys.append(pts)
5492  
5493 collection = mcoll.PolyCollection(polys, **kwargs)
5494  
5495 # now update the datalim and autoscale
5496 pts = np.vstack([np.hstack([ind[where, None], dep1[where, None]]),
5497 np.hstack([ind[where, None], dep2[where, None]])])
5498 if ind_dir == "y":
5499 pts = pts[:, ::-1]
5500  
5501 up_x = up_y = True
5502 if "transform" in kwargs:
  • E501 Line too long (87 > 79 characters)
5503 up_x, up_y = kwargs["transform"].contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)
5504 self.update_datalim(pts, updatex=up_x, updatey=up_y)
5505  
5506 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False)
5507 self._request_autoscale_view()
5508 return collection
5509  
5510 def fill_between(self, x, y1, y2=0, where=None, interpolate=False,
5511 step=None, **kwargs):
5512 return self._fill_between_x_or_y(
5513 "x", x, y1, y2,
5514 where=where, interpolate=interpolate, step=step, **kwargs)
5515  
5516 if _fill_between_x_or_y.__doc__:
5517 fill_between.__doc__ = _fill_between_x_or_y.__doc__.format(
5518 dir="horizontal", ind="x", dep="y"
5519 )
5520 fill_between = _preprocess_data(
5521 _docstring.dedent_interpd(fill_between),
5522 replace_names=["x", "y1", "y2", "where"])
5523  
5524 def fill_betweenx(self, y, x1, x2=0, where=None,
5525 step=None, interpolate=False, **kwargs):
5526 return self._fill_between_x_or_y(
5527 "y", y, x1, x2,
5528 where=where, interpolate=interpolate, step=step, **kwargs)
5529  
5530 if _fill_between_x_or_y.__doc__:
5531 fill_betweenx.__doc__ = _fill_between_x_or_y.__doc__.format(
5532 dir="vertical", ind="y", dep="x"
5533 )
5534 fill_betweenx = _preprocess_data(
5535 _docstring.dedent_interpd(fill_betweenx),
5536 replace_names=["y", "x1", "x2", "where"])
5537  
  • E266 Too many leading '#' for block comment
5538 #### plotting z(x, y): imshow, pcolor and relatives, contour
5539  
5540 @_preprocess_data()
5541 @_docstring.interpd
5542 def imshow(self, X, cmap=None, norm=None, *, aspect=None,
5543 interpolation=None, alpha=None,
5544 vmin=None, vmax=None, origin=None, extent=None,
5545 interpolation_stage=None, filternorm=True, filterrad=4.0,
5546 resample=None, url=None, **kwargs):
5547 """
5548 Display data as an image, i.e., on a 2D regular raster.
5549  
5550 The input may either be actual RGB(A) data, or 2D scalar data, which
5551 will be rendered as a pseudocolor image. For displaying a grayscale
5552 image, set up the colormapping using the parameters
5553 ``cmap='gray', vmin=0, vmax=255``.
5554  
5555 The number of pixels used to render an image is set by the Axes size
5556 and the figure *dpi*. This can lead to aliasing artifacts when
5557 the image is resampled, because the displayed image size will usually
5558 not match the size of *X* (see
5559 :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/image_antialiasing`).
5560 The resampling can be controlled via the *interpolation* parameter
5561 and/or :rc:`image.interpolation`.
5562  
5563 Parameters
5564 ----------
5565 X : array-like or PIL image
5566 The image data. Supported array shapes are:
5567  
5568 - (M, N): an image with scalar data. The values are mapped to
5569 colors using normalization and a colormap. See parameters *norm*,
5570 *cmap*, *vmin*, *vmax*.
5571 - (M, N, 3): an image with RGB values (0-1 float or 0-255 int).
5572 - (M, N, 4): an image with RGBA values (0-1 float or 0-255 int),
5573 i.e. including transparency.
5574  
5575 The first two dimensions (M, N) define the rows and columns of
5576 the image.
5577  
5578 Out-of-range RGB(A) values are clipped.
5579  
5580 %(cmap_doc)s
5581  
5582 This parameter is ignored if *X* is RGB(A).
5583  
5584 %(norm_doc)s
5585  
5586 This parameter is ignored if *X* is RGB(A).
5587  
5588 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
5589  
5590 This parameter is ignored if *X* is RGB(A).
5591  
5592 aspect : {'equal', 'auto'} or float or None, default: None
5593 The aspect ratio of the Axes. This parameter is particularly
5594 relevant for images since it determines whether data pixels are
5595 square.
5596  
5597 This parameter is a shortcut for explicitly calling
5598 `.Axes.set_aspect`. See there for further details.
5599  
5600 - 'equal': Ensures an aspect ratio of 1. Pixels will be square
5601 (unless pixel sizes are explicitly made non-square in data
5602 coordinates using *extent*).
5603 - 'auto': The Axes is kept fixed and the aspect is adjusted so
5604 that the data fit in the Axes. In general, this will result in
5605 non-square pixels.
5606  
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
5607 Normally, None (the default) means to use :rc:`image.aspect`. However, if
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
5608 the image uses a transform that does not contain the axes data transform,
  • E501 Line too long (88 > 79 characters)
5609 then None means to not modify the axes aspect at all (in that case, directly
5610 call `.Axes.set_aspect` if desired).
5611  
5612 interpolation : str, default: :rc:`image.interpolation`
5613 The interpolation method used.
5614  
5615 Supported values are 'none', 'antialiased', 'nearest', 'bilinear',
5616 'bicubic', 'spline16', 'spline36', 'hanning', 'hamming', 'hermite',
5617 'kaiser', 'quadric', 'catrom', 'gaussian', 'bessel', 'mitchell',
5618 'sinc', 'lanczos', 'blackman'.
5619  
5620 The data *X* is resampled to the pixel size of the image on the
5621 figure canvas, using the interpolation method to either up- or
5622 downsample the data.
5623  
5624 If *interpolation* is 'none', then for the ps, pdf, and svg
5625 backends no down- or upsampling occurs, and the image data is
5626 passed to the backend as a native image. Note that different ps,
5627 pdf, and svg viewers may display these raw pixels differently. On
5628 other backends, 'none' is the same as 'nearest'.
5629  
5630 If *interpolation* is the default 'antialiased', then 'nearest'
5631 interpolation is used if the image is upsampled by more than a
5632 factor of three (i.e. the number of display pixels is at least
5633 three times the size of the data array). If the upsampling rate is
5634 smaller than 3, or the image is downsampled, then 'hanning'
5635 interpolation is used to act as an anti-aliasing filter, unless the
5636 image happens to be upsampled by exactly a factor of two or one.
5637  
5638 See
5639 :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/interpolation_methods`
5640 for an overview of the supported interpolation methods, and
5641 :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/image_antialiasing` for
5642 a discussion of image antialiasing.
5643  
5644 Some interpolation methods require an additional radius parameter,
5645 which can be set by *filterrad*. Additionally, the antigrain image
5646 resize filter is controlled by the parameter *filternorm*.
5647  
5648 interpolation_stage : {'data', 'rgba'}, default: 'data'
5649 If 'data', interpolation
5650 is carried out on the data provided by the user. If 'rgba', the
5651 interpolation is carried out after the colormapping has been
5652 applied (visual interpolation).
5653  
5654 alpha : float or array-like, optional
5655 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
5656 If *alpha* is an array, the alpha blending values are applied pixel
5657 by pixel, and *alpha* must have the same shape as *X*.
5658  
5659 origin : {'upper', 'lower'}, default: :rc:`image.origin`
5660 Place the [0, 0] index of the array in the upper left or lower
5661 left corner of the Axes. The convention (the default) 'upper' is
5662 typically used for matrices and images.
5663  
5664 Note that the vertical axis points upward for 'lower'
5665 but downward for 'upper'.
5666  
5667 See the :ref:`imshow_extent` tutorial for
5668 examples and a more detailed description.
5669  
5670 extent : floats (left, right, bottom, top), optional
5671 The bounding box in data coordinates that the image will fill.
5672 These values may be unitful and match the units of the Axes.
5673 The image is stretched individually along x and y to fill the box.
5674  
5675 The default extent is determined by the following conditions.
5676 Pixels have unit size in data coordinates. Their centers are on
5677 integer coordinates, and their center coordinates range from 0 to
5678 columns-1 horizontally and from 0 to rows-1 vertically.
5679  
5680 Note that the direction of the vertical axis and thus the default
5681 values for top and bottom depend on *origin*:
5682  
5683 - For ``origin == 'upper'`` the default is
5684 ``(-0.5, numcols-0.5, numrows-0.5, -0.5)``.
5685 - For ``origin == 'lower'`` the default is
5686 ``(-0.5, numcols-0.5, -0.5, numrows-0.5)``.
5687  
5688 See the :ref:`imshow_extent` tutorial for
5689 examples and a more detailed description.
5690  
5691 filternorm : bool, default: True
5692 A parameter for the antigrain image resize filter (see the
5693 antigrain documentation). If *filternorm* is set, the filter
5694 normalizes integer values and corrects the rounding errors. It
5695 doesn't do anything with the source floating point values, it
5696 corrects only integers according to the rule of 1.0 which means
5697 that any sum of pixel weights must be equal to 1.0. So, the
5698 filter function must produce a graph of the proper shape.
5699  
5700 filterrad : float > 0, default: 4.0
5701 The filter radius for filters that have a radius parameter, i.e.
5702 when interpolation is one of: 'sinc', 'lanczos' or 'blackman'.
5703  
5704 resample : bool, default: :rc:`image.resample`
5705 When *True*, use a full resampling method. When *False*, only
5706 resample when the output image is larger than the input image.
5707  
5708 url : str, optional
5709 Set the url of the created `.AxesImage`. See `.Artist.set_url`.
5710  
5711 Returns
5712 -------
5713 `~matplotlib.image.AxesImage`
5714  
5715 Other Parameters
5716 ----------------
5717 data : indexable object, optional
5718 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
5719  
5720 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.artist.Artist` properties
5721 These parameters are passed on to the constructor of the
5722 `.AxesImage` artist.
5723  
5724 See Also
5725 --------
5726 matshow : Plot a matrix or an array as an image.
5727  
5728 Notes
5729 -----
5730 Unless *extent* is used, pixel centers will be located at integer
5731 coordinates. In other words: the origin will coincide with the center
5732 of pixel (0, 0).
5733  
5734 There are two common representations for RGB images with an alpha
5735 channel:
5736  
5737 - Straight (unassociated) alpha: R, G, and B channels represent the
5738 color of the pixel, disregarding its opacity.
5739 - Premultiplied (associated) alpha: R, G, and B channels represent
5740 the color of the pixel, adjusted for its opacity by multiplication.
5741  
5742 `~matplotlib.pyplot.imshow` expects RGB images adopting the straight
5743 (unassociated) alpha representation.
5744 """
5745 im = mimage.AxesImage(self, cmap=cmap, norm=norm,
5746 interpolation=interpolation, origin=origin,
5747 extent=extent, filternorm=filternorm,
5748 filterrad=filterrad, resample=resample,
5749 interpolation_stage=interpolation_stage,
5750 **kwargs)
5751  
5752 if aspect is None and not (
5753 im.is_transform_set()
5754 and not im.get_transform().contains_branch(self.transData)):
5755 aspect = mpl.rcParams['image.aspect']
5756 if aspect is not None:
5757 self.set_aspect(aspect)
5758  
5759 im.set_data(X)
5760 im.set_alpha(alpha)
5761 if im.get_clip_path() is None:
5762 # image does not already have clipping set, clip to axes patch
5763 im.set_clip_path(self.patch)
5764 im._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
5765 im.set_url(url)
5766  
5767 # update ax.dataLim, and, if autoscaling, set viewLim
5768 # to tightly fit the image, regardless of dataLim.
5769 im.set_extent(im.get_extent())
5770  
5771 self.add_image(im)
5772 return im
5773  
5774 def _pcolorargs(self, funcname, *args, shading='auto', **kwargs):
5775 # - create X and Y if not present;
5776 # - reshape X and Y as needed if they are 1-D;
5777 # - check for proper sizes based on `shading` kwarg;
5778 # - reset shading if shading='auto' to flat or nearest
5779 # depending on size;
5780  
5781 _valid_shading = ['gouraud', 'nearest', 'flat', 'auto']
5782 try:
5783 _api.check_in_list(_valid_shading, shading=shading)
5784 except ValueError:
5785 _api.warn_external(f"shading value '{shading}' not in list of "
5786 f"valid values {_valid_shading}. Setting "
5787 "shading='auto'.")
5788 shading = 'auto'
5789  
5790 if len(args) == 1:
5791 C = np.asanyarray(args[0])
5792 nrows, ncols = C.shape[:2]
5793 if shading in ['gouraud', 'nearest']:
5794 X, Y = np.meshgrid(np.arange(ncols), np.arange(nrows))
5795 else:
5796 X, Y = np.meshgrid(np.arange(ncols + 1), np.arange(nrows + 1))
5797 shading = 'flat'
5798 C = cbook.safe_masked_invalid(C, copy=True)
5799 return X, Y, C, shading
5800  
5801 if len(args) == 3:
5802 # Check x and y for bad data...
5803 C = np.asanyarray(args[2])
5804 # unit conversion allows e.g. datetime objects as axis values
5805 X, Y = args[:2]
5806 X, Y = self._process_unit_info([("x", X), ("y", Y)], kwargs)
5807 X, Y = [cbook.safe_masked_invalid(a, copy=True) for a in [X, Y]]
5808  
5809 if funcname == 'pcolormesh':
5810 if np.ma.is_masked(X) or np.ma.is_masked(Y):
5811 raise ValueError(
5812 'x and y arguments to pcolormesh cannot have '
5813 'non-finite values or be of type '
5814 'numpy.ma.MaskedArray with masked values')
5815 nrows, ncols = C.shape[:2]
5816 else:
5817 raise _api.nargs_error(funcname, takes="1 or 3", given=len(args))
5818  
5819 Nx = X.shape[-1]
5820 Ny = Y.shape[0]
5821 if X.ndim != 2 or X.shape[0] == 1:
5822 x = X.reshape(1, Nx)
5823 X = x.repeat(Ny, axis=0)
5824 if Y.ndim != 2 or Y.shape[1] == 1:
5825 y = Y.reshape(Ny, 1)
5826 Y = y.repeat(Nx, axis=1)
5827 if X.shape != Y.shape:
5828 raise TypeError(f'Incompatible X, Y inputs to {funcname}; '
5829 f'see help({funcname})')
5830  
5831 if shading == 'auto':
5832 if ncols == Nx and nrows == Ny:
5833 shading = 'nearest'
5834 else:
5835 shading = 'flat'
5836  
5837 if shading == 'flat':
5838 if (Nx, Ny) != (ncols + 1, nrows + 1):
5839 raise TypeError(f"Dimensions of C {C.shape} should"
5840 f" be one smaller than X({Nx}) and Y({Ny})"
5841 f" while using shading='flat'"
5842 f" see help({funcname})")
5843 else: # ['nearest', 'gouraud']:
5844 if (Nx, Ny) != (ncols, nrows):
5845 raise TypeError('Dimensions of C %s are incompatible with'
5846 ' X (%d) and/or Y (%d); see help(%s)' % (
5847 C.shape, Nx, Ny, funcname))
5848 if shading == 'nearest':
5849 # grid is specified at the center, so define corners
5850 # at the midpoints between the grid centers and then use the
5851 # flat algorithm.
5852 def _interp_grid(X):
5853 # helper for below
5854 if np.shape(X)[1] > 1:
5855 dX = np.diff(X, axis=1) * 0.5
5856 if not (np.all(dX >= 0) or np.all(dX <= 0)):
5857 _api.warn_external(
5858 f"The input coordinates to {funcname} are "
5859 "interpreted as cell centers, but are not "
5860 "monotonically increasing or decreasing. "
5861 "This may lead to incorrectly calculated cell "
5862 "edges, in which case, please supply "
5863 f"explicit cell edges to {funcname}.")
5864  
5865 hstack = np.ma.hstack if np.ma.isMA(X) else np.hstack
5866 X = hstack((X[:, [0]] - dX[:, [0]],
5867 X[:, :-1] + dX,
5868 X[:, [-1]] + dX[:, [-1]]))
5869 else:
5870 # This is just degenerate, but we can't reliably guess
5871 # a dX if there is just one value.
5872 X = np.hstack((X, X))
5873 return X
5874  
5875 if ncols == Nx:
5876 X = _interp_grid(X)
5877 Y = _interp_grid(Y)
5878 if nrows == Ny:
5879 X = _interp_grid(X.T).T
5880 Y = _interp_grid(Y.T).T
5881 shading = 'flat'
5882  
5883 C = cbook.safe_masked_invalid(C, copy=True)
5884 return X, Y, C, shading
5885  
5886 @_preprocess_data()
5887 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
5888 def pcolor(self, *args, shading=None, alpha=None, norm=None, cmap=None,
5889 vmin=None, vmax=None, **kwargs):
5890 r"""
5891 Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid.
5892  
5893 Call signature::
5894  
5895 pcolor([X, Y,] C, **kwargs)
5896  
5897 *X* and *Y* can be used to specify the corners of the quadrilaterals.
5898  
5899 .. hint::
5900  
5901 ``pcolor()`` can be very slow for large arrays. In most
5902 cases you should use the similar but much faster
5903 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` instead. See
5904 :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
5905 <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>` for a discussion of the
5906 differences.
5907  
5908 Parameters
5909 ----------
5910 C : 2D array-like
5911 The color-mapped values. Color-mapping is controlled by *cmap*,
5912 *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*.
5913  
5914 X, Y : array-like, optional
5915 The coordinates of the corners of quadrilaterals of a pcolormesh::
5916  
5917 (X[i+1, j], Y[i+1, j]) (X[i+1, j+1], Y[i+1, j+1])
5918
5919
5920
5921 (X[i, j], Y[i, j]) (X[i, j+1], Y[i, j+1])
5922  
5923 Note that the column index corresponds to the x-coordinate, and
5924 the row index corresponds to y. For details, see the
5925 :ref:`Notes <axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation>` section below.
5926  
5927 If ``shading='flat'`` the dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be one
5928 greater than those of *C*, and the quadrilateral is colored due
5929 to the value at ``C[i, j]``. If *X*, *Y* and *C* have equal
5930 dimensions, a warning will be raised and the last row and column
5931 of *C* will be ignored.
5932  
5933 If ``shading='nearest'``, the dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be
5934 the same as those of *C* (if not, a ValueError will be raised). The
5935 color ``C[i, j]`` will be centered on ``(X[i, j], Y[i, j])``.
5936  
5937 If *X* and/or *Y* are 1-D arrays or column vectors they will be
5938 expanded as needed into the appropriate 2D arrays, making a
5939 rectangular grid.
5940  
5941 shading : {'flat', 'nearest', 'auto'}, default: :rc:`pcolor.shading`
5942 The fill style for the quadrilateral. Possible values:
5943  
5944 - 'flat': A solid color is used for each quad. The color of the
5945 quad (i, j), (i+1, j), (i, j+1), (i+1, j+1) is given by
5946 ``C[i, j]``. The dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be
5947 one greater than those of *C*; if they are the same as *C*,
5948 then a deprecation warning is raised, and the last row
5949 and column of *C* are dropped.
5950 - 'nearest': Each grid point will have a color centered on it,
5951 extending halfway between the adjacent grid centers. The
5952 dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*.
5953 - 'auto': Choose 'flat' if dimensions of *X* and *Y* are one
5954 larger than *C*. Choose 'nearest' if dimensions are the same.
5955  
5956 See :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/pcolormesh_grids`
5957 for more description.
5958  
5959 %(cmap_doc)s
5960  
5961 %(norm_doc)s
5962  
5963 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
5964  
5965 edgecolors : {'none', None, 'face', color, color sequence}, optional
5966 The color of the edges. Defaults to 'none'. Possible values:
5967  
5968 - 'none' or '': No edge.
5969 - *None*: :rc:`patch.edgecolor` will be used. Note that currently
5970 :rc:`patch.force_edgecolor` has to be True for this to work.
5971 - 'face': Use the adjacent face color.
5972 - A color or sequence of colors will set the edge color.
5973  
5974 The singular form *edgecolor* works as an alias.
5975  
5976 alpha : float, default: None
5977 The alpha blending value of the face color, between 0 (transparent)
5978 and 1 (opaque). Note: The edgecolor is currently not affected by
5979 this.
5980  
5981 snap : bool, default: False
5982 Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.
5983  
5984 Returns
5985 -------
5986 `matplotlib.collections.PolyQuadMesh`
5987  
5988 Other Parameters
5989 ----------------
5990 antialiaseds : bool, default: False
5991 The default *antialiaseds* is False if the default
5992 *edgecolors*\ ="none" is used. This eliminates artificial lines
5993 at patch boundaries, and works regardless of the value of alpha.
5994 If *edgecolors* is not "none", then the default *antialiaseds*
5995 is taken from :rc:`patch.antialiased`.
5996 Stroking the edges may be preferred if *alpha* is 1, but will
5997 cause artifacts otherwise.
5998  
5999 data : indexable object, optional
6000 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
6001  
6002 **kwargs
6003 Additionally, the following arguments are allowed. They are passed
6004 along to the `~matplotlib.collections.PolyQuadMesh` constructor:
6005  
6006 %(PolyCollection:kwdoc)s
6007  
6008 See Also
6009 --------
6010 pcolormesh : for an explanation of the differences between
6011 pcolor and pcolormesh.
6012 imshow : If *X* and *Y* are each equidistant, `~.Axes.imshow` can be a
6013 faster alternative.
6014  
6015 Notes
6016 -----
6017 **Masked arrays**
6018  
6019 *X*, *Y* and *C* may be masked arrays. If either ``C[i, j]``, or one
6020 of the vertices surrounding ``C[i, j]`` (*X* or *Y* at
6021 ``[i, j], [i+1, j], [i, j+1], [i+1, j+1]``) is masked, nothing is
6022 plotted.
6023  
6024 .. _axes-pcolor-grid-orientation:
6025  
6026 **Grid orientation**
6027  
6028 The grid orientation follows the standard matrix convention: An array
6029 *C* with shape (nrows, ncolumns) is plotted with the column number as
6030 *X* and the row number as *Y*.
6031 """
6032  
6033 if shading is None:
6034 shading = mpl.rcParams['pcolor.shading']
6035 shading = shading.lower()
6036 X, Y, C, shading = self._pcolorargs('pcolor', *args, shading=shading,
6037 kwargs=kwargs)
6038 linewidths = (0.25,)
6039 if 'linewidth' in kwargs:
6040 kwargs['linewidths'] = kwargs.pop('linewidth')
6041 kwargs.setdefault('linewidths', linewidths)
6042  
6043 if 'edgecolor' in kwargs:
6044 kwargs['edgecolors'] = kwargs.pop('edgecolor')
6045 ec = kwargs.setdefault('edgecolors', 'none')
6046  
6047 # aa setting will default via collections to patch.antialiased
6048 # unless the boundary is not stroked, in which case the
6049 # default will be False; with unstroked boundaries, aa
6050 # makes artifacts that are often disturbing.
6051 if 'antialiaseds' in kwargs:
6052 kwargs['antialiased'] = kwargs.pop('antialiaseds')
6053 if 'antialiased' not in kwargs and cbook._str_lower_equal(ec, "none"):
6054 kwargs['antialiased'] = False
6055  
6056 kwargs.setdefault('snap', False)
6057  
6058 if np.ma.isMaskedArray(X) or np.ma.isMaskedArray(Y):
6059 stack = np.ma.stack
6060 X = np.ma.asarray(X)
6061 Y = np.ma.asarray(Y)
6062 # For bounds collections later
6063 x = X.compressed()
6064 y = Y.compressed()
6065 else:
6066 stack = np.stack
6067 x = X
6068 y = Y
6069 coords = stack([X, Y], axis=-1)
6070  
6071 collection = mcoll.PolyQuadMesh(
6072 coords, array=C, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, alpha=alpha, **kwargs)
6073 collection._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
6074  
6075 # Transform from native to data coordinates?
6076 t = collection._transform
6077 if (not isinstance(t, mtransforms.Transform) and
6078 hasattr(t, '_as_mpl_transform')):
6079 t = t._as_mpl_transform(self.axes)
6080  
6081 if t and any(t.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)):
6082 trans_to_data = t - self.transData
6083 pts = np.vstack([x, y]).T.astype(float)
6084 transformed_pts = trans_to_data.transform(pts)
6085 x = transformed_pts[..., 0]
6086 y = transformed_pts[..., 1]
6087  
6088 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False)
6089  
6090 minx = np.min(x)
6091 maxx = np.max(x)
6092 miny = np.min(y)
6093 maxy = np.max(y)
6094 collection.sticky_edges.x[:] = [minx, maxx]
6095 collection.sticky_edges.y[:] = [miny, maxy]
6096 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy)
6097 self.update_datalim(corners)
6098 self._request_autoscale_view()
6099 return collection
6100  
6101 @_preprocess_data()
6102 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
6103 def pcolormesh(self, *args, alpha=None, norm=None, cmap=None, vmin=None,
6104 vmax=None, shading=None, antialiased=False, **kwargs):
6105 """
6106 Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid.
6107  
6108 Call signature::
6109  
6110 pcolormesh([X, Y,] C, **kwargs)
6111  
6112 *X* and *Y* can be used to specify the corners of the quadrilaterals.
6113  
6114 .. hint::
6115  
6116 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` is similar to `~.Axes.pcolor`. It is much faster
6117 and preferred in most cases. For a detailed discussion on the
6118 differences see :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
6119 <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>`.
6120  
6121 Parameters
6122 ----------
6123 C : array-like
6124 The mesh data. Supported array shapes are:
6125  
6126 - (M, N) or M*N: a mesh with scalar data. The values are mapped to
6127 colors using normalization and a colormap. See parameters *norm*,
6128 *cmap*, *vmin*, *vmax*.
6129 - (M, N, 3): an image with RGB values (0-1 float or 0-255 int).
6130 - (M, N, 4): an image with RGBA values (0-1 float or 0-255 int),
6131 i.e. including transparency.
6132  
6133 The first two dimensions (M, N) define the rows and columns of
6134 the mesh data.
6135  
6136 X, Y : array-like, optional
6137 The coordinates of the corners of quadrilaterals of a pcolormesh::
6138  
6139 (X[i+1, j], Y[i+1, j]) (X[i+1, j+1], Y[i+1, j+1])
6140
6141
6142
6143 (X[i, j], Y[i, j]) (X[i, j+1], Y[i, j+1])
6144  
6145 Note that the column index corresponds to the x-coordinate, and
6146 the row index corresponds to y. For details, see the
6147 :ref:`Notes <axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation>` section below.
6148  
6149 If ``shading='flat'`` the dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be one
6150 greater than those of *C*, and the quadrilateral is colored due
6151 to the value at ``C[i, j]``. If *X*, *Y* and *C* have equal
6152 dimensions, a warning will be raised and the last row and column
6153 of *C* will be ignored.
6154  
6155 If ``shading='nearest'`` or ``'gouraud'``, the dimensions of *X*
6156 and *Y* should be the same as those of *C* (if not, a ValueError
6157 will be raised). For ``'nearest'`` the color ``C[i, j]`` is
6158 centered on ``(X[i, j], Y[i, j])``. For ``'gouraud'``, a smooth
6159 interpolation is caried out between the quadrilateral corners.
6160  
6161 If *X* and/or *Y* are 1-D arrays or column vectors they will be
6162 expanded as needed into the appropriate 2D arrays, making a
6163 rectangular grid.
6164  
6165 %(cmap_doc)s
6166  
6167 %(norm_doc)s
6168  
6169 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
6170  
6171 edgecolors : {'none', None, 'face', color, color sequence}, optional
6172 The color of the edges. Defaults to 'none'. Possible values:
6173  
6174 - 'none' or '': No edge.
6175 - *None*: :rc:`patch.edgecolor` will be used. Note that currently
6176 :rc:`patch.force_edgecolor` has to be True for this to work.
6177 - 'face': Use the adjacent face color.
6178 - A color or sequence of colors will set the edge color.
6179  
6180 The singular form *edgecolor* works as an alias.
6181  
6182 alpha : float, default: None
6183 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
6184  
6185 shading : {'flat', 'nearest', 'gouraud', 'auto'}, optional
6186 The fill style for the quadrilateral; defaults to
6187 :rc:`pcolor.shading`. Possible values:
6188  
6189 - 'flat': A solid color is used for each quad. The color of the
6190 quad (i, j), (i+1, j), (i, j+1), (i+1, j+1) is given by
6191 ``C[i, j]``. The dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be
6192 one greater than those of *C*; if they are the same as *C*,
6193 then a deprecation warning is raised, and the last row
6194 and column of *C* are dropped.
6195 - 'nearest': Each grid point will have a color centered on it,
6196 extending halfway between the adjacent grid centers. The
6197 dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*.
6198 - 'gouraud': Each quad will be Gouraud shaded: The color of the
6199 corners (i', j') are given by ``C[i', j']``. The color values of
6200 the area in between is interpolated from the corner values.
6201 The dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*. When
6202 Gouraud shading is used, *edgecolors* is ignored.
6203 - 'auto': Choose 'flat' if dimensions of *X* and *Y* are one
6204 larger than *C*. Choose 'nearest' if dimensions are the same.
6205  
6206 See :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/pcolormesh_grids`
6207 for more description.
6208  
6209 snap : bool, default: False
6210 Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.
6211  
6212 rasterized : bool, optional
6213 Rasterize the pcolormesh when drawing vector graphics. This can
6214 speed up rendering and produce smaller files for large data sets.
6215 See also :doc:`/gallery/misc/rasterization_demo`.
6216  
6217 Returns
6218 -------
6219 `matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh`
6220  
6221 Other Parameters
6222 ----------------
6223 data : indexable object, optional
6224 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
6225  
6226 **kwargs
6227 Additionally, the following arguments are allowed. They are passed
6228 along to the `~matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh` constructor:
6229  
6230 %(QuadMesh:kwdoc)s
6231  
6232 See Also
6233 --------
6234 pcolor : An alternative implementation with slightly different
6235 features. For a detailed discussion on the differences see
6236 :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
6237 <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>`.
6238 imshow : If *X* and *Y* are each equidistant, `~.Axes.imshow` can be a
6239 faster alternative.
6240  
6241 Notes
6242 -----
6243 **Masked arrays**
6244  
6245 *C* may be a masked array. If ``C[i, j]`` is masked, the corresponding
6246 quadrilateral will be transparent. Masking of *X* and *Y* is not
6247 supported. Use `~.Axes.pcolor` if you need this functionality.
6248  
6249 .. _axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation:
6250  
6251 **Grid orientation**
6252  
6253 The grid orientation follows the standard matrix convention: An array
6254 *C* with shape (nrows, ncolumns) is plotted with the column number as
6255 *X* and the row number as *Y*.
6256  
6257 .. _differences-pcolor-pcolormesh:
6258  
6259 **Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()**
6260  
6261 Both methods are used to create a pseudocolor plot of a 2D array
6262 using quadrilaterals.
6263  
6264 The main difference lies in the created object and internal data
6265 handling:
6266 While `~.Axes.pcolor` returns a `.PolyQuadMesh`, `~.Axes.pcolormesh`
6267 returns a `.QuadMesh`. The latter is more specialized for the given
6268 purpose and thus is faster. It should almost always be preferred.
6269  
6270 There is also a slight difference in the handling of masked arrays.
6271 Both `~.Axes.pcolor` and `~.Axes.pcolormesh` support masked arrays
6272 for *C*. However, only `~.Axes.pcolor` supports masked arrays for *X*
6273 and *Y*. The reason lies in the internal handling of the masked values.
6274 `~.Axes.pcolor` leaves out the respective polygons from the
6275 PolyQuadMesh. `~.Axes.pcolormesh` sets the facecolor of the masked
6276 elements to transparent. You can see the difference when using
6277 edgecolors. While all edges are drawn irrespective of masking in a
6278 QuadMesh, the edge between two adjacent masked quadrilaterals in
6279 `~.Axes.pcolor` is not drawn as the corresponding polygons do not
6280 exist in the PolyQuadMesh. Because PolyQuadMesh draws each individual
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
6281 polygon, it also supports applying hatches and linestyles to the collection.
6282  
6283 Another difference is the support of Gouraud shading in
6284 `~.Axes.pcolormesh`, which is not available with `~.Axes.pcolor`.
6285  
6286 """
6287 if shading is None:
6288 shading = mpl.rcParams['pcolor.shading']
6289 shading = shading.lower()
6290 kwargs.setdefault('edgecolors', 'none')
6291  
6292 X, Y, C, shading = self._pcolorargs('pcolormesh', *args,
6293 shading=shading, kwargs=kwargs)
6294 coords = np.stack([X, Y], axis=-1)
6295  
6296 kwargs.setdefault('snap', mpl.rcParams['pcolormesh.snap'])
6297  
6298 collection = mcoll.QuadMesh(
6299 coords, antialiased=antialiased, shading=shading,
6300 array=C, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, alpha=alpha, **kwargs)
6301 collection._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
6302  
6303 coords = coords.reshape(-1, 2) # flatten the grid structure; keep x, y
6304  
6305 # Transform from native to data coordinates?
6306 t = collection._transform
6307 if (not isinstance(t, mtransforms.Transform) and
6308 hasattr(t, '_as_mpl_transform')):
6309 t = t._as_mpl_transform(self.axes)
6310  
6311 if t and any(t.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)):
6312 trans_to_data = t - self.transData
6313 coords = trans_to_data.transform(coords)
6314  
6315 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False)
6316  
6317 minx, miny = np.min(coords, axis=0)
6318 maxx, maxy = np.max(coords, axis=0)
6319 collection.sticky_edges.x[:] = [minx, maxx]
6320 collection.sticky_edges.y[:] = [miny, maxy]
6321 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy)
6322 self.update_datalim(corners)
6323 self._request_autoscale_view()
6324 return collection
6325  
6326 @_preprocess_data()
6327 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
6328 def pcolorfast(self, *args, alpha=None, norm=None, cmap=None, vmin=None,
6329 vmax=None, **kwargs):
6330 """
6331 Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid.
6332  
6333 Call signature::
6334  
6335 ax.pcolorfast([X, Y], C, /, **kwargs)
6336  
6337 This method is similar to `~.Axes.pcolor` and `~.Axes.pcolormesh`.
6338 It's designed to provide the fastest pcolor-type plotting with the
6339 Agg backend. To achieve this, it uses different algorithms internally
6340 depending on the complexity of the input grid (regular rectangular,
6341 non-regular rectangular or arbitrary quadrilateral).
6342  
6343 .. warning::
6344  
6345 This method is experimental. Compared to `~.Axes.pcolor` or
6346 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` it has some limitations:
6347  
6348 - It supports only flat shading (no outlines)
6349 - It lacks support for log scaling of the axes.
6350 - It does not have a pyplot wrapper.
6351  
6352 Parameters
6353 ----------
6354 C : array-like
6355 The image data. Supported array shapes are:
6356  
6357 - (M, N): an image with scalar data. Color-mapping is controlled
6358 by *cmap*, *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*.
6359 - (M, N, 3): an image with RGB values (0-1 float or 0-255 int).
6360 - (M, N, 4): an image with RGBA values (0-1 float or 0-255 int),
6361 i.e. including transparency.
6362  
6363 The first two dimensions (M, N) define the rows and columns of
6364 the image.
6365  
6366 This parameter can only be passed positionally.
6367  
6368 X, Y : tuple or array-like, default: ``(0, N)``, ``(0, M)``
6369 *X* and *Y* are used to specify the coordinates of the
6370 quadrilaterals. There are different ways to do this:
6371  
6372 - Use tuples ``X=(xmin, xmax)`` and ``Y=(ymin, ymax)`` to define
6373 a *uniform rectangular grid*.
6374  
6375 The tuples define the outer edges of the grid. All individual
6376 quadrilaterals will be of the same size. This is the fastest
6377 version.
6378  
6379 - Use 1D arrays *X*, *Y* to specify a *non-uniform rectangular
6380 grid*.
6381  
6382 In this case *X* and *Y* have to be monotonic 1D arrays of length
6383 *N+1* and *M+1*, specifying the x and y boundaries of the cells.
6384  
6385 The speed is intermediate. Note: The grid is checked, and if
6386 found to be uniform the fast version is used.
6387  
6388 - Use 2D arrays *X*, *Y* if you need an *arbitrary quadrilateral
6389 grid* (i.e. if the quadrilaterals are not rectangular).
6390  
6391 In this case *X* and *Y* are 2D arrays with shape (M + 1, N + 1),
6392 specifying the x and y coordinates of the corners of the colored
6393 quadrilaterals.
6394  
6395 This is the most general, but the slowest to render. It may
6396 produce faster and more compact output using ps, pdf, and
6397 svg backends, however.
6398  
6399 These arguments can only be passed positionally.
6400  
6401 %(cmap_doc)s
6402  
6403 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A).
6404  
6405 %(norm_doc)s
6406  
6407 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A).
6408  
6409 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s
6410  
6411 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A).
6412  
6413 alpha : float, default: None
6414 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
6415  
6416 snap : bool, default: False
6417 Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.
6418  
6419 Returns
6420 -------
6421 `.AxesImage` or `.PcolorImage` or `.QuadMesh`
6422 The return type depends on the type of grid:
6423  
6424 - `.AxesImage` for a regular rectangular grid.
6425 - `.PcolorImage` for a non-regular rectangular grid.
6426 - `.QuadMesh` for a non-rectangular grid.
6427  
6428 Other Parameters
6429 ----------------
6430 data : indexable object, optional
6431 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
6432  
6433 **kwargs
6434 Supported additional parameters depend on the type of grid.
6435 See return types of *image* for further description.
6436 """
6437  
6438 C = args[-1]
6439 nr, nc = np.shape(C)[:2]
6440 if len(args) == 1:
6441 style = "image"
6442 x = [0, nc]
6443 y = [0, nr]
6444 elif len(args) == 3:
6445 x, y = args[:2]
6446 x = np.asarray(x)
6447 y = np.asarray(y)
6448 if x.ndim == 1 and y.ndim == 1:
6449 if x.size == 2 and y.size == 2:
6450 style = "image"
6451 else:
6452 dx = np.diff(x)
6453 dy = np.diff(y)
6454 if (np.ptp(dx) < 0.01 * abs(dx.mean()) and
6455 np.ptp(dy) < 0.01 * abs(dy.mean())):
6456 style = "image"
6457 else:
6458 style = "pcolorimage"
6459 elif x.ndim == 2 and y.ndim == 2:
6460 style = "quadmesh"
6461 else:
6462 raise TypeError("arguments do not match valid signatures")
6463 else:
6464 raise _api.nargs_error('pcolorfast', '1 or 3', len(args))
6465  
6466 if style == "quadmesh":
6467 # data point in each cell is value at lower left corner
6468 coords = np.stack([x, y], axis=-1)
6469 if np.ndim(C) not in {2, 3}:
6470 raise ValueError("C must be 2D or 3D")
6471 collection = mcoll.QuadMesh(
6472 coords, array=C,
6473 alpha=alpha, cmap=cmap, norm=norm,
6474 antialiased=False, edgecolors="none")
6475 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False)
6476 xl, xr, yb, yt = x.min(), x.max(), y.min(), y.max()
6477 ret = collection
6478  
6479 else: # It's one of the two image styles.
6480 extent = xl, xr, yb, yt = x[0], x[-1], y[0], y[-1]
6481 if style == "image":
6482 im = mimage.AxesImage(
6483 self, cmap=cmap, norm=norm,
6484 data=C, alpha=alpha, extent=extent,
6485 interpolation='nearest', origin='lower',
6486 **kwargs)
6487 elif style == "pcolorimage":
6488 im = mimage.PcolorImage(
6489 self, x, y, C,
6490 cmap=cmap, norm=norm, alpha=alpha, extent=extent,
6491 **kwargs)
6492 self.add_image(im)
6493 ret = im
6494  
6495 if np.ndim(C) == 2: # C.ndim == 3 is RGB(A) so doesn't need scaling.
6496 ret._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax)
6497  
6498 if ret.get_clip_path() is None:
6499 # image does not already have clipping set, clip to axes patch
6500 ret.set_clip_path(self.patch)
6501  
6502 ret.sticky_edges.x[:] = [xl, xr]
6503 ret.sticky_edges.y[:] = [yb, yt]
6504 self.update_datalim(np.array([[xl, yb], [xr, yt]]))
6505 self._request_autoscale_view(tight=True)
6506 return ret
6507  
6508 @_preprocess_data()
6509 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
6510 def contour(self, *args, **kwargs):
6511 """
6512 Plot contour lines.
6513  
6514 Call signature::
6515  
6516 contour([X, Y,] Z, [levels], **kwargs)
6517 %(contour_doc)s
6518 """
6519 kwargs['filled'] = False
6520 contours = mcontour.QuadContourSet(self, *args, **kwargs)
6521 self._request_autoscale_view()
6522 return contours
6523  
6524 @_preprocess_data()
6525 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
6526 def contourf(self, *args, **kwargs):
6527 """
6528 Plot filled contours.
6529  
6530 Call signature::
6531  
6532 contourf([X, Y,] Z, [levels], **kwargs)
6533 %(contour_doc)s
6534 """
6535 kwargs['filled'] = True
6536 contours = mcontour.QuadContourSet(self, *args, **kwargs)
6537 self._request_autoscale_view()
6538 return contours
6539  
6540 def clabel(self, CS, levels=None, **kwargs):
6541 """
6542 Label a contour plot.
6543  
6544 Adds labels to line contours in given `.ContourSet`.
6545  
6546 Parameters
6547 ----------
6548 CS : `.ContourSet` instance
6549 Line contours to label.
6550  
6551 levels : array-like, optional
6552 A list of level values, that should be labeled. The list must be
6553 a subset of ``CS.levels``. If not given, all levels are labeled.
6554  
6555 **kwargs
6556 All other parameters are documented in `~.ContourLabeler.clabel`.
6557 """
6558 return CS.clabel(levels, **kwargs)
6559  
  • E266 Too many leading '#' for block comment
6560 #### Data analysis
6561  
6562 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", 'weights'], label_namer="x")
6563 def hist(self, x, bins=None, range=None, density=False, weights=None,
6564 cumulative=False, bottom=None, histtype='bar', align='mid',
6565 orientation='vertical', rwidth=None, log=False,
6566 color=None, label=None, stacked=False, **kwargs):
6567 """
6568 Compute and plot a histogram.
6569  
6570 This method uses `numpy.histogram` to bin the data in *x* and count the
6571 number of values in each bin, then draws the distribution either as a
6572 `.BarContainer` or `.Polygon`. The *bins*, *range*, *density*, and
6573 *weights* parameters are forwarded to `numpy.histogram`.
6574  
6575 If the data has already been binned and counted, use `~.bar` or
6576 `~.stairs` to plot the distribution::
6577  
6578 counts, bins = np.histogram(x)
6579 plt.stairs(counts, bins)
6580  
6581 Alternatively, plot pre-computed bins and counts using ``hist()`` by
6582 treating each bin as a single point with a weight equal to its count::
6583  
6584 plt.hist(bins[:-1], bins, weights=counts)
6585  
6586 The data input *x* can be a singular array, a list of datasets of
6587 potentially different lengths ([*x0*, *x1*, ...]), or a 2D ndarray in
6588 which each column is a dataset. Note that the ndarray form is
6589 transposed relative to the list form. If the input is an array, then
6590 the return value is a tuple (*n*, *bins*, *patches*); if the input is a
6591 sequence of arrays, then the return value is a tuple
6592 ([*n0*, *n1*, ...], *bins*, [*patches0*, *patches1*, ...]).
6593  
6594 Masked arrays are not supported.
6595  
6596 Parameters
6597 ----------
6598 x : (n,) array or sequence of (n,) arrays
6599 Input values, this takes either a single array or a sequence of
6600 arrays which are not required to be of the same length.
6601  
6602 bins : int or sequence or str, default: :rc:`hist.bins`
6603 If *bins* is an integer, it defines the number of equal-width bins
6604 in the range.
6605  
6606 If *bins* is a sequence, it defines the bin edges, including the
6607 left edge of the first bin and the right edge of the last bin;
6608 in this case, bins may be unequally spaced. All but the last
6609 (righthand-most) bin is half-open. In other words, if *bins* is::
6610  
6611 [1, 2, 3, 4]
6612  
6613 then the first bin is ``[1, 2)`` (including 1, but excluding 2) and
6614 the second ``[2, 3)``. The last bin, however, is ``[3, 4]``, which
6615 *includes* 4.
6616  
6617 If *bins* is a string, it is one of the binning strategies
6618 supported by `numpy.histogram_bin_edges`: 'auto', 'fd', 'doane',
6619 'scott', 'stone', 'rice', 'sturges', or 'sqrt'.
6620  
6621 range : tuple or None, default: None
6622 The lower and upper range of the bins. Lower and upper outliers
6623 are ignored. If not provided, *range* is ``(x.min(), x.max())``.
6624 Range has no effect if *bins* is a sequence.
6625  
6626 If *bins* is a sequence or *range* is specified, autoscaling
6627 is based on the specified bin range instead of the
6628 range of x.
6629  
6630 density : bool, default: False
6631 If ``True``, draw and return a probability density: each bin
6632 will display the bin's raw count divided by the total number of
6633 counts *and the bin width*
6634 (``density = counts / (sum(counts) * np.diff(bins))``),
6635 so that the area under the histogram integrates to 1
6636 (``np.sum(density * np.diff(bins)) == 1``).
6637  
6638 If *stacked* is also ``True``, the sum of the histograms is
6639 normalized to 1.
6640  
6641 weights : (n,) array-like or None, default: None
6642 An array of weights, of the same shape as *x*. Each value in
6643 *x* only contributes its associated weight towards the bin count
6644 (instead of 1). If *density* is ``True``, the weights are
6645 normalized, so that the integral of the density over the range
6646 remains 1.
6647  
6648 cumulative : bool or -1, default: False
6649 If ``True``, then a histogram is computed where each bin gives the
6650 counts in that bin plus all bins for smaller values. The last bin
6651 gives the total number of datapoints.
6652  
6653 If *density* is also ``True`` then the histogram is normalized such
6654 that the last bin equals 1.
6655  
6656 If *cumulative* is a number less than 0 (e.g., -1), the direction
6657 of accumulation is reversed. In this case, if *density* is also
6658 ``True``, then the histogram is normalized such that the first bin
6659 equals 1.
6660  
6661 bottom : array-like, scalar, or None, default: None
6662 Location of the bottom of each bin, i.e. bins are drawn from
6663 ``bottom`` to ``bottom + hist(x, bins)`` If a scalar, the bottom
6664 of each bin is shifted by the same amount. If an array, each bin
6665 is shifted independently and the length of bottom must match the
6666 number of bins. If None, defaults to 0.
6667  
6668 histtype : {'bar', 'barstacked', 'step', 'stepfilled'}, default: 'bar'
6669 The type of histogram to draw.
6670  
6671 - 'bar' is a traditional bar-type histogram. If multiple data
6672 are given the bars are arranged side by side.
6673 - 'barstacked' is a bar-type histogram where multiple
6674 data are stacked on top of each other.
6675 - 'step' generates a lineplot that is by default unfilled.
6676 - 'stepfilled' generates a lineplot that is by default filled.
6677  
6678 align : {'left', 'mid', 'right'}, default: 'mid'
6679 The horizontal alignment of the histogram bars.
6680  
6681 - 'left': bars are centered on the left bin edges.
6682 - 'mid': bars are centered between the bin edges.
6683 - 'right': bars are centered on the right bin edges.
6684  
6685 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical'
6686 If 'horizontal', `~.Axes.barh` will be used for bar-type histograms
6687 and the *bottom* kwarg will be the left edges.
6688  
6689 rwidth : float or None, default: None
6690 The relative width of the bars as a fraction of the bin width. If
6691 ``None``, automatically compute the width.
6692  
6693 Ignored if *histtype* is 'step' or 'stepfilled'.
6694  
6695 log : bool, default: False
6696 If ``True``, the histogram axis will be set to a log scale.
6697  
6698 color : color or array-like of colors or None, default: None
6699 Color or sequence of colors, one per dataset. Default (``None``)
6700 uses the standard line color sequence.
6701  
6702 label : str or None, default: None
6703 String, or sequence of strings to match multiple datasets. Bar
6704 charts yield multiple patches per dataset, but only the first gets
6705 the label, so that `~.Axes.legend` will work as expected.
6706  
6707 stacked : bool, default: False
6708 If ``True``, multiple data are stacked on top of each other If
6709 ``False`` multiple data are arranged side by side if histtype is
6710 'bar' or on top of each other if histtype is 'step'
6711  
6712 Returns
6713 -------
6714 n : array or list of arrays
6715 The values of the histogram bins. See *density* and *weights* for a
6716 description of the possible semantics. If input *x* is an array,
6717 then this is an array of length *nbins*. If input is a sequence of
6718 arrays ``[data1, data2, ...]``, then this is a list of arrays with
6719 the values of the histograms for each of the arrays in the same
6720 order. The dtype of the array *n* (or of its element arrays) will
6721 always be float even if no weighting or normalization is used.
6722  
6723 bins : array
6724 The edges of the bins. Length nbins + 1 (nbins left edges and right
6725 edge of last bin). Always a single array even when multiple data
6726 sets are passed in.
6727  
6728 patches : `.BarContainer` or list of a single `.Polygon` or list of \
6729 such objects
6730 Container of individual artists used to create the histogram
6731 or list of such containers if there are multiple input datasets.
6732  
6733 Other Parameters
6734 ----------------
6735 data : indexable object, optional
6736 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER
6737  
6738 **kwargs
6739 `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties
6740  
6741 See Also
